PARA.TAB: Mr ACTING SPEAKER (Mr Nehl) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 11 September, on motion by Mr Costello:
That the bill be now read a second time.
upon which Mr Gareth Evans moved by way of amendment:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
"whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House notes that:
(1) the Budget betrays the Australian promise of working towards a more fair, just, inclusive and united society;
(2) the Budget is both mindless and heartless, and its prescriptions are not what the Australian economy needs at present;
(3) the Budget will have a savagely contractionary impact on economic growth and make impossible the job creation necessary to reduce Australia's still unacceptably high level of unemployment;
(4) with stronger economic growth the Budget could be restored to underlying balance over the life of this Parliament through a much more moderate program of fiscal consolidation;

(5) the spending cuts and tax increases contained in the Budget are, on the evidence of the Government's own Budget Papers, not necessary to reduce the Commonwealth Government's debt‐to‐GDP ratio and will not produce a significant improvement in the current account deficit;

(6) the Budget not only offers no hope to the unemployed but actively harms their prospects of finding a job by cutting labour market programs and privatising the previously publicly provided employment service function of the CES;
(7) the Budget will have unfair and unjust consequences for the struggling and disadvantaged in our midst—the poor, the old, the sick, indigenous Australians and newly‐arrived migrants;

(8) the many spending cuts concerned with education and training, research and development, trade development (including breaches of promise with respect to EMDG, ITES and IAMP), production bounties, and other business support, will be counter‐productive in their longer term consequences;

(9) there is deception involved in the family tax package contained in the Budget, whereby what the Prime Minister appears to be putting into one pocket is for most middle Australian families being taken right out of the other by the Treasurer in higher education fees, Austudy changes, higher nursing home charges, higher fees and charges;

(10) there are many breaches of Coalition election promises contained in this Budget, which amount to over $17 billion over four years, and which will cause hardship, insecurity, and dismay for millions of Australians;

(11) the Budget involves a massive betrayal of regional Australia through the abolition of the $150 million regional development programme, large cuts to road funding, the closure of regional Government offices such as Medicare and CES offices, and the cuts to the ABC and university funding;
(12) the mean‐spirited decision to introduce large, up‐front entry fees and massively increased daily fees for nursing homes, and increase user‐charges will harm elderly Australians;
(13) the abolition of Childcare Operational Subsidies will impact heavily upon community based child care centres;

(14) the reduction of $800 million over four years in public hospital funding will cause longer waiting lists for the sick and reduce the quality of hospital and medical assistance for millions of people;
(15) the Budget involves a breaking of the Government's so called `core' commitment to maintain Medicare in its entirety through cuts to rebates for numerous items under Medicare;
(16) the cruel decision to abolish the Commonwealth Dental Health Programme will cause serious problems for the less well off;
(17) harsh and promise‐breaking decisions will force Australian families to pay substantially more for the cost of their prescription medicines;
(18) the massive funding cuts to education, the increased HECS charges and AUSTUDY changes will penalise the less well‐off;
(19) the Budget's comprehensive and ideological assault on the public sector will cost 10,500 jobs in 1996‐97 alone;

(20) the Government has failed to honour its election commitment to maintain the environment budget and to provide an additional $84 million in the 1996‐97 Budget, instead cutting by 13 per cent the environmental budget and forward estimates;

(21) the reckless decision to reduce funding for the National Highway by $622 million over four years, breaches a clear Coalition election commitment at the 1996 election, and with other decisions will reduce the level of public infrastructure investment, especially in regional Australia;
(22) the decision to impose a 500 per cent increase in the taxation arrangements for visits to the Great Barrier Reef will discourage tourism and cost jobs in Queensland;

(23) the Government has failed to honour its promise to not cut Australia's foreign aid beyond the election commitment to abolish the DIFF program, and in doing so will allow the estimated ODA/GDP ratio for Australia in 1996‐97 to fall to 0.29 per cent;

(24) the Government has failed to honour its election promise that Defence expenditure would not be cut, whilst cutting $165 million from the 1995 Defence Budget estimates for 1996‐97, and reducing Defence expenditure as a percentage of GDP to its lowest level since 1939;
(25) the mean‐spirited and discriminatory approach to migrants and ethnic communities will harm outworkers, hurt newly‐arrived migrants and refugees, cut humanitarian aid and penalise asylum seekers;
(26) the substantial cuts to ATSIC and to indigenous‐related Commonwealth programs represent a massive setback to the process of reconciliation in Australia;
(27) the savage cuts to the ABC, of $209 million over four years, are in complete breach of the Coalition's solemn election promise to maintain existing levels of Commonwealth funding to the ABC;
(28) the Budget has failed to honour the promise to maintain levels of arts funding and spend an additional $60 million over three years; and

(29) the Government's plan to substantially increase Commonwealth court and tribunal fees, coupled with deep cuts to legal aid, will result in a severe curtailment of access to justice by many Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Martin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In addressing the question of the budget, can I say that, while it might take some time for people to realise it, this budget marks the end of an era—and a very important era. It marks the end of an era in which Australian governments have tried to achieve full employment for their citizens: the concept of all Australians being entitled to a job and to a real job opportunity.

SPEECH.PARA: The clearest indicator of this is the decision in the budget to abolish the Commonwealth Employment Service. The CES was set up in 1946, exactly half a century ago. It was an integral part of the postwar consensus shaped by the Labor Party and which has survived up until now to strive for full employment. So important was the idea of a Commonwealth Employment Service, of a free employment exchange, in the project of postwar reconstruction that it was enshrined in an international convention. In 1949, member nations of the ILO, following the declaration of Philadelphia that established the ILO and set up in bright lights the question of full employment as an objective for all nations, resolved to phase out fee‐charging employment agencies. They did this so that all nations would maintain or ensure the maintenance of a free employment service.

This was to be an employment service available to all workers. The concept of one nation was for all Australians to have access to a free employment service irrespective of where you lived—be it metropolitan Australia or country and regional Australia. It is interesting to note that, following the establishment of the Commonwealth Employment Service in 1946, a network of Commonwealth Employment Service offices all around Australia was established as a result of that decision, the decision of this parliament. It was important because this was to be an employment service available to all workers—not just those who could pass a mean‐spirited government's `capacity to benefit' test, as is the Howard government's approach of today.

The other components of that great postwar consensus included the 1944 White Paper on Full Employment and a bold program of public works such as the Snowy Mountains scheme—a scheme which I think we all believe was of the utmost importance to the future of Australia. That scheme also, as part of postwar reconstruction, gave the opportunity to many people to come to Australia from a range of countries around the world and to contribute to the development of this great nation. These creations came about because of the vision of people like Ben Chifley, the then Labor Prime Minister.

It is interesting to note that the then opposition supported the establishment of the Commonwealth Employment Service. The reason the then Labor government brought these schemes in and supported not only decent national infrastructure projects but also the Commonwealth Employment Service was that people who had experienced the scourge of mass unemployment in the Depression of the 1930s decided that they had an obligation to ensure that it would never be repeated.

The people who benefited were people like my own father, who was given the opportunity for trade training and work as a bricklayer by the policies of putting jobs first pursued by the postwar Labor government. It is interesting to note that those very people were offered a six-month training course not dissimilar to those opportunities provided under Working Nation. The objective was to ensure that, having been given access to some basic training and to the opportunity of getting some basic skills, they were then given the very experience in industry which would ensure that they were not only job ready but also capable of accessing ongoing, meaningful employment. A generation of Australians was appreciative of the programs pursued by the likes of Ben Chifley, just as I say that a generation of Australians would have benefited by the current government pursuing the type of Working Nation initiatives put in place by the previous government.

All governments, Labor and Liberal, to varying degrees have stuck to the goal of full employment since that time. Social changes and changes in the world economy, particularly since 1973, have naturally made that goal much harder to attain than in the long years of postwar post economic boom. The goal itself, I am pleased to say, has always been upheld until now. But not now—no, not any more—not after the first Howard budget.

BREAK.PARA: This budget marks the first time since the Second World War that a new government has failed to even try to reduce unemployment in its first budget. That is what it has failed to do: it has failed to even suggest that its primary objective at the moment—in its first budget, in its first term of government—is to reduce unemployment. This budget is the first time since the Great Depression of the 1930s that an Australian government has wilfully ignored the curse of unemployment and, more importantly, deliberately withdrawn services from those disadvantaged people in many areas of Australia, especially in regional Australia.

The Howard government has effectively, through the budget, thrown the towel in and stated publicly that unemployment is now no longer a priority. What a disgrace to think that in 1996 the number one challenge confronting Australia—the question of reducing unemployment—is not a priority in the Howard government's agenda.

There are many challenges confronting Australia. If you go out into mainstream Australia, into the suburbs and the regions of Australia, all they want to talk about at the moment is the ongoing responsibility of both sides of the Australian parliament to put their heads together and do something about the question of unemployment because those people do not want to see a generation lost without opportunity and without a capacity to pursue a meaningful opportunity in life. That is why I say that, without a doubt, the Howard government—and, yes, they ought to hang their heads in shame—have thrown the towel in and stated publicly that unemployment is not a priority.

The Commonwealth Employment Service is staffed—and I am pleased to say this—by thousands of dedicated men and women around Australia. Unlike some on the other side of the House would suggest, those men and women who staff the CES take on the difficult task day in and day out of matching job seekers with available job vacancies. To their credit they help steer the long-term unemployed into suitable case management, training and support.

There are 1.8 million Australians who use the Commonwealth Employment Service each year. I tell you why they use it—because they know that the staff of the Commonwealth Employment Service are dedicated men and women in the suburbs of metropolitan Australia, in the suburbs of regional centres of Australia—

TALK.START.PARA: —Your policies forced them to use it.

—Even in the Northern Territory, for the information of the member for the Northern Territory. Those men and women are totally consumed with their desire to assist in matching job seekers with available job vacancies.

BREAK.PARA: I recently had an opportunity to speak to some of those dedicated people at Casuarina CES in the Northern Territory. I can tell this House that they are totally concerned with the need to maintain that local CES office, to maintain the opportunity to ensure that they have ongoing resources and support from government to do something about matching job seekers with available job vacancies.

The real problem is that they question whether or not the member for the Northern Territory (Mr Dondas) was prepared to stand up and fight for a network of CES offices throughout the Northern Territory rather than throw the towel in, just as he threw it in with respect to the Office of Northern Development when this government said that it was no longer a priority for the Howard government to assist with regional development in Australia. Just as he was not prepared to stand up for the Office of Northern Development, he is not prepared to stand up for a network of CES offices throughout the Northern Territory.

The local CES is part of our community around Australia. It is a vital part of our sadly fraying community infrastructure. It is an integral part of the balanced set of approaches we started under Working Nation to improve service delivery. If it goes, it will be sorely missed by thousands upon thousands of Australians. It will weaken the very delivery of the active labour market program support that we introduced in government.

High fees, I suggest, will be charged by the new competing employment placing enterprises—the so-called EPEs—in most cases, enabling significant profits to be made by those favoured in the process. The quality of the new job finding services will be diminished—yes, diminished—because of the cuts in resources for their regulation.

The long-term unemployed and people living in remote areas, such as in Cairns, Townsville or Rockhampton, and in regions of high unemployment will particularly feel the cut in services as the profit‐driven EPEs will not be interested in helping the long-term unemployed—the most difficult cases—because it is all too hard and the profit margin is not large enough.

The government is walking away from the unemployed, just like Margaret Thatcher did in Great Britain. No-one should be fooled by the idea that their CES is going to be adequately replaced by the so-called one-stop shop—the as yet unnamed service delivery agency. It will be a one-stop shop for the long-term unemployed—no services, no opportunity in life and condemned to benefits for the rest of their lives, be it in seats such as Lowe, the Northern Territory, Capricornia or Leichhardt.

Let me make it clear. There is nothing wrong in principle with combining the resources of the current social security offices with the resources of the CES offices. This is a direction in which the previous Labor government was moving. Its objective was to make it simpler for unemployed people to obtain both jobsearch assistance and benefit payments at one location. But that is not what is going to happen now. Mark my words, what is going to happen now is entirely different from what was a fair and practical objective with respect to the establishment of a one-stop shop.

What is going to happen under the Howard government's budget initiatives is that the Commonwealth Employment Service is going to be abolished. Its essential services are going to be sold off to the private sector providers for profit. We are going back to the era of fee-charging employment agencies—the very thing we sought to outlaw in 1946 when we established right throughout Australia a network of CES offices on the basis that it is one nation.

There are plans afoot to have a massive 5,000 fewer staff in the new network of offices than in the old. Yes, another 5,000 jobs going and you can imagine the impact that is going to have on regional Australia in places such as Launceston, where we have already seen the closure of the local CES office; Newcastle, where we have already seen the closure of the Belmont office; Cairns, where we have already seen the closure of the Mareeba CES office since the election; Mowbray; North Melbourne; South Melbourne; and Granville in western Sydney.

These are places that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) might be naturally concerned with in respect of unemployment; places where those citizens of Australia depend on the CES office, respect it and support the dedicated staff who go out of their way to assist them. I suggest that the Prime Minister go and ask the people in these suburbs and towns what they think about losing their CES and its associated jobs.

The abolition of the CES represents a huge reduction in service for job seekers. The one-stop shop is just a public relations gloss to divert attention from this violent crime, this violent change which is to be inflicted on the jobless. There is no advantage in having a one-stop shop if there are only half as many shops and if the queues there are twice as long. There is even less advantage if the office's doors are permanently closed to many thousands of job seekers whom the government cannot even be bothered to help.

These cuts in employment assistance are taking place at John Howard's personal insistence—mark it: at John Howard's personal insistence. I wonder whether John Howard has any idea of how badly the morale and commitment of CES offices has been hit by his decision to destroy their service. When people see and feel the difference in their lives that the absence of a CES makes, we are going to remind them endlessly of who took it away—the Howard coalition government.

People always want unemployment to improve when they change their government. Even the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) understands that. Last night on the 7.30 Report Minister Vanstone stated not once but twice that, if the government did not reduce unemployment, it would not be re‐elected. By this action she has set the jobs target that John Howard has been running away from as the Prime Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Please refer to the Prime Minister by his correct title.

—By this action she has set the jobs target that the Prime Minister has been running away from time and time again. I can understand why the coalition is so sensitive about this concept. If a party promises to do something about unemployment, the electorate expects it to do something about unemployment. It is not going to be conned by the failure of the Prime Minister and the government to face up to their responsibilities.

BREAK.PARA: But this government have suddenly stopped talking about reducing unemployment. They have stopped talking about it as part of a political strategy. They think that they can portray the unemployed as being on the edges of society, away from the mainstream of Australia. Yes, push them over the cliff and pretend that they do not exist.

But the problem is that they do exist. They exist in the suburbs of metropolitan Australia and they exist in regional Australia. They are not going to go away because unemployment today is an issue which concerns all Australians. Whether you have a job or not, you regard unemployment as the number one issue that we as a nation have to continue to make progress on.

Unemployment is an issue which concerns all of us, not just those who are currently out of work but also those who fear being out of work, such as the 30,000 public servants who will lose their jobs in the first 18 months of the new government—in fact, all those people who have a sense of insecurity about their lives and the lives of their families at the moment. That will not instil a sense of confidence in the economy and ensure that it achieves adequate growth rates to achieve the five per cent jobs target that we established in the previous government—a target that would have been achieved as the economic and social strategy that we had put in place was maintained.

The Australian community knows that it is wrong to chop over 200,000 places from labour market programs this year because that will sell their futures and their kids' futures short. It will sell the community short and create a series of little ghettos all around Australia. That in turn will impact on mainstream Australia—the mainstream Australia that the Prime Minister likes to wrap himself around. The Prime Minister cannot accept that we as a nation will not tolerate a series of little ghettos all around Australia, and the situation will be worse by a reduction over the next four years of labour market expenditure of $1.8 billion.

I suggest that unemployment is something that the Prime Minister claimed to be concerned about during the election. He has now walked away from his responsibilities. The Australian community knows that, above all, we need a new set of policies to create more jobs—policies which expand our nation's growth, not contract it.

The surveys of employment vacancies since this government was elected show that vacancies have already slumped to their lowest level in years. The burst of confidence normally associated with a new government is glaringly absent. Little wonder, given that in the six months since this government took office it has moved to axe some 30,000 jobs in the public sector, up to another 30,000 in Telstra and countless more in higher education. Now, with this no jobs budget—that is what it is—another $8 billion is to be taken out of the economy over the next two years.

What will that do for economic confidence and the capacity of the economy to grow? According to the outlays in the budget papers, for the employment creation activities and labour market programs, a massive $1.8 billion was taken out. But only $160 million was put into the modern Australian apprenticeship and training scheme for the young unemployed. And they say that MAATS is the panacea for resolving unemployment in Australia!

I hope the member for the Northern Territory is listening because I know that local communities in towns in the Northern Territory very much supported the Working Nation initiatives and the putting in place of infrastructure developments that the Northern Territory government denied them. What is their expense from MAATS over four years? It is only another $160 million, a pretty miserable amount. The token amount of money put in by the new government will have no effect in reducing youth unemployment.

I support Labor's amendments to the second reading motion. Labor will never give up striving for full employment as this government has given up. We will revive this great ideal. We will devise the means to attain it just as the Australian people expect their governments to do. The issue of the day is unemployment. I contend that it is about time that the new government lived up to its responsibilities. It should set a jobs target because anyone who wants to achieve anything in life should be prepared to set targets. (Time expired)
Motion (by Mr Rocher) put:
That the member for Curtin be now heard.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zammit, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to join this debate on the Appropriation Bill, but before I go into the main part of what I wish to say, I would like to make passing reference to some matters raised by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson). He did raise some interesting points. In his almost 20‐minute address, he spent nearly all of his time talking about two specific matters: unemployment and the CES. He said that the Howard government is sensitive about the issue of unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt that the Howard coalition government is very sensitive about the issue of unemployment. One of the reasons we were elected with such an overwhelming majority is that people were telling us that they were feeling sensitive about the issue of unemployment. It is an indictment on Labor—a party that purports to stand for working class Australia—that, after 13 years in government, there are one million Australians who are unemployed.

The honourable member for Batman mentioned the scourge of mass unemployment, and that is absolutely right. After 13 years, we do have a scourge of unemployment. He said that everywhere he goes in Australia, he is told by average Australians that the government and the opposition should put their heads together to reduce unemployment. I think that is absolutely right. The people I speak to are saying to me, `Why doesn't the Labor Party join the government in attacking the question of unemployment, in doing something specific and something concrete about unemployment?'

The feigned concern that the Labor Party have for the unemployed was brought home to me when, at the request of former New South Wales Premier Greiner, I represented New South Wales at a meeting of state treasurers here in Canberra. The then Prime Minister of Australia, Bob Hawke, was sitting only a couple of seats away from me in the cabinet room. He asked the Treasury officials, `What is the situation regarding the LTUs?' I had never heard of such a phrase. I felt a bit uneasy because I thought that if I were to ask the New South Wales Treasury officials what LTUs were, they might tell me that I should know what they were. I did not know, so I thought I had better find out. I turned to the Treasury officials and asked, `What are the LTUs that the Prime Minister is referring to?' They replied, `Long-term unemployed.' For a Labor Prime Minister of Australia to refer to the one million Australians—half a million of whom are long-term unemployed—by using the acronym LTU is indicative that those opposite have lost their commitment to the people who are unemployed.

The other matter that was raised by the member for Batman was the question of the CES. He kept saying repeatedly that the new government is going to abolish the CES. I put it to the honourable member for Batman that there is a very big difference between abolishing and re-organising.

The CES is well intentioned, but it has not delivered. With one million Australians out of work and with no hope for a reduction in long-term unemployment, the CES has to adopt a different attitude and a different way of doing things. As I have said, there is no doubt that the staff of the CES are committed. They all work hard and no-one should decry their involvement and their commitment. However, it has not been working and something must be done. There is no doubt that the CES will find that, once they get re-organised and they merge with the Department of Social Security in a one-stop shop, costs will come down and a better service will be provided.

I turn now to the budget. If there is anything that defined the attitude of the previous Keating Labor government to budgets it is deficit and debt. When we came into government we found that the underlying deficit for 1995 was $10.3 billion. We face a starting point deficit for 1996-97 of $9.6 billion. The emphasis in this budget is on reducing the deficit. In my opinion, the best outcome is a return of confidence in the economy. There will be a $3.9 billion reduction in the deficit this year and a further $3.3 billion reduction in the deficit next year—that is, a reduction in the deficit of $7.2 billion.

What was scandalous with regard to the attitude of the former government was its own purpose spending. During the past five years, own purpose spending for the federal Labor government grew by an astounding 45 per cent. I have rarely seen growth to that extent and the former Labor government should be ashamed of itself for allowing its own purpose spending to grow by 45 per cent in a three‐year period.

Despite all the tough but fair and responsible financial measures taken by the Howard government to reduce spending, we still face a deficit of $5.6 billion in 1996-97 and a deficit of $1.5 billion the year after. If the Keating government had been re-elected, there is no doubt that Australia's credit rating would have been further eroded with all the consequential results.

It is very interesting to note that in the mid‐1980s Australia enjoyed a AAA credit rating. In the mid‐1980s, after only a few years of Labor government, Moody's decided to downgrade Australia's credit rating from AAA to AA1 and at the same time Standard and Poor's downgraded Australia's credit rating to AA plus. In 1989, for the second time, Standard and Poor's downgraded Australia's credit rating from AA plus down to AA. In 1989, Moody's reduced Australia's credit rating from AA1 to AA2.

This means a great deal on the international economic front. There is no doubt that a risk premium is added to Australia's borrowings with any downgrading of our credit rating. The result of the addition of a risk premium means that Australians have to pay more to borrow money. That is an impost on Australia and Australians—an impost that has to be paid. As a result, the cost of living goes up, the cost of borrowing goes up and the cost of running businesses goes up.

It is very interesting to note that, as a result of this budget, Standard and Poor's has announced only very recently that Australia could, after 13 years, have its credit rating upgraded. That is a very positive thing for Australia and all Australians.

I turn now to the question of promises kept. First of all, I want to refer to self‐funded retirees. The tax rebate for all self‐funded retirees, costing up to $80 million, has been instituted. Child‐care cash rebates costing in the vicinity of $120 million per year have been retained more or less in general terms. The subsidy for private health insurance has been delivered at $450.

This is a tough but fair budget which shares the burden. That is another way to describe it—tough but fair. There is to be a higher Medicare levy for high income earners—something the former government did not have the courage to tackle. The seniors card, costing about $160 million, has been retained.

The other matter I believe is very important and needs to be addressed in this parliament is that of rich tax avoiders. It is very interesting that the former Labor government waited until three weeks, or maybe even two weeks, before the election to say that, if they are returned, they will address the issue of rich tax avoiders. Why did they wait for 13 years to say something about this rort, which is costing the average Australian a lot of money? This situation is unnecessary and should have been tackled. I was very glad to see that rich tax avoiders will have to pay a fair amount of money to consolidated revenue. It is expected that some $100 million will be collected. Labor failed to act, and the Howard government has now addressed this very important issue.

In regard to the Beazley black hole, the $8 billion, the August 1995 budget papers showed Treasury's forward estimates of government spending and revenue. They indicated to us that that would be in the vicinity of $2 billion or $3 billion. In February 1996, just prior to the election, Treasury made available to the government the estimates, which were secreted away by a drowning Keating Labor government and not shown to the coalition until after the election win. They showed the forward estimates for 1995—that is, for the 1996-97 year, with outlays at $135 billion and income at $134 billion. This was the situation prior to the information being made available.

Upon coming to government, we found an increase in outlays of $2 billion, bringing that up to $137 billion—this information was not passed on to the Howard‐Fischer coalition—and that income was reduced by $4 billion. So there was $137 billion in outlays and $129 billion in income. We should have known about all this prior to the election. In all honesty the former government should have made that information available, but they chose not to and are now screaming when we talk about the Beazley black hole. No wonder they are screaming. They are saying we should have known. How could we have known when they had that information and kept it from the opposition? This will not happen again.

The Costello budget is deflationary. Last year—that is, 1995-96—spending grew at 3.9 per cent, which is reasonable. This year there will be a zero growth rate as a result of the Keating government's policies. Following the forward estimates coming into effect, the growth rate this year is zero, and that is an indictment of the former government.

This budget has an emphasis on small business. The labour market programs, which the honourable member for Batman referred to at great length, have cost the Australian taxpayer billions of dollars and have failed miserably. The former government threw money at all these problems with no long-term planning and put people into a job for a while and then threw them out of it when the money ran out. Look at all the programs the former government put in place: One Nation, Investing in the Nation, Working Nation, Creative Nation—and so the list goes on.

The Australian public, the Australian electorate, were very patient with the former government. They gave the former government a good go and they just did not deliver. The most effective way any government can genuinely assist the unemployed is by getting the economy right. Governments borrowing money to provide short-term jobs are only putting the inevitable off as they will ultimately have to face up to the fact that borrowings have to be repaid and the losers are again the unemployed, especially the long-term unemployed. A healthy small business sector is the quickest and only way to take up employment. This budget, within present constraints, goes a long way towards achieving that goal—for example, by providing relief in relation to capital gains tax.

I want to refer to jobs growth, because the honourable member for Batman spent all of his 20‐minute contribution on jobs and I think it is vitally important we set the record straight. At the beginning of the year, jobs growth was about three per cent. We need five per cent jobs growth to bring unemployment down to a reasonable level—if any unemployment is reasonable. More recently, because of the former government's policies, jobs growth has dwindled to about one per cent. So how can the honourable member for Batman or the opposition say that they should not have been kicked out of government when the growth rate has been reduced to the vicinity of one per cent? Very large numbers of Australians will have no future unless jobs growth is increased substantially.

I know some commentators have said that a reduction in spending and the tightening of fiscal measures will mean an even slower jobs growth. However, that assertion has to be seen in the context of the $4 billion reduction in spending in 1996-97 compared with Australia's GDP, which is in the vicinity of $460 billion. That is a one per cent reduction. As I mentioned previously, the renewed confidence in small and medium business will bring about the uplift of the economy. This budget provides the necessary framework and, in conjunction with industrial relations changes—especially the changes to the unfair dismissal laws to make them fair dismissal laws by protecting the rights of employers and the employees—will go a long way towards that.

I would like to say a lot more about industrial relations changes because they are needed to increase the work force substantially and are one of the cornerstones of this budget. However, time is running out—I have only three or four minutes left—so in my concluding remarks I want to refer to the very important issue of fiscal transparency.

In my view, one of the most underrated achievements in the presentation of these budget papers is on the table demonstration; that is, the above‐the‐board demonstration to the electorate of the true operating situation. In other words, there are to be no more mirrors and smokescreens. The Treasurer (Mr Costello) must be commended for showing leadership, the likes of which has not been demonstrated by other Treasurers in the last decade or so.

The use of words such as `headline balance', which is technical jargon used to describe the budget balance and is virtually useless in trying to determine the exact position, is now going to be a thing of the past. These headline balances in the past used asset sales and other such items as income to cloud the issue. Whilst it is technically correct to say that an asset sale is income and therefore should be included as part of the budget process and shown as a plus, we all know that the sale of an asset is a once only item. Therefore it is irresponsible to show it as income for the purpose of balancing the budget, because you cannot keep selling an asset that has already been sold.

This budget and future budgets will show the underlying budget position, which is the only fair and just process to follow, so that the electorate obtains an accurate position of what the government is doing with the moneys that, after all, belong to the people. The measures taken in this budget will do what the former Labor government has failed to do, and that is, encourage domestic savings which will result in more domestic investment in the public spheres. The huge external debt will fall exponentially, aided by the $6 billion the government will apply to reduce that debt as a result of the partial sale of Telstra.

There is no doubt that these long overdue measures will result in the short-term stabilisation of interest rates and in fact could well mean a modest reduction in the rates early next year. Unless grave and unforeseen circumstances occur, what is absolutely certain is that in the long run interest rates will fall and that will mean that business will begin to again invest in stock and capital equipment, resulting in a lift in productivity and a reduction in unemployment.

I conclude by saying that the Treasurer has set the benchmark in this budget for future budgets and he must be commended, as I said earlier. Perhaps the headline in the Australian Financial Review of 21 August 1996 put it best when it said about the Treasurer and the budget `A job well done'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tanner, Lindsay, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This budget is a mean and nasty budget. It is a budget in the true John Howard tradition from his days as Treasurer. It is a budget which is contractionary. It is a budget which will reduce the degree of growth that has been left by the former government. It is a budget for high unemployment. It is a budget which attacks the living standards of low income earners and the battlers that this government so hypocritically purports to represent. Particularly, it is a budget that fails to address the nation's transport problems. I will devote the early part of my remarks to the areas that specifically relate to my shadow ministry.

SPEECH.PARA: The first and most significant area with respect to the budget in the transport area is the issue of roads. It is an issue that the National Party in particular has long tried to make its own. It is an issue that Labor governments have often been criticised for in relation to the amounts they have devoted to road development in public expenditure.

Lo and behold: what have we seen after the promises that have been made by the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, Mr Sharp, and the coalition to maintain Labor's commitments to national highway funding, to maintain Labor's commitments to payments to the states and local government with respect to roads and, in addition, to spend $65 million per year over 10 years on the Pacific Highway and $36 million a year over four years on the black spots program? What have we seen delivered?

In relation to the specific promises with respect to the Pacific Highway and black spots; yes, they have been delivered. Funding to local government and the states is virtually identical over the four‐year period of the forward estimates to that which was proposed by Labor. But where the big cut occurs and where the big damage occurs is in the national highway program. Six hundred and twenty-two million dollars over four years is to be taken out of the national highway program. Even if you ignore the promise to make the new commitments to the Pacific Highway and black spots additional to existing commitments and factor in the amounts there, you still end up with funding that is more than $50 million per year over the four years—over $200 million over the four years—less than what the former Labor government was going to commit.

PARA.BREAK: Of course, the minister has tried to fudge this by saying, `We're actually spending a little bit more than was spent last year.' But that is not what was promised. What was promised was maintenance of existing com mitments and additional funding for specific programs. That promise has been explicitly broken, and broken to the tune of $620-odd million.

SPEECH.PARA: People in Townsville are now asking, `What is happening to the Woolcock Street extension?' People in western Sydney are wondering what is going to happen to the western orbital, so vital for infrastructure development and employment in western Sydney. In many other parts of Australia, areas that depend on national highway funding are now asking, `What is John Sharp doing for us?'

The second area that is suffering, and is going to suffer further as a result of the release yesterday of the Brew report with respect to the Australian National Railways Commission, is rail funding. The former government was committed to $370 million over five years to develop Australia's interstate rail infrastructure under the guise of Track Australia.

The current government says that it is committed to something similar; but it has actually taken out $133 million over the next four years from the forward estimates—a $133 million cut from the forward estimates for funding for this program. It has committed no funding at all in the current budget, the excuse of course being the Brew inquiry into Australian National.

We actually got the executive summary of that report yesterday. Interestingly enough, the first recommendation of substance is that the government should proceed with the Track Australia proposal. So why it is that this inquiry and the complications with respect to the future of the various components of Australian National is in some way a barrier to proceeding with Track Australia is a bit hard to determine. Surely that is one recommendation that the minister can proceed with, irrespective of the outcome on the other issues.

But of course he has been done over. He has been done over by the Treasurer (Mr Costello), he has been done over by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and he has been done over by others in his own party who are more interested in the diesel fuel rebate. So the development of vital infrastructure which affects rural and regional Australia has not proceeded.

In the maritime industry we see stage 3 of the attack on Australia's shipping industry: the announced abolition of section 57AM of the Income Tax Assessment Act. This provides accelerated depreciation for Australian ships over five years—20 per cent. Almost all substantial items of capital equipment of an equivalent nature—such as trucks, crop‐dusting aircraft, bulldozers and a whole list of agricultural equipment—enjoy accelerated depreciation under the Income Tax Assessment Act as good as or better than this provision that provides for such depreciation for shipping.

That was part of the reform process introduced in the mid-1980s under the former Labor government. It was designed to ensure that labour efficiency was improved—and it has improved substantially, with crewing numbers improving dramatically on Australian ships from above 30 per ship to now about 18. It was also designed to improve capital efficiency.

Also in maritime, there were great promises to the people of Tasmania about the Bass Strait freight equalisation scheme: `We will maintain that scheme and we will add in another $49 million over three years to assist with a program that will reduce the fares for passengers and cars travelling across Bass Strait, matching a promise by the former government to provide $44 million for the equivalent purpose.' What has been delivered? A cut of $32.2 million over four years in the freight equalisation scheme, which will effectively flow through to higher prices for Tasmanians on a range of products.

The promise with respect to the vehicle equalisation scheme has been only half delivered: only about $24 million over three years is to be provided, which is slightly less than half of what was promised. Tasmanians have been conned by the Howard government, which promised but not delivered. As with issues like cabotage and the waterfront, they talk big, they promise lots of things, but when it comes to action and delivering they are nowhere to be found. The people who supported them and thought they might deliver are very quickly starting to get very disillusioned.

In aviation there is the question of Western Sydney Airport. When the bizarre proposal for Holsworthy as an alternative site for Sydney's second airport was first raised the very first issue—along with the specifics relating to the site—that the Labor Party raised was that this was a device to allow the government to put off expenditure on developing a second airport for Sydney into the never‐never; to delay, defer and obfuscate.

Of course the minister denied that: `No, we are still going full steam ahead. Labor was slow and was mucking around. We are going to do it straightaway; we are going to get to it.' What has happened in the budget? Some $73 million that had been in the forward estimates for this coming financial year for the development of the second airport for Sydney has gone and it does not appear in the out years. That gives us an indication of what the Holsworthy proposal is really about. It is about saving money for the government and allowing it to defer and obfuscate on the issue of a second airport for Sydney.

Then we move to safety and look at what has happened to the Federal Office of Road Safety—$2 million has been taken out of the public education program of the Federal Office of Road Safety. Half its budget has been obliterated. Why? It is the old conservative line that this is a function for the states. It takes you back to Malcolm Fraser's days when there was a long list of things that were functions of the states. When they were cut out of the federal arena, did they surface in the state arena? No. The end result, for all John Sharp's posturing with respect to road safety, is that all that has been achieved in this budget is cutting public education, a critical part of our road safety program.

Then we look at where the money has gone. He has managed to achieve for people who own planes a significant cut in the price of avgas. This is the government of the battlers that is changing the Australian tax system and the provision of social welfare to make sure they look after battlers. What we have is, on the one hand, people who own planes being able to pay slightly less for their avgas and, at the same time, the amount of money spent on road safety education is being reduced significantly.

The backdrop to all that is the scandalous fiasco with the minister and the Board of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority. He is meddling daily in the behaviour and activity of Australia's aviation safety regulator—at great risk, I hasten to add, to his future position as minister. The meddling continues. In the latest aviation report we see stories of his attempt to stack the committees and to determine who will chair the committees that have been established for industry consultation on the review of civil aviation safety regulations. So the minister is continuing to meddle in these things and is not tackling the real issues that face transport in this area.

Finally—the ultimate irony—we have a situation where he has presided over the abolition of the regional development part of his department. This is a senior National Party minister saying that the federal government has no role in regional development. I suggest that Sir John McEwen must be doing a few handstands in his grave as a result of that. Not only is he presiding over the abolition of regional development but the cost of redundancies in his department as a result of that decision is going to be taken out of the transport department's own administration budget. So up to 10 per cent of the total administration budget for the transport department—it is not a large administration budget; it is roughly about $100 million—is going to be paid to abolish the other part of the department. It is a disgrace and a joke. It illustrates how weak this minister has been and how much he has been done over by Finance and Treasury in this budget process.

I will now turn to the question of the broad macro-economic picture of the budget. The critical thing about this budget is that it is a high unemployment budget. That is the overriding issue when you look at the budget. The first thing is that unemployment is not expected to alter—so they give up straightaway. It is expected to be 8.25 per cent—and that is an optimistic assessment, for reasons I will get to in a second. No targets are set and there are no targets even for the out years; there are no estimates for the out years in the forward estimates.

Labour market programs are slashed by $1.8 billion over four years, so the long‐term unemployed who can benefit by having their employability and their skills improved by that program are being condemned to the scrap heap and told, `You can stay long‐term unemployed forever.'

Industry assistance has been slashed by an enormous amount: over $2.4 billion over four years. But that is job creating and export creating assistance. So jobs we are developing in areas such as the shipbuilding industry in Tasmania, South Australia and Western Australia are now under threat as a result of those decisions. Regional development has been slashed. So the freight centre, for example, that would have gone ahead at Cairns airport and which would have created substantial numbers of jobs in the Cairns region, including in the primary industry sector, will probably not be able to go ahead as a result of that decision. The end result is more jobs lost.

There have been 30,000 public servants sacked and another 24,000 people to be cut out of Telstra; and an overall contractionary budget which will take money out of the economy at the bottom end of a soft landing at a time when we need to have a steady‐as‐it‐goes policy and when we need to make sure that the fragile degree of growth that we have as a result of that soft landing should not be shattered. The minister is admitting that the long‐term unemployed rate may rise. The latest ANZ job vacancy figures indicate that in the August period we had the lowest job vacancies since March 1994. Saul Eslake, their chief economist, who is a former member of the Liberal Party—and may still be a member—says that the government's prediction of 8.25 per cent is optimistic.

This is just a softening up for the reality that we face in the future with respect to this government—that is, John Howard unemployment, John Howard 1982 unemployment, John Howard unemployment of 10 to 11 per cent, no improvement and long-term unemployed people, ordinary working people, the battlers that he says he represents, having no hope, no opportunities and no ability to look after themselves in a decent way with reasonable living standards and to look after their families.

We need to look at the macro-economic position to illustrate this point. In March the Treasurer said—he got all hairy chested; he tore open his shirt and the buttons popped off and there was the big hairy chest—`I'm going to cut $8 billion off outlays. There will be no soft options: $8 billion out of outlays.' What has happened? He has cut $5.2 billion out of outlays and taken $2 billion from the revenue side. Who has noticed this? Have any of the ultra right‐wing columnists—your Alan Mitchells and your Alan Woods—been dancing around and complaining about this? No, they have not. But that is what has happened. He has wimped his own test. He said he would cut $8 billion, but he cut only $5.2 billion.

Revenue is up by 7.5 per cent, or 4.6 per cent in real terms—a great achievement for a cutting Treasurer, isn't it? Outlays for this year are down by 0.5 per cent in real terms and 2.1 per cent in the next year. But what happens in the year after that? Forward estimates show that they are up by 5.7 per cent and a further 2.7 per cent after that. It is pretty obvious that the Treasurer understands the real impact of what he is doing—that is, that the contractionary impact will be such that growth will reduce, we will go into or close to recession and he will have to inflate the budget and he will have to increase outlays in a couple of years time to correct the damage.

The 1997‐98 forecast of a surplus of $6.6 billion and an underlying surplus of $1.5 billion assumes steady growth of 3.5 per cent, but that is a very brave and optimistic assumption when you have a very clearly contractionary budget. There is no question that we need a degree of fiscal constraint. There is no question that we need to improve the fiscal position. But that involves a tight balancing act to make sure that we do not throttle growth, which in itself damages our fiscal position more than just about anything else.

BREAK.PARA: We can get four per cent plus growth, which would wipe out over a period of two or three years most of the deficit. We can, at the same time, reduce outlays by small amounts—by $1 billion a year or a bit over $1 billion a year—over that time and reach balance within a couple of years. What we have is a re‐run of the twin deficits theory. The Treasurer and the Prime Minister do not admit it any more because it is so totally discredited, but in reality that is what is happening.

Treasury is still pushing the line that savings is the cause of the current account deficit. It is not a trade problem. It is not because we do not export enough and we import too much. It is not because we do not have any decent industry policy that assists Australian exporters and high-tech manufacturers and services exporters. It is because we do not save enough. We had that theory around in the past, and it is obviously discredited.

If you look at our own history, and if you look at what is happening in countries like Malaysia and New Zealand at the moment, budget cuts might increase public saving but they will diminish private saving, which will mean that people will lose jobs and, therefore, not save anywhere near as much, if at all, and that people will have to pay more for things like prescriptions, child care, HECS and the like. Are they going to save all that? So the consequences will be negative for savings.

We can now have a look at the actual cuts to see what in reality this budget is about—and it is a direct continuation of John Howard's track record as Treasurer in the Fraser government. The actual initiatives in the budget—and these are all over a four‐year period—are that HECS is to be increased, with a lower threshold, by $1.136 billion; university funding is down 4.9 per to $839 million; Austudy is hit and is down by $470 million; public hospitals, $800 million; child care down by $490 million; disability services, $113 million; the dental scheme, $400 million; the PBS, $402 million; Medicare changes receiving $411 million; nursing home cuts and aged care cuts, $478 million; the environment, $450 million; Murray-Darling Basin assistance, $93 million; legal aid, $101 million; and the ABC, ATSIC, labour market programs, road funding, as I have mentioned, and industry and regional development are all cut.

Who gets helped by all of these things—the dental scheme, PBS and Medicare? It is the battlers that they supposedly represent, the battlers that they say we are now the representatives of, and Peter Costello's blue‐collar workers. There are not many out there waving flags for him at the moment. It is an absolute joke that the Liberal Party should ever purport to represent blue‐collar workers because it hurts blue‐collar workers and it hurts battlers.

We can have a look at what they have not done. They have not touched the diesel fuel rebate and they have not actually addressed tax avoidance issues. The government knocked out a measly $100 million. Labor was going to knock $800 million out of the schemes that had been uncovered by the Taxation Office and Peter Costello has wimped that and said, `Oh, no, I've got too many friends involved in all of that sort of stuff, the big end of town, the people that I represent. So we'll give them a little bit of a touch‐up just to make it look good, but basically we are going to leave them alone.' Why should we be surprised? Because this is the party at the bottom of the harbour, this is John Howard, who sat on the worst tax avoidance schemes for years as Treasurer and watched the public revenue erode and who was not prepared to tackle the issue then, and they will not be prepared to tackle it now.

We need to compare this budget with the government's list of promises. They promised to maintain real labour market expenditure; to maintain all of the Commonwealth safety net concessions, such as the dental schemes and the PBS; to maintain hospital funding; to maintain Medicare; to maintain the rules with respect to HECS; to not cut child‐care funding; to maintain road commitments and spend more on other specific programs; to maintain ABC funding in real terms; to maintain Austudy—and so the list goes on. Those were the promises, those were the commitments, made by the Howard government in its period in opposition, in its period leading up to the last election. Those are all the commitments that have been broken by Honest John and his supporters. This is, as I said at the outset, a mean and nasty budget. It is—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The member has persistently not been referring to members by their correct title and has simply gone too far. The member will refer to the Prime Minister as the Prime Minister.

—I will avoid referring to the Prime Minister at all in my remaining remarks. This is a budget that has betrayed middle Australia. It has betrayed workers, it has betrayed battlers and it has condemned Australians to fewer jobs, lower growth, lower exports. It has done very little in the transport area, as much as anywhere else. It has done very little to tackle the real problems in Australian industry, to tackle the real problems of unemployment, industry development and productivity. This government thinks the response to the budget is good, but bit by bit it is going to find that the politics of this budget will unravel as people start to experience the specific aspects of the budget and start to realise what it means for them and their living standards.

SPEECH.PARA: So the situation we are in which leads the chair to believe we might be disruptive or in some way impeding the normal course of business of the House arises out of a failure of the standing orders to deal with the presence of Independent members. I submit that on each of the four or five occasions I have tried to speak under these circumstances I was the first on my feet. I know it is difficult, if there is someone on the other side to me, for the chair to necessarily notice me in the first place, but I suspect that that is not the case on every occasion. Knowing the problem that I was confronted with, you can rest assured that I was first out of the blocks on every occasion, including this morning. The chair might not necessarily have been able to see that, particularly if it was being guided by this speakers list, which has no standing, and was looking in the direction of the member whose name appears next to speak on the list.

We have the situation now, Madam Deputy Speaker, where the advice I obtained and was given is not to be applied on some motion that a member who rises to be heard before or at the start of the speaking time of another member is being disruptive. In itself, that cannot be disruptive, I put to you, because it is open to anyone to get up and to move that motion. I submit to you, Madam Deputy Speaker, that it cannot be disruptive then to call for a division on the motion. If the Speaker had chosen, at an appropriate time when this parliament first sat, to react to the enjoiners of some of my Independent colleagues and me, a formula would have been created where we got our opportunities in accordance perhaps with the relative numbers. If you went to the extreme, Madam Deputy Speaker, and said that, by taking my full speaking time in addressing this motion, it was disruptive, we would have another set of circumstances. By any stretch of the imagination, it cannot be considered obstructionist or disruptive to exercise a right clearly given to a member. If that right, as is the House's equal right to disagree, shapes up in the form of a division, that is how it goes.
