—There are.
—You've had six months and you still haven't fixed it up.

—Again, the interjections just betray the real position. The fact of the matter is that there is a system for allocating opportunities for people to speak. That system is that every day someone sits down and types up a list of who is going to speak and when. On the government side the Chief Government Whip has that responsibility. That happens within his office with the member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) and others.

BREAK.PARA: On the non-government side, the Chief Opposition Whip receives the expressions of interest from those who want to speak and he knocks up a list. That is what happens. He gives the non-government list to the Chief Government Whip, and the Chief Government Whip puts the lists together so that we have a list of speakers for and against. That is how it works. That really is a very simple proposition.

The truth of the matter is that the member for Curtin and some of the other Independents do not want to have to submit their names to somebody so that the list can be prepared. Therefore, they walk into the House and say, `They won't let us speak. We are denied the opportunity to speak.'

TALK.START.PARA: —You are misrepresenting it and you know it.

—Again, typically, I get a claim of misrepresentation. We have a claim of misrepresentation. We have been trying to settle this in a constructive and reasonable way for months. I was told, as late as yesterday, that the reason the names could not be submitted to the honourable member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay) is that the Independents would be tagged by the government as being members of the Labor Party simply because someone told the Chief Opposition Whip that they wanted to speak in a debate. I know politics descends to trivia from time to time, but I must say it is not a good reflection on any member to say that they have been denied the right to speak when they have denied themselves that right because of the rather absurd propositions that they have been putting about.

BREAK.PARA: Independents are entitled to speak. The fact that this debate is now going on is evidence of that. We are happy for you to have your proper entitlement to speak. There is no question about it. But, obviously, in the interests of the reasonable management of the House, we cannot sit here all day having divisions called by the member for Curtin on the grounds that he wants to be heard when it suits him.

It is the same in the Main Committee. We set up the Main Committee so that people could have a chance to speak. Obviously, the government is not going to sit back and allow people to disrupt the operation of the ordinary forms of the House and deny other people the right to speak.

Hot under the collar as you may be, I would like to know what you think is unreasonable about that proposition. We are trying to facilitate a sensible way of handling the debate. It is not encouraged or made easier by motions and propositions which are clearly in breach of the standing orders. Madam Deputy Speaker is quite entitled to form the opinion that she has formed.

On that basis, the government will certainly be voting against the dissent motion. If there are other motions later in the day also designed for the same obstructive purpose, we will continue to make the points that we have made this morning. We are always happy to sit down and talk with the Independents as to the forms of the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—You will get up and say, `We're the oppressed minority, and it is dreadful that you are walking over our rights.' Go right ahead. Jackboots will be heard marching across the floor of parliament. You will hope that your votes rise in the seats of Moore, Curtin and wherever else. We will understand your political rhetoric but, behind the political rhetoric and the statement you are about to make, the fact is that we continue to be prepared to discuss these matters.

BREAK.PARA: As far as the speakers list is concerned, quite frankly, the names should have been submitted on the agreed formula ages ago, and this would never have happened. That is the truth of the matter. The government will not accept obstruction in the business of the House, and therefore, Madam Deputy Speaker, we support the ruling and the expression of opinion that you have formed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, thank you for the opportunity to speak. I sometimes wonder what the Leader of the House (Mr Reith) means when he talks about these meetings, agreements or arrangements. He mentioned in his speech the word `trivia'. I have formulated the opinion that the Leader of the House probably considers most of the activities in this House are trivial because they get in the way of the orderly running of government business.

SPEECH.PARA: What we are about today is the fact that the Leader of the House has had six months—six long months—in order to resolve a matter that I, along with the other Independents, brought to the attention of the government immediately after the election. We knew this was going to happen because I, in my past service as a whip, understood the workings of the arrangements for speaking in this chamber. I knew that at some stage we were going to come to this point and, in effect, this point is merely the expression of members wanting to speak in this chamber.

I do not speak specifically about the standing orders. Madam Deputy Speaker, I know that you have long studied the standing orders and House of Representatives Practice. As you know, the speakers list is a convention that was arrived at in this place in the 1950s. Speaker Cameron, who was the Speaker at the time the speakers list became a convention, made a number of observations about the introduction of speakers lists. I refer you to page 475 of House of Representatives Practice, where he observed in the first instance that it was a perfectly logical and convenient method of conducting debate. But he added that, if they were not adhered to, or members objected to the practice, the House would revert to a system under which there was no list whatsoever and the chair would call the member he thought had first risen in his place.

That brings us then to standing order 61, the very standing order that gives any member of this chamber the right to move that he or she be now heard. It is quite clear in the standing orders, it is quite clear in House of Representatives Practice at page 474:

When two or more Members rise together to speak, the Speaker shall call upon the Member who, in the Speaker's opinion, first rose in his or her place. The decision of the Chair may be challenged by a motion that any Member who rose `be now heard' or `do now speak' and that question must be put forthwith and determined without amendment or debate.
It also goes on to say—and this is a critical point because it gives some guidance to an occupant of the chair in relation to the call:

Although the allocation of the call is a matter for the discretion of the Chair, it is usual, as a principle, to call Members from each side of the House, Government and Opposition, alternatively. Within this principle minor parties and any independents are given reasonable opportunities to express their views.

This is the nub of the problem which the Leader of the House has brought on the House himself. Time and time again we have endeavoured to reconcile this dilemma by arriving at some formula that would be accommodated within this convention; but, as such, none exists and none has been arrived at because we cannot get an agreement.

At the end of the day, the only guide that a member wanting to express the views of his constituents in this place has on when to speak or to obtain the call is from the standing orders. My colleague the member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) exercised his rights.

The Leader of the House may as well do as Oliver Cromwell did and call for the removal of this bauble and close the place down. In fact, he displays some of the tendencies of that authoritarian period in Oliver Cromwell's administration of the then Commonwealth of Britain.

It is all very well for the government of the day to use its numbers to crush the expressions of opinion from individual members, in particular Independent members. But, at the end of the day, the community will view this place as becoming more and more irrelevant to their views and to the things they want to talk about.

It is quite clear that the now laughing Leader of the House views all of these activities within the chambers as merely some unnecessary inconvenience in the orderly conduct of government business. I can recall the very same person in this place on the opposition benches making similar observations to mine—similar in the sense that at times the previous Labor administration mercilessly used its numbers and the forms of the House to prevent expression by members on behalf of their constituents, and we are seeing the very same process occurring here.

The Leader of the House made the point that we have been disruptive in the processes and, in particular, he mentioned the Main Committee. I think two bills have been referred back to this chamber from the Main Committee—a right, I might say, that is inherent in the standing orders. It was quite clearly put in there, as you and I know, Madam Deputy Speaker, when the Main Committee evolved in the discussions within the Procedure Committee and then in the chamber.

In both of those cases, the Primary Industries Legislation Amendment Bill and the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Legislation Amendment Bill, there were good grounds for bringing those bills back into this chamber because they were certainly controversial or would require amendment or divisions. In the first instance, the member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) located $24 million of wool growers' non‐wool assets being handed over for a particular project with only two lines in the explanatory—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The issue of relevance in this debate has been allowed to cross the issues which have led to the motion which are the arrangements for Independent members to speak. But when you start debating the merits of bills that have been previously dealt with by this House, you are out of order. I suggest you get back on track.

—Madam Deputy Speaker, with respect, I will. The matter was raised by the Leader of the House, quite clearly. In fact, I brought it to your attention at the beginning when he started to do that, when I said that I felt that the terms of the debate were being widened sufficiently to allow a wide‐ranging debate on the nature of this particular technique of oppression being used by the government against Independent members.
—And I have allowed that. You were erring onto the substance of bills.

—I appreciate that greatly and show due deference to your ruling. But, at the end of the day, according to the standing orders, we have only one way of obtaining our rights in this place to speak. If we are considered disruptive in trying to obtain our rights under the standing orders, then there is, in my view, a very serious problem.

SPEECH.PARA: The serious problem is this: where do we go? We cannot make our representations in this chamber because—after the comments made by the Leader of the House—we are being forced to comply with a process that is not in the standing orders. Standing orders do not mention it at all. Speaker Cameron did not mention it when the list was introduced into the processes of the House.

BREAK.PARA: Where is it written in standing orders? What does the Leader of the House use as a guide for this? Is it some sort of arrangement that he has concocted? That is not in the standing orders. The standing orders do not even mention the Chief Government Whip or Chief Opposition Whip in relation to the speaking rights of members.

So how could it be disruptive if a member tries to exercise his or her rights to speak in this place? If it is disruptive, you might as well close this place down because, in essence, any debate is a token debate; you can debate only as long as the government allows you to do so, throwing you crumbs of government time to put a point of view across. Mind you, even having made your point in this place, often it is ignored anyway.

At the end of the day, if this place is to be relevant to the operation of the business of government and relevant to the interests of the community at large, our interests must be taken seriously. We are not debating some trivial point here. If the Leader considers it to be trivial, in my view he deserves to be consigned to the ranks of those who have anti‐parliamentarian sentiments—because this is an anti‐parliamentarian act. This is not an act of parliamentary democracy; at the end of the day, this is an attempt to prevent us from exercising our rights.

Madam Deputy Speaker, you have chosen to make a ruling on this matter. Under the House of Representatives Practice a Speaker's ruling is not required. Obviously, since the debate has commenced, I have studied that point. In essence, we are objecting to a ruling which, in our view, regards any member's attempt to exercise their right to speak—having been made once and then a second time—as being disruptive.

But where does the disruption line end up being drawn? Is it at once, twice, three times? Is it at once a day, twice a day, three times a day, once a week, twice a week, once a month, once a sitting, once a parliament, twice a parliament? Where do you draw the line?

By what right does the chair of this place exercise that particular judgment? If that ruling were right, any member, whether Independent, Labor Party, National Party or Liberal Party, could be considered disruptive purely and simply because they wanted to exercise their rights.

I put it to you, Madam Deputy Speaker, that standing orders provide for the opportunity for members to rise in their places to seek the call of the Speaker. A member who has not obtained the call and who believes they were first on their feet is entitled, under standing orders, to move that they be now heard. That is entitled to be dealt with without debate or comment or amendment.

Madam Deputy Speaker, in making your ruling that the member for Curtin was being disruptive under the provisions of standing order 86, in essence you have provided a greater opportunity for executive government to prevent the voice of the people being expressed in this chamber. In essence, you have contributed to the overweening, overbalanced power of the executive vis‐a‐vis the parliament. We all know that, because of the tyranny of numbers in this place, in essence the executive runs this chamber. It runs it mercilessly, as it did under the previous government.

We were told at the beginning of this parliament that we would see reforms that would raise the standing of this chamber and raise the standing of the contributions of individual members on behalf of their constituents. We were told that we would see reforms that would raise the independence of the Speaker. We all sat here and said that we would wait and see what happens, that we would wait and make our judgments based on our experience. Six months have passed and I cannot see any difference between this administration's conduct of the business of this House and the previous one's.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear! It's worse.

—Yes, to some extent it is worse. As Independent members, we made efforts from the word go to arrive at a satisfactory and sensible arrangement that would accommodate our needs to represent our constituents' concerns. Six months down the track, we are no closer to that arrangement.

BREAK.PARA: The only person who can accept responsibility for that is the Leader of the House. If he cannot make an arrangement, with all the numbers he has, with all the threats he has made about changing standing orders to prevent us from exercising our rights, surely to goodness somebody should look at the way in which the Leader of the House is acting in that capacity. After all, with the weight of numbers, surely it is not beyond the wit of the Leader of the House to come to some arrangement that could have prevented this occurrence where the member for Curtin has done what is within his perfect right to do, and that is to move that he be now heard under the standing orders of this House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLachlan, Ian, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, I rise to support your action in allowing the dissent motion, although I have to say that I think you had the option of not doing so. We have supported you in that ruling because, obviously, the dissidents to this debate should be allowed to have their say. However, I have to say that they cannot be allowed to have their say too often; otherwise, by definition, it is a disruption.

SPEECH.PARA: Let's get to the essence of this debate. As I understand it, a proposition was put to the Independents that they submit their names to the opposition whip so that they would go on a speaking list in a proportional way. Up until now at least, they have refused to submit their names for such a list.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—If that is rubbish, I am sure you will come forward and submit your names again this afternoon. Perhaps, as the opposition whip said, some have delivered their names and some have refused. So I am half right and you are half right on that subject.

SPEECH.PARA: The argument that is put is quite right; that is, if the House wants not to have a list, it should have the right to that expression. But you saw from the vote earlier that the great majority of the House wanted to go on a list. Why do they want to go on a list? It is because there are 148 members of the House and they each want their proportionate turn in which to speak.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are 147 at present.

—Indeed, but it will soon come back to the even number that it was only a few days ago, in the same proportion that it was a few days ago. If you are not prepared to put your names on a list to get that sort of proportion right, then I have no doubt that you will be sitting where you are sitting for a long time to come.

SPEECH.PARA: As well as that, it was by convention the turn to speak of a member on this side of the House. When the member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) rose this time, it was the turn to speak of a member on this side of the House. Therefore, if there are any conventions in this House, that is one which, on this occasion, you should have observed.

I am not going to speak for the whole time that has been allotted. This debate is perfectly clear: either you are going to submit yourselves to a proportionate right to speak with everybody on this side of the House and everybody on the other side of the House, or you are not. If you do not submit yourselves to that then, no doubt, you will continue to use the tactics that you are now using—the tactics of disruption—to get your way. That will not be allowed. You may as well understand that from the beginning.

Madam Deputy Speaker, we support what you have done on this occasion. We hope that those Independent members who have been heard this time will now go away and think about whether they should, like everybody else, be able to speak in this House on some sort of proportionate basis—not on a disproportionate basis, every time they feel they should jump up.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay, Leo, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, as the Deputy Manager of Opposition Business, I would like to say that we on this side of the House support your ruling. While there probably are some points in the matters raised by the member for Moore (Mr Filing), I think your ruling was a reasonable one. Members of the House had made a decision, about 40 minutes prior to the Independents disputing your ruling, that they wished to, in effect, stay with the speakers list which the House had before it. Standing order 86 is fairly clear. It provides that a number of matters have to be put to the House without debate. The first of those is 86(a), which states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that a Member "be now heard" or "do now speak" . . .
The paragraph at the end of standing order 86 states:

Should any of these questions be negatived, no similar proposal shall be received if the Speaker or the Chair is of the opinion that it is an abuse of the orders or forms of the House, or is moved for the purpose of obstructing business.

You, Madam Deputy Speaker, have come to the decision that this motion was moved, I think in your words, `to disrupt the proceedings of the House'. It would seem a reasonable thing to say, as it was such a short time after members of the House, by a very large margin of about 130 to four, decided that they did not want to hear the member for Curtin (Mr Rocher).

TALK.START.PARA: —I was going to give you both a serve!

—The day that the member for Curtin gives me a vote is the day that I will give up. Madam Deputy Speaker, the opposition would think that your ruling was a reasonable ruling. Of course, if the chair continually refused to allow members to speak—I do not believe that you would do that, Madam Deputy Speaker—then the opposition would have a different view. At this stage, our position is that we think you were correct.

SPEECH.PARA: As the Leader of the House (Mr Reith) injected my name into this debate earlier, I point out to the House that the opposition is more than willing to produce a speakers list which includes all shades of opinion for the non-government members in this House. Indeed, a number of the non‐government members avail themselves of that procedure. The member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) regularly avails himself of that procedure. The member for Calare (Mr Andren) has done so, as has the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson).

A former member for Wills, who was not very sympathetic to the Liberal Party when the previous government was in office—he was probably less sympathetic to the Liberal Party on many issues than many other members in the House—used to regularly avail himself of the option of having his name put on the speakers list by the previous chief opposition whip, Mr Halverson, who is now the Speaker. That worked well. Mr Halverson gave Mr Cleary and his colleague Mr Mack a go. The opposition is more than willing to give the other non-government members in this House a go.

As I put to the member for Moore the other day, we have got a lot of heat and not much light in this debate. The simple task is to try it. Let's try it. All members in the non-government parties who have put their names down on the list have got on the list at a time that allowed them to speak. The member for Oxley and the member for Calare have been able to speak. The member for Kalgoorlie regularly gets to speak. I say to the member for Moore: let's try this system that has been proposed. It worked in the last parliament for Mr Mack and Mr Cleary, and I am sure it will work in this parliament for the five Independents. Putting that aside, Madam Deputy Speaker, your ruling was a reasonable one, and the opposition will vote to uphold your ruling.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Truss, Warren, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been good to have the opposition members voting on the same side as the government on the last two divisions. I hope they have got used to the idea and use their vote constructively to also support the 1996 budget. This is an important budget for Australia. It represents a turning point in the financial history of our country. At long last a government has taken our budget deficit seriously and has put in place a program to eliminate that deficit over the years ahead.

SPEECH.PARA: The most widely acclaimed feature of the 1996 federal budget has been its financial responsibility. The budget clearly indicated, for the first time in more than a decade, that a federal government was serious about living within its means. The first Howard government budget included a firm strategy to eliminate the budget deficit over the next three years and to start paying off some of the legacy of debt bequeathed by the former Labor regime.

In an answer to a question without notice this week from me, the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey) confirmed that the federal government's debt is now over $96 billion and, without radical changes in policy, would have reached $120 billion by the year 2000. The federal government's debt will have risen by 600 per cent in just 10 years, including a $69 billion increase in the last five years. Labor has left this nation an appalling legacy of debt.

Mr Fahey told the parliament that the $10 billion included in this budget to pay interest on Labor's debt is equivalent to half the entire health budget and all the education budget. To put it in other language: every man, woman and child in Australia will be paying around $5,000 extra in taxes every year to pay off the legacy of 13 years of ALP government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame.

—Yes, what shame Labor members must feel about the mess they left their country in after their uninterrupted term of government. Labor, of course, have been the debt kings always. It is interesting to note, if we trace the history of our country since Federation, that Labor governments have been in office for less than a third of the 95‐year history of our country but they have been responsible for accumulating over 90 per cent of the government's foreign debt.

SPEECH.PARA: They have always adopted this attitude that they can spend as if there were no tomorrow and that the bankcard will never be called up. It might be pleasant in government to be going out spending money, favouring all of the groups that have supported the government parties during election times; it may be popular to give your electorate the extra goodies they so often want to receive. It is popular to raise social security benefits and to spend more on government programs, to raise Public Service salaries, to build new buildings and to ensure that the processes of government are well heeled.

That may well be popular but it all has to be paid for. The bills come in. The interesting thing about our current economic crisis as a nation is that it has arisen because never before in history have we had such an extended period of Labor government. Normally, we have had three or four years of Labor spending sprees, then they were turfed out of office and a government with better management skills has been able to come along and balance the budget before our nation's debt gets out of control.

But this time we have had more than a decade of uninterrupted Labor rule, more than a decade of uninterrupted mismanagement. So these debts have really accumulated. The government debt is now $96 billion and the interest on that debt is one of the major items of our expenditure. Indeed, the $10.3 billion budget deficit that this government confronted on coming to office would not really have existed if we did not have to pay interest and redemption on the debts of the previous regime.

This government is paying the bills of its predecessors. In this budget we have to pick up the accounts for the spending sprees of the past. Many of the things we would like to do in government have got to be put on hold as we pay the bills of a previous era. Balanced federal budgets are essential to keep down interest rates and to boost investment. Already, market confidence in the government's budget strategy has produced an interest rate drop—and more are possible. The half a per cent reduction in interest rates means something like $70 a month on the average household mortgage loan. Those are very real benefits that can be built upon by continuing to balance the budget and for our Commonwealth to be seen as financially responsible.

I was impressed by the comments of Standard and Poor's, which are looking again at the possibility of upgrading Australia's credit rating. Our credit rating was reduced three times under the Labor regime—at considerable cost to all borrowers in this nation. At last the international credit rating agencies are starting to look favourably upon our country. It is important, therefore, that the strategy of this budget be carried through and that the program to balance the budget be honoured, maintained and delivered.

Unfortunately, it is clear that Labor have learned nothing from their federal election defeat. Their declared intention to oppose $7 billion of budget deficit reduction measures would, if successful, destroy the prospects for restoring Australia's credit rating and destroy the prospects for continuing lower interest charges. If the government is unable to deliver on its budget deficit strategy, the repercussions for our country will be continuing high interest rates, a continuing lack of confidence in our nation's financial capability and a continual lowering of our international credit rating. It is essential that the strategy of the budget be honoured. I call upon the Labor opposition to demonstrate how important it is to maintain fiscal responsibility by supporting the key elements of our budget strategy.

The Democrats, of course, are even worse. They propose even more wholesale hacking away at the strategy of the budget and propose even greater levels of expenditure. The Democrats are becoming something of an enigma. They promised at the election to keep the parties honest. But now they are seemingly opposing every attempt by the government to implement its election promises. When we seek to honour our promises they vote against it. How is that keeping the major parties honest? The Democrats need to look thoroughly at their level of honesty, they need to look thoroughly at the way they portray themselves and they need to be responsible. They are elected as senators by a small percentage of the people of Australia. They have a role and they must use that role constructively to ensure that the best interests of our country are always honoured and maintained. To do that, they must also support the fundamental structure of this budget.

The budget is a major turning point. As the government makes a smaller call on the nation's savings, more money is available to invest in Australian industry and to prevent the sale of Australian companies overseas. This is a very important element of this budget strategy. There is widespread national concern about the level of foreign investment in our country and about the sale of Australian companies to overseas interests.

In addition to the gross foreign debt of our country, which currently stands at about $220 billion, there is something over $180 billion of foreign equity in Australian companies, bringing total foreign investment in our nation to around $400 billion. That is a lot of debt, a lot of allegiance we owe to masters in other parts of the world who are affecting our capacity to manage our country as we see fit. It is important for our country to get control of its own agenda again. To do that, we must rely less on borrowings from overseas and be able to demonstrate that we are able to balance our own budgets.

The overwhelming direction of the budget has been to benefit the people of Australia. It is true that in cutting expenditure there will be some pain. One of the aspects of this budget that has been appreciated by Australians has been the commendable way in which the government has at least endeavoured to share the pain evenly. Almost everyone has found that there is some little area where they will be adversely affected. But most Australians are accepting that there needs to be a little pain in our national interest, that we cannot continue to go on living beyond our means. Most Australians are prepared to say, `I will do my little piece so long as others are seen to also be fairly bearing the burden.' That has been one of the successes of this budget: it is seen to be fair; it is seen to be inflicting the burden of our national load evenly on all Australians.

Those on high incomes are being asked to contribute more than those on low incomes—and that is fair. Business is being asked to bear some of the burden—and that is fair. Even pensioners are being asked to bear a very small part of that burden—and that is fair, too, and they recognise that fairness.

There are many benefits in the budget. There are no increases in income tax, sales tax, company tax or fuel excise. When did we last have a budget, particularly a budget after an election, where that claim could be made? Prior to the election almost every Labor government said that there would be no increases in taxes, but immediately after the election, even though they had access to the books before the election, they knew what the bottom line was going to be: almost invariably the Labor government's first budget after the election was a sorry litany of increased taxes and higher charges.

That has not happened here. Even though the new government was ambushed by a $10.3 billion deficit, we have been able to bring down a budget without increases in income tax, sales tax, company tax or fuel excise. The billion dollar family tax package, the capital gains tax relief for small business, the private health insurance rebates, the increased tax free threshold for self-funded retirees, the retention of the diesel fuel rebate scheme and a host of other tax measures will help provide incentive and security for the future.

But it is not just all about tax increases, tax reductions and deficit reductions. There is a lot of good news in the budget on the expenditure side as well. There is increased expenditure on roads in this budget. It is not as much as I would like, but it is the second biggest road budget in Australian history. The task of providing a satisfactory road system for our nation is essential for our export trade and our economic future. We need to be devoting more expenditure to upgrading the road system. Sadly, over recent years, Labor has allowed our national asset, our road system, to deteriorate.

Programs such as the black spots program had been axed altogether. Even though fuel excise had grown almost sevenfold under the life of the Labor government—fuel's proportion of the tax receipts was growing and Tax's share of the cost of fuel was growing, in spite of that $10 billion revenue from fuel excise—Labor was actually spending less and less on roads.

I am pleased that this budget turns that around, reinstates the black spots program and spends more money on local and regional roads. We can, at last, start addressing the enormous task of repairing our damaged national road system. But, as I said, more still needs to be done. I hope that in subsequent budgets the government can build upon its commitment to our road system.

I also welcome the increased funding in areas such as relationships counselling. Our country pays a very high price for failed relationships. We spend billions of dollars each year on the effects of relationship breakdowns, but the cost is not only economic; perhaps the greater cost is to our society. It is always a sad day for me when I get a call about someone with problems with the Family Court system or with the Child Support Agency—and there are of course scores of problems with the way in which those particular agencies operate. But the saddest part about those calls is that, more often than not, there is little I can do to help them, and there is little I can do to help them because there is such an absence of goodwill, the broken relationship is bitter and there is often an intense desire to get even.

The real losers in all of that dispute and bitterness are not the couple themselves but, more often than not, their children, their families, their parents, their grandparents and everyone associated with them. Many lives are destroyed permanently when a relationship breaks down, so I welcome the government's initiative to provide additional funds in this area. Again, it is not enough but it is a start and a positive indication that this government is serious about doing something to keep relationships together rather than having to always bear the cost of the failure of a marriage or family. There is so much that needs to be done in that regard.

The government's initiative in targeting families in this budget is especially good news. The $1 billion tax breaks through higher tax free thresholds for families with children are a very positive initiative and will be warmly welcomed. That initiative is available not just to families with high taxable incomes, not just to families with taxable incomes at all; the benefits are available to all families. So there will be real cash benefits to help families with the extra expenses they have in raising children.

I welcome especially also the boost in funding for education and for schools. The abolition of Labor's new schools policy is warmly welcomed in the community. Of course it was generally referred to as a no new schools policy because it made it very difficult for new schools to open up and to receive Commonwealth funding.

The fact is that many parents these days are exercising the option of a private education for their children. They are choosing to pay the fees to go to a school with often far inferior facilities to what is available in the state schools and where they have to work twice as hard to mow the lawn and provide the basic facilities for the school that they would never have to at a state school. They are making that decision, they are making that choice because they believe that the quality of that education is superior or because it particularly meets the needs of their children.

I think it is high time a government acknowledged that freedom of choice and provided appropriate support to families who choose that option. We are not neglecting the state school system. There are additional funds available also in this budget to assist state schools with their capital works and to ensure that there are appropriate programs to support the schooling system.

This is a budget which offers hope to Australians. It is a budget that without doubt carries some pain, but it is a pain that needs to be borne in our national interest as we work towards building a more secure and progressive future for our nation. Balancing budgets is a vital national objective. Previous Treasurers have given lip service to the importance of achieving that objective but they have rarely been prepared to make the tough decisions that are necessary to achieve that goal. This government has been prepared to make those decisions, and we are bearing that pain.

A lot of that pain has been inflicted upon us by our predecessors, and they should hang their heads in shame and acclaim the fact that we are taking the tough decisions that they were not prepared to take. I commend this budget. It naturally does not include everything I would wish it to include but I hope that, as our government moves along into future budgets and into future terms in office, it will be able to deliver everything we have promised to the Australian people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crean, Simon, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the amendment moved by the shadow Treasurer. The first Howard budget fails in the job because it does not create jobs. It cuts expenditure, regardless of the consequences. It retards economic growth and it is a budget of betrayal. It betrays the unemployed, it betrays Australian industry, it betrays families and it betrays regional Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: We on our side do not argue against getting the budget into surplus. In fact, Labor has produced the only surplus budgets in the history of this country. But creating jobs through sustained high economic growth must be the first priority. Helping those who need it, particularly the long‐term unemployed, requires an investment by the nation, as does developing the skills of the work force. Government cannot simply be about cutting costs. It has to be about investing in our most valuable asset: our people. To achieve sustained economic growth we also need a partnership between government and industry.

In all of these objectives there is a vital role for government, but this budget takes the opposite path: it abrogates a role for government. In doing so it consigns Australia to lower growth and higher unemployment. If anyone needs any evidence of that today, look at the labour force figures just produced, where we see unemployment having shot up to 8.8 per cent, 0.3 per cent in one month.

In office, Labor did pursue an active government role for government. While in office we fostered the partnership between government and industry and, in our last three years of office, the economy grew on average at 4.2 per cent each year. Compare this with the first Howard budget which forecasts economic growth of 3½ per cent. We are going backwards. And there are the same forecasts for all the years up to the year 2000.

This figure is not enough to create the conditions necessary for employment growth. The budget sees revenue rising this year by $8½ billion and outlays by just under $4 billion. But with economic growth as per what Labor delivered, the increase in revenue would have been about $1 billion higher and outlays about $400 million less. A net contribution to the underlying budget deficit would come in at over $1 billion less than that which is budgeted for, $5.6 billion. Our scenario would also see the budget return to surplus by 1999‐2000—a longer path to surplus than the coalition's, but with stronger economic growth and better job opportunities.

But this is not a budget for jobs. It hits the unemployed in two ways, and we are seeing the first signs of that today with the disgraceful 8.8 per cent unemployment figure. It not only retards economic growth which leads to job creation; it also slashes by $2 billion labour market programs which are vital for helping the long‐term unemployed get back to work.

The government argues that the programs were a failure. They were not a failure. Look at skillshare. Skillshare had a success rate of 50 to 60 per cent according to Access Economics—which advised the Liberal Party before it came to power—demonstrating that skillshare contributes net savings to the budget of $80 million over three years. It has been successful on two fronts, but it is cut by 33 per cent.

The NEIS program, the new enterprise incentive scheme for getting small businesses started, had a success rate of 83 per cent but its funds have been cut by 17 per cent. Even the good ones go; even the things that stimulated economic development and got the long‐term unemployed back into work, are to go.

As to traineeships, the wage subsidy which is provided to employers to take on trainees has been cut. Now there will be no subsidy to companies which employ more than 100 people. This is a ridiculous distinction, and it should be removed. The decision to cut the subsidies on traineeships will retard the huge growth in the number of traineeships seen under Labor's Working Nation program. In the last year, traineeships doubled to 35,000 trainees on the basis of the massive commitment which Working Nation put in. This commitment has now been dramatically slashed.

We know that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) refuses to commit to an unemployment target. But there is worse: the cuts to the labour market programs abandon the long‐term unemployed. They are to be consigned to the scrap heap, and the programs which gave them hope and a measure of self‐esteem have gone. I find it incredible that the Prime Minister is prepared to set targets for inflation and for cutting red tape for small businesses, but is not prepared to set a target for the unemployed. Is paper more important than people?

The Prime Minister should come clean and indicate what his unemployment target is. But he knows—because Senator Vanstone, the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, let the cat out of the bag—that under the coalition‐Howard budget policies unemployment will still be over eight per cent by the end of this century. That is not our conclusion but is in a report commissioned by Minister Vanstone—which the government has refused to table in this parliament, I might add; they have been running away from it all week. That report confirms an unemployment rate of 8.1 per cent by the year 2000—based on coalition policies, not on Labor policies.

PARA.BREAK: It is the reason that the Victorian budget that was handed down yesterday, for the first time in the Kennett government's term, projects no fall in unemployment. Under Labor, they got successive falls in unemploy ment, but the Victorian budget handed down yesterday says there will be no change. And why is that? Because they have a budget policy in place that retards growth and retards employment opportunity.

SPEECH.PARA: The minister not only got that report showing that they would be locked in to 8.1 per cent, but she also received advice from her own department that Labor was on track to achieve its target of five per cent. Today we have the Governor of the Reserve Bank giving evidence before a parliamentary committee confirming that the five to six per cent target for unemployment is achievable. We believe it could have been achieved. We were prepared to put policies in place to achieve it. We had made progress. We said it would take time, but we were making progress.

This is the government that promised to do more for unemployment, but it has done less. It has turned the record back, and we have seen the result today in the jump to 8.8 per cent unemployment. The report which was handed to the minister says that the coalition is on track for 8.1 per cent unemployment by the end of this decade, whereas we were on track for five per cent unemployment. There is a 300,000 job difference between what our policies would have produced and what you are putting in place. And you say you are concerned about jobs! This budget gives the lie to that argument.

In the industry area of the budget, the reason the unemployed will suffer is not just because of cuts to labour market programs and the scrapping of Working Nation programs but also because the budget cuts support for investment in this country—the very means by which you get growth in production and jobs. The government has cut the programs. It has gutted industry assistance by almost $4 billion in this budget. This not only breaks many election promises but also ignores the significant returns to the economy from these programs.

The cuts to research and development, for example, are massive, but the government's own reports demonstrate the net benefit to the economy. The expenditures produce those net benefits. The Industry Commission and the Bureau of Industry Economics have found that the R&D concessions have contributed net benefits to the economy of a substantial size. These things should not be seen as costs; they should be seen as investments in the future of the nation—a role that governments should be prepared to take.

One example of the programs that will go is the research and development being carried out at the Mount Lyell mine in Tasmania. This is a mine that was closed some years ago and has now reopened. They have world leading technology, which they want to develop, aimed at finding a more efficient method of extracting copper. It could work not only for copper but also for extracting other minerals as well. It would add value to our natural resources; it would mean not exporting the waste, but doing something with it here.

But this will not happen unless the research and development goes on. If we do not support it, other countries will. They will be the ones to get the benefit. This is not a cost to the budget; this is an investment in the future of the nation, in the future of Tasmania. If I had the time, I could go through a litany of examples of the programs that this government is cutting through cuts to research and development.

It is also scrapping the shipbuilding bounty. This is a program that Labor introduced back in the late 1980s. It has seen ships exported from this country, mostly the wave‐piercing catamarans, such as people who have been overseas would have travelled on. These are all built in Australia with support from this program. But the bounty took the industry production up by close to 200 per cent. It saw export growth of 150 per cent and jobs growth of 50 per cent. For what? An investment of about $9 million a year. Again, I say to you: isn't this what Australia should be encouraging?

Yet we had the ridiculous position the other day where the government reversed the decision in relation to the ships capital grants. It means that companies like Shell and BHP can now get a subsidy to buy ships built overseas, but they will not reverse the decision that enables ships to be built in this country and exported overseas. What sort of lunacy is such a policy? That is why we are calling on the government in our second reading amendment to reverse this decision.

It does not stop just with ships; it also goes to the book industry—the publishing industry—which is, again, somewhere where we introduced a bounty scheme, a support assistance scheme. We saw the export of books from this country grow by 200 per cent in the last 12 years. We have seen businesses grow up in many rural and regional centres. In the Victorian country town of Maryborough, for example, 25 per cent of the local work force is directly dependent upon this growth in the book industry.

Cut the program and production goes overseas. Is this what we mean by exporting to Asia—exporting the jobs over there so that they do not occur here? That is not my view of it; it is not Labor's view of it. But production is not going to happen here unless the government is prepared to support industry.

The budget also terminates the computer bounty and the machine tools and robotics bounty. Both of those industries have trebled exports in the last five years. It abolishes the DIFF scheme, the one that Alexander Downer has come to grief over. Again, the DIFF scheme is not a cost to the budget. For every dollar spent, it returns $3.50 to the nation. The budget cuts the export market development grants scheme. For every dollar spent there, through a multiplier effect, up to $25 returns to the nation. These are not costs. They are investments in Australia. They are investments in Australia's future and investments in Australia's jobs.

They are part of the reason why Labor was able to sustain economic growth at better than four per cent. For these reasons, we will oppose the budget cuts to research and development and the abolition of the bounties. We are prepared to go out and support Australia's manufacturing industry, to support Australia's export industries and to be the champions of the clever country. All of those things have been betrayed in this budget.

The budget also amounts to a massive betrayal of regional Australia. This budget is a litany of promises made to regional Australia and broken, including $150 million cut to regional road funding and $66 million cut to the ABC. You know they are the regions which are going to be hit hardest, because they have nothing else to rely upon. There are the cuts to regional university places—16,000 of them. How are kids in the bush going to be able to travel to the city? How can they afford it? Labor made sure the places went to where they were, and these are the places that have now been cut.

The cut to the labour market programs will impact most heavily in regional Australia. The cuts to services—the closure of the Medicare offices, of the Department of Social Security offices, of the tax offices and of the employment offices—mean that these offices are closing up all over Australia under this government's program of reducing services to the bush. We also have the abolition of the regional development program—$150 million—which supported infrastructure programs and initiatives in regional Australia.

It is not just the cuts and the broken promises that impact on regional Australia; it is the philosophy. Because in announcing the abolition of the regional development program, the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) said, `There is no clear rationale or constitutional basis for Commonwealth involvement in regional development.' A straight quote, I might say, out of the audit commission. But what a joke! Here is a man—the pretender to the National Party leadership—claiming that the Australian government has no role in regional economic development. If the National Party does not stand for regional Australia, what does it stand for? The minister himself is such a champion for regional Australia, he abolished the department. But the fact is that with the commitment that Labor made to regional Australia we saw important developments.

The Minister for Science and Technology (Mr McGauran) admitted the other day that the cut to the 150 per cent research and development program was to ensure the retention of the diesel fuel rebate to the bush. We all know how the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) placed great reliance on winning the diesel fuel rebate. So what has happened? The budget has propped up Tim Fischer's leadership of the National Party by ripping a billion dollars out of smart companies and researchers. Not a very clever investment, I would suggest.

It is nonsense to say that the Australian government has no role in regional development. Through the regional development program we ensured an active role for the Commonwealth. Our approach, which was endorsed by the McKinsey report just after the budget but which the government has decided to scrap, was that the program should continue. It is a report that cost $700,000—that is $7,000 a day. It found that the regional development program had made a significant start in rejuvenating leadership in Australia's regions and that it had the potential to make a significant impact on the growth of regions. It recommended the continuation of funding: $50 million over five years to support the structures and $25 million over five years for `seed' funding and infrastructure funding.

Labor says that there is a role for the Commonwealth government in regional economic development. There must be a role for all governments. We have to pull together as a team, not pass the responsibility to some other level of government. All levels of government have to work together with the regions, giving them ownership. Under our strategy for regional development, we will reinstate the support for REDOs. We will provide program funding for infrastructure redevelopment. We will give regions more say in the way in which programs are delivered, and we will, in partnership, work with them to get them to identify and develop a regional agenda. We intend to win back the confidence of the regions, but unlike the coalition we will not betray them. We are prepared to back them.

PARA.BREAK: This is a budget deserving of the highest condemnation. It destroys the prospects for economic growth and with it the prospects for job growth. It fails to tackle the difficult problems, such as long-term unemployment. It sees the government walking away from effective involvement in industry policy in this country, and it represents the betrayal of regional Australia by a coalition government. The unemployed, Australian industries, fami lies and regions are all part of mainstream Australia, but this is not a budget for them. Accordingly, we will be supporting the amendment moved by the shadow Treasurer and will be seeking to oppose those aspects of legislation that come before the House to try to reverse the ridiculous decisions; the most graphic evidence of the failure being the increase in unemployment this month. We are now seeing what the John Howard coalition government produces: high unemployment, low wages and no commitment to the future. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone, Sharman, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Contrary to what has been stated by the previous speaker, the member for Hotham (Mr Crean), this is a budget for regional Australians. I should know; I represent the regional seat of Murray. I can assure the honourable member for Hotham that my regional constituents are very pleased with the way this government has not simply spoken platitudes but has directly addressed the problems. Rural people like my constituents have been working very hard with incredibly low returns and seeing their product on international markets penalised because of the industrial relations environment in this country. We are forever competing head on with countries which can produce their meat products onto markets at a fraction of the cost that we can, even though when the bullock carcass leaves the farmer it is many dollars below what their counterparts produce elsewhere in the world. So this budget is for regional Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: The people in my electorate and my colleagues who also represent regional Australia, such as the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Reid), are overwhelmingly supportive of this budget. I want to add that we are not a divisive coalition. We believe in all Australians proceeding forward together. So it is no wonder that, when they had a good hard look at the budget, all of Australia has been congratulatory and relieved. This is the budget they have been hoping for over the last decade. This is the budget which will build Australia up to take its place among the world's strongest nations, beholden to no-one, with its debt pared back, with domestic savings providing the funds needed to build our industry and keep it in the hands of hardworking Australians for generations to come—my children and the children of all of the others that we represent.

This budget does not make extravagant claims about reducing unemployment. The previous speaker, the member for Hotham, seemed to have a problem with that, but we are not going to mention figures because it is more complicated and more complex than that. It is much more important for us to look at a multifaceted strategy than to simply pluck a figure out of the air and then produce mickey mouse training programs so that we can show by a sleight of hand that the numbers of unemployed have miraculously been reduced. What we are going to do is create real work, not for the sake of that real work in itself but so we have an environment where business can thrive and create the jobs which give dignity and fulfilment in the lives of individuals. We will create the wealth of the nation by working hard together.

This budget focuses on the creation of this new economic environment, where families can be more secure, where education is more accessible, where research and development will be more productive and where business can thrive. Free of unfair dismissal laws that make employing a newcomer high risk and in a flexible work environment, owners and employees will be able to work together in a workplace that is cooperative, respectful and anchored in mutual interest. No more should we look with envy at countries like Japan, where the bosses and the workers regard themselves as on the same side. We can create that environment in this country.
The $150 million per annum reduction in capital gains tax for small business is a long awaited relief and should help organisations and businesses to invest so they can compete.

In a recent survey of dry‐land farmers in my electorate, over 80 per cent were using tractors and equipment over 20 years old. Too much of our other primary industry has to upgrade equipment and invest in training and product development. But they needed some hope, some sense of a future where they could compete as a result of their hard work and not be hamstrung by red tape and IR problems. This budget helps them.

The Supermarket to Asia strategy announced only an hour or so ago by our own Prime Minister (Mr Howard) is a key plank in the budget which will help regional Australia. Our Prime Minister recognises that the potential of food and fibre production in this country means that next to no‐one else in the world is able to feed the growing populations who have growing income and who are becoming more health conscious. We are close to the Asian markets. We can serve them. We are a nation that can produce clean green food. We have skilled farmer operators and skilled manufacturers. But we have to have the infrastructure, the research and development and, most of all, hope. This budget is all about hope.

While the previous Prime Minister, Paul Keating, liked to remind us of the nearness of the burgeoning Asian markets, over the last 10 years, despite all of those statements to that effect, we actually saw the growth of Australia's market share in those food markets fall well behind our competitors, particularly our neighbours, New Zealand. We know that, even as we speak, we are battling to keep market share for our beef.

We will keep the export market development grants to assist businesses making their first ventures into exporting. And we recognise that tourism is a valuable and growing business in the economy and it should also be eligible for such assistance.

This budget recognises the essential cooperative industry and university post‐graduate research that must go on. The restoration of CSIRO funding comes not a moment too soon. How can we talk about wanting to be a clever nation when in the last decade or so the CSIRO has been battling to survive. Our nation's research capacity was slipping away under the last government.

Agribusiness cannot become more competitive without adequate infrastructure and in particular it is dependent upon roads. The previous government—of which the member for Hotham (Mr Crean) was an important member—saw no need for black spot road safety funding to help fix up parts of the road system which were a major danger to life.

This budget recognises that rural roads in particular have to be adequate to sustain both regional development and to keep members of our community safe as they travel. The $149 million for road safety black spot funding will make an enormous difference, and half of this is to be allocated to rural roads. I remind the House that Labor took this funding away. So how can the member for Hotham suggest that we are not totally focused on regional development?

This year in Victoria alone we have seen death from road accidents exceed last year's figures. In an electorate like Murray, where hundreds of huge milk tankers ply narrow country roads twice a day, criss‐crossing major arteries, we must have good quality road surfaces and safe intersections.

Only several days ago we saw three killed and seven injured in a single horrific road smash on the Goulburn Valley Highway. The duplication of this national highway is urgently required, and we look forward to federal funds from this budget to start this work.

We had a lot of promises under the previous government but, unfortunately, very little action. This budget recognises the infrastructure needs of the entire nation, but also cuts to the core of the problems which have kept our current account deficient at levels which sapped the savings of the nation—and certainly ate away at its heart. This budget is fair and just, while it takes the hard decisions.

It is also a compassionate budget. In the true liberal tradition it provides a safety net for those who cannot survive unaided, because the education system has failed them, because they are too old and without savings, or too sick without savings, or disabled.

After years of confused regulation and rigid bureaucracy, our care of the aged in hostels and nursing homes was in no way keeping pace with an ageing population, a population with the lives of the most frail extending well beyond the lifespans of previous generations. This budget provides for a six per cent increase in funding for the home and community care program. This will help rural people in particular live out their days in their small local communities—one of their priorities as they end their days.

Flexibility will be introduced in the system so the distinction between an aged person's hostel and nursing home blurs—what a sensible idea, long looked for. Now the needs of the elderly person will be critically assessed and the funding will follow the individual. There will be over $130 million per year additional funds to help in the refurbishment and development of nursing home facilities. In my electorate of Murray where many small hostels need to upgrade their facilities there is a special fund that they may tap into for the facilities needed to provide nursing home accommodation.

This budget also recognises that most people prefer to live out their days at home. The strain placed upon carers who dedicate so much of their lives to providing for others' needs is to be taken on board and is recognised in this budget. These are the carers of the frail elderly, the chronically sick as well as those who care for the disabled. These carers are a very important part of our community and we could not do without them.

In Murray there are men and women in their seventies who dedicate their lives to the care of their adult disabled sons and daughters. They live in fear of the future when they may not be able to continue that full‐time care that they so willingly give. This government is compassionate and understanding. It has provided an extra $36.7 million above 1995‐96 expenditure over the next four years for a national carers action plan which will in particular extend and improve respite care in emergencies; increase the number of days a carer can temporarily cease caring in a year without affecting their qualification for the carer payment so it will be more flexible; and double the time that carers can spend in employment, voluntary work and educational training from 10 to 20 hours per week. In other words, we recognise that the carer needs also to be able to maintain their links in the community and to have some time away to re‐educate for a time when they may want to re‐enter the work force themselves.

BREAK.PARA: Only those who have worked with the disabled truly understand how significant these changes are. In Murray, there has been up to a two‐year wait to get school holiday respite care so that the family of a disabled person can take a break with their other sons and daughters. That might not seem so much, but to a family it is essential. Marriage breakdown is an all too frequent outcome when one of the parents, usually the mother, has to devote so much of her time and emotional energy to a severely disabled child. Yet there is a two‐year wait for respite care for the family of a severely disabled child.

It has been the case in the past that a single night's emergency respite care for a profoundly intellectually disabled child has been reflected immediately in a reduced carer's payment to the parent. We are going to be more humane, compassionate and flexible.

A week ago, I briefed the Numurkah Association for the Intellectually Disabled on the new carers initiatives in the budget. This group of parents and other concerned community members have built up excellent education, training and residential services for the disabled over a period of 30 years. They know just how hard it is to provide the opportunities and support for the disabled in their care—in particular, to find them employment.

They were very welcoming of this budget, especially the fact that it provides 1,000 new employment places for people with a disability, as well as better access to advocacy services. Open, sheltered and supported employment organisations will be eligible to apply for growth funding.

Our government, a caring government, recognises that disabled people have a range of employment needs and interests and should not be straight‐jacketed into some department's preferred employment or supervisory model. We are not about political correctness; we are about maximum opportunities for people who have a range of capacities and interests. This budget, through its employment place creation, will see that flexibility and diversity of employment is there for the disabled.

Despite that very good news, the Australian Democrats have deliberately tried to alarm the public by claiming in a media release that some 34,000 people should expect to see their disability support pensions cancelled. This is a cruel tactic aimed at causing maximum distress to the most vulnerable in our community. Yes, those who were transferred from an invalid to a disability support pension in 1991, five years ago, will be reviewed—for the first time—to see if their condition has changed. Those over 55 should not be reviewed.

If it is found that the individual is able to return to work—in other words, their health is better—they will not be left high and dry, as the Democrats have suggested. They will not be left without any means of support. They will be transferred, if they do not have any work, to an unemployment benefit; or, if they need training or other relevant support, such as the age pension, that is what will occur. To talk about 34,000 people out on the streets tomorrow is cruel and not right.

A Labor Prime Minister, Bob Hawke, once promised that under his policies no Australian child would live in poverty. He even had a target year—1990. Our budget does not deal in slogans. Instead, we recognise the causes of child poverty. We are committed to ensuring that families have access to affordable child care; have assistance to buy private health insurance; and, most importantly, will benefit from the family tax initiative.

We recognise that child poverty is a multi‐faceted problem and needs to be tackled from many dimensions. We are tackling the potential or real inequality at its heart. We recognise that up to 20 per cent of children leave school functionally illiterate. Their futures are blighted as they are left behind in an information driven society. There are now and will be in the future fewer jobs for the unskilled and the non‐literate. It is a cruelty to have a school system that has 20 per cent of children leaving functionally illiterate.

It is this government's promise that every child leaving primary school will be able to read, write, spell and communicate at an appropriate level. To achieve this, funding for literacy and numeracy programs in schools will increase by 50 per cent to $45 million over the next three years.

We also recognise that many students fail to reach their potential because they simply are not aware of all the career options. This budget will tackle vocational education. It will counter disadvantage through an $80 million package for vocational education in schools, $40 million for workplace training opportunities for students, $38 million for work placement coordinators, and $23 million to implement vocational education in schools.

Instead of the mickey mouse training packages offered under the previous government that did little for the long-term unemployed, this budget has provided for school based apprenticeships and traineeships to allow students to combine paid work with their secondary school certificate. Already, in our electorate, the Northern Industry Education Board has tested this model and established food technology courses which combine the final years of secondary school with industry mentoring, work experience and TAFE training. We see this type of vocation focused education and training as the hope for the future in our region where we have a shortage of skilled workers for the food manufacturing and engineering sectors.

Of course, many students will want to go on to university. This budget recognises the significance of that sector and, through the introduction of HECS exemption scholarships, it will help. A more streamlined Austudy program, and the potential for Australian and international students to purchase some 25 per cent of places—all of those things bring the university closer and make it more accessible to all people.

By helping to establish these linkages between schools, universities and the workplace, we will be giving more hope and a better future to our children. We will be helping to create a clever country based on the sustainable growth of business and industry.

PARA.BREAK: This is a budget that Australia has welcomed. People know it is tough but we have to start paying our way as a nation. The debt burden we were building year after year was a legacy that our children would have inherit ed. This is a budget that looks to a better future and I support it wholeheartedly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellis, Annette, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in support of the amendments to the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1996‐97 moved by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Mr Gareth Evans. In doing so I wish to draw to the attention of the House the effects of this Liberal budget in my electorate.

SPEECH.PARA: The member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) made a very big deal about how his government would have the interests of Mr and Mrs Namadgi—as he referred to them—at heart when he courted my electorate during the election campaign. Despite those smug claims, Prime Minister Howard's first budget offers nothing to the residents of Namadgi. The budget offers nothing to the unemployed, it inflicts a great deal of unnecessary pain on thousands of ordinary Australians in my electorate and proves beyond any doubt that Prime Minister Howard's promises can never again be believed.

The greatest failure of this budget is that it does nothing to solve Australia's greatest economic problem—unemployment. In fact, it only makes it worse. The effect of this budget can only be to take growth and therefore jobs out of the economy. Despite the deluded rantings of the member for Higgins (Mr Costello), no-one on this side of the House is arguing that the budget deficit should be ignored, but we firmly believe that it should be dealt with in a way that does not reduce growth and employment.

Higher growth is good because it means that more jobs will be created, incomes will be higher and business conditions improved. Increased growth means less spending on unemployment benefits and more taxation revenue because more people have jobs. Put simply, the higher the level of growth, the smaller the level of cuts needed to balance the budget. But, instead of striving for higher growth, the government has miserably opted for lower growth.

The effect of this budget on the residents of Namadgi is dramatic. The Howard Liberal government has continued its arrogant disregard for the Canberra community by savaging the public service, starving the construction industry and gutting higher education. During the recent election campaign the former Liberal member for Canberra went around this town promising a 2,500 limit on the number of public sector job cuts. However, thousands of jobs have already been lost directly through cuts to public programs and services. Many more jobs will be lost indirectly from the effects of lower government spending on private businesses and local communities and because the budget reduces growth, tens of thousands of new jobs that could have been created over the next two years will not now be created.

The coalition has shown a punitive, short-sighted attitude towards the public service over many years. This budget is no different. The Community and Public Sector Union reports that over 27,000 public service jobs have been targeted for cutting, or have already been cut, with more to be targeted as the year goes on. The government's own budget papers state that 10,500 public service jobs will be cut from June 1996 to June 1997. This is over and above the job cuts already announced.

Public service jobs are not the only ones being destroyed by the Prime Minister's cuts. The simple fact is that when you cut public service jobs, you also destroy job opportunities for other workers out in the private sector. In Canberra, the strength and the viability of the private sector is more dependent on the public sector and government decisions than in any other city in the nation. The growth of small and medium business in this town is reliant on certainty and stability in the public sector.

The inter‐relationship between the two sectors is vital. For example, the relocation of staff and eventual closure of the Tuggeranong CES office will cause local private businesses to suffer. Already, small and medium businesses in my electorate, places like clothing retailers and cafes, have had to lay off workers because of the cuts. In fact, a small business operator said to me only last weekend in the Hyperdome, `Johnny Howard said things would be better with him. Well, they're not.'

BREAK.PARA: A further blow to the local economy comes from the government's decision to abandon the construction of new buildings for the Department of the Environment, the National Film and Sound Archive and the Australian Federal Police. This decision was taken despite the justified need for these buildings and the obvious positive effects the construction would have on the local economy, employment and business confidence.

By failing to meet the accommodation needs of the environment department alone the government has incurred additional property operating costs of $1.5 million over the next three years. This is not the only example of false economy. The Australian Federal Police Association has criticised the government's decision not to go ahead with construction of the national headquarters for the AFP because the age and condition of the existing accommodation makes necessary computer and technology upgrades difficult and expensive to install.

The Howard government's disregard for the ACT community is overwhelming. It seems that they want to see our national capital a true bush capital, not just in name but in reality—with no people, no buildings, just trees and a return to the limestone plains.

The government's pre‐budget announcement of significant cuts to higher education was a pathetic attempt to con parents and students that not much had changed, that the higher education budget had only been `given a little nick', to quote a minister. This is an outrageous claim, particularly given that the coalition promised before the election to `at least maintain the level of Commonwealth funding to universities both in terms of operating grants and research grants'. There can be no doubt that the proposed changes to HECS and university funding will have a big effect on current students and an even bigger effect on young Australians who hope to gain a university education. Cuts to the universities will mean a reduction in the number of government funded places. As a result, young Australians from ordinary families will miss out on places while those from wealthier families will be able to buy a place if they miss out on a government funded place.

I fear that Mr and Mrs Namadgi will find that paying full up‐front fees is the only way to get a university place for their child in institutions where the Howard government has cut gross funding. A crucial aspect of the proposed changes to HECS is the decision to make existing students start paying their HECS debt at a much lower income, $20,700 instead of $28,500. The lowering of the repayment threshold from average weekly earnings removes one of the key measures of fairness in the system. Make no mistake, it will lead to continued reductions in the future.
