During the recent election campaign the Prime Minister promised Mr and Mrs Namadgi additional places in family day care and retention of the non‐means tested child‐care cash rebate and of the system of child‐care assistance. These commitments have not been kept either. Despite the Prime Minister's claims, many Namadgi families will find that the Liberals' family tax initiative will not cover increased costs they will have to bear as a result of the budget. For example, Mr and Mrs Namadgi on a combined income of $47,000 a year with two children in child care for 50 hours a week will have to pay $14.93 a week more, and extra if their children go to community based long day care. The Howard government's family tax initiative gives Mr and Mrs Namadgi just $7.70 a week, leaving them $7.23 a week worse off.

Another point: Ms Namadgi, a sole parent earning $28,000 a year and studying one night a week, with two kids in child care for 55 hours, will have to pay $41.69 a week more, extra if the children go to community based long day care. The Howard government gives Ms Namadgi only $17.30 a week extra. She is therefore $24.39 a week worse off.

Previously Mr and Mrs Namadgi had a threshold of $30 per week of income per child that the government exempted when calculating child‐care assistance. That does not count any more and will result in lower levels of assistance. If Mr and Mrs Namadgi work long hours, the Howard government is now saying they have to pay full costs once child care goes over 50 hours a week. In addition, the government has frozen the amount of child‐care payments families can receive for the next two years. At the same time they are allowing the minimum fee which Mr and Mrs Namadgi have to pay to rise. This will increase the gap between government assistance and the rate actually charged by the centre.

In marked contrast to these pathetic efforts of the government, the former Labor government had a long history of achievement in child care: the introduction of child‐care assistance, the child‐care cash rebate and operational subsidies for community based child‐care centres. Most importantly, child care was made much more affordable and available. The difference between Labor and the conservatives is that we actually believe in families having a choice to access flexible, affordable, high quality child care. This budget represents the first step towards undoing all those achievements. The increased child‐care costs will almost certainly make many women think twice about re‐entering or remaining in the work force.

Now let us look at the government's planned creation of a new statutory authority to be known, I understand, as `the Agency'. This agency will be formed out of the Department of Social Security and the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs and will take on the current responsibilities of the Department of Social Security in addition to the registration, assessment and referral of the unemployed. It is intended that the agency will be established in July of 1997 and the transformation completed by December of that year.

This proposal raises serious questions for jobseekers in my electorate. What will the agency actually be doing? Will the unemployed clients still be able to deal personally with case managers? How will the touch screen referral service operate? Will all referrals be given centrally from the agency or will the client have to travel to each EPE or PEPE to get their referral? It appears that the new all‐singing, all‐dancing agency will do little to actually improve services to the unemployed. Unfortunately in the case of my electorate all of the indications are that the agency will be located outside the electorate, leaving a population of nearly 100,000 people without any local service at all. I guess it is just tough luck for Mr Howard's Mr and Mrs Namadgi and their kids should they happen to be unemployed. We have not even talked about the elderly, the disabled and others who travel to access Department of Social Security type services in that new regime.

In yet another blow to Mr and Mrs Namadgi, the government has announced cuts to public hospital funding of around $1 billion over four years, which will impact on the quality of health services they can expect to receive. We already know that hospital funding grants to the states will be cut by a total of $313 million over the next four years. This reduction in funding must mean a reduction in public hospital standards and longer waiting lists. If Mr Howard's Mr and Mrs Namadgi were to take out private health insurance as the Prime Minister wants them to, it is true that they would get a rebate of up to $450 per annum. However, they are only entitled to this rebate if they fork out around $2,000, leaving them $1,500 per year worse off.

The Prime Minister has increased the price of pharmaceuticals covered by the PBS system by up to 20 per cent. Concession card holders, including pensioners, will pay an extra 50c per prescription, but that is not all. Concession card holders will now have to pay an extra $26 a year before becoming eligible for the PBS safety net. General patients will now have to pay an extra $2.60 for prescriptions charged at the maximum rate. This means that Mr and Mrs Namadgi, who have a child with chronic asthma, for example, will have to pay an extra $52 a year for the child's 20 PBS prescriptions.

Low income Australians will suffer greatly from the scrapping of the Commonwealth dental program. The program provides quality care for concession holders who are unable to afford private dental health care. The scrapping of this program will cause great hardship for thousands of Australians.

The Prime Minister has also decided to reduce funding and introduce or increase user charges for home and community services. A pensioner who uses three hours a week of these services for home help, nursing and home meals may have to pay up to $18.90 a week or $980 a year. Older Australians will also be hit by the introduction of up‐front entry fees to nursing homes. The average nursing home entry is estimated to be around $30,000 but there is no limit on what nursing homes will in fact be able to charge. Only part of this entry payment will be refunded when a resident leaves the nursing home. The government has failed to give a guarantee that nursing home residents or their spouses will not have to sell their homes to pay that new up‐front fee. Pensioners who do not own their own home and do not have significant financial assets may not have to pay the up‐front fee, but I ask how the government will guarantee that these people will not be discriminated against by nursing home operators who would prefer people who can pay the up‐front fee.

In addition to the new entry fees, nursing home patients will also have to pay a new means tested daily fee of up to $34. I understand that pensioners with private incomes as low as $50 a week will have to face that fee. How do I console the lady who came to see me after the budget in my electorate, a self‐funded retiree whose husband is in a nursing home suffering from dementia? She is losing sleep worrying about how she can maintain his existence in that nursing home should she be faced with a fee increase of something like $34 a day.

Mr Deputy Speaker, even after the undoubted joy of being courted and condoled by the Prime Minister, Mr and Mrs Namadgi have come out of this budget much worse off. They face increased costs for health, education and child care. Even after paying this huge price the budget will not solve our most pressing economic problem—unemployment. It is all very well for the government and the Treasurer to boast that their budget has been well received but as a young person said to me last week in my electorate office, `The money market, the economists, they may like the budget, but they don't happen to live in a mortgaged family house in a street somewhere in Tuggeranong'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nugent, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to make some comment on a contribution made earlier in this debate by the mem ber for Oxley (Ms Hanson). The member made a number of assertions and statements were made which have received wide publicity outside of this place since that speech. It seems to me that it is incumbent on members in this place to challenge some of those statements and, particularly, to put some of the facts on the record. I believe that many of the statements made by the member for Oxley were not supported or substantiated by facts.

SPEECH.PARA: I am disappointed that many of our spokesmen on both sides of the chamber have chosen not to challenge some of the statements made by the member in her statement. I think it is important that somebody in this place is seen to be prepared to stand up and point out what I believe is the error of many of her statements.

Whilst it is not possible to deal with every single aspect of what the member for Oxley said, I want to comment on three or four or five—if I have time—in some detail. First of all, and I quote from the Hansard, I take issue with the statement made by the member for Oxley where she said:

. . . I am fed up to the back teeth with the inequalities that are being promoted by the government and paid for by the taxpayer under the assumption that Aboriginals are the most disadvantaged people in Australia.

I do not believe that there is any assumption about the situation of Aboriginal people in this country. There are certainly other disadvantaged people, Aboriginal people are not the only disadvantaged people, but as a group there is no question that the facts demonstrate quite clearly that Aboriginal people are the most disadvantaged people in this country.

The first fact that you can look at is life expectancy. Life expectancy is conditioned by a number of factors whether it is infrastructure, housing, health, employment or whatever. If you are a non-Aboriginal male child born in Australia this year—and I have grandchildren who have been born in this country and I had another grandchild born this year—then compared with an Aboriginal male child born in this country in 1996 you have an 18-year better life expectancy. An Aboriginal female child born today compared with a non‐Aboriginal female child born today in this country has a 15-year less life expectancy. That is the first, hard, crushing fact of life for the indigenous population of this country, and it is a factual piece of information. There is no assumption about Aboriginal groups being disadvantaged, it is very factual.

Look at the health statistics such as the rate of diabetes in Aboriginal women. If we look at the rate of middle ear infection, in many Aboriginal primary schools up to 50 per cent of the children in those schools have middle ear infections. That means that they not only have a health problem, it means that they have an education problem as well.

There is no other school outside of the Aboriginal community in this country that has got health statistics of that type. It is not uncommon, because of a lack of infrastructure—clean water, clean housing, sanitation and so on—to find that all the health statistics in many Aboriginal communities are quite appallingly below those of other areas of our community. When we look at education, at the number of children in the Aboriginal community who get a good education, we find that the numbers are appallingly behind those of the wider community.

Looking at housing: you travel to many of the Aboriginal and indigenous communities in this country and you will find that the overcrowding in housing is really quite disgraceful and is in fact only comparable often with the most appalling conditions in the Third World countries of this globe. I have said in this place before, for example, on trips that I have made to Aboriginal communities, it is not uncommon to find 20 or 30 people living in a house. In fact, in one community I went to in the Northern Territory, there were 38 people on average living in a three‐bedroom house in the 200 houses in that community. Can you imagine 38 people living in a three‐bedroom house, with one toilet and one shower, in a hot climate. It is appalling.

There is nowhere else in this community or in this country where those sorts of housing numbers in fact apply. Three years ago the Industry Commission did a study on Aboriginal housing and they came to the conclusion that we required to spend over $2 billion just to bring Aboriginal housing up to the standard of the rest of the community. So how could anybody possibly say that the Aboriginal community is not disadvantaged in terms of housing?

When we look at employment—and we talk in this place about employment regularly—we talk about the appalling state of the unemployment rate, which is stuck at about eight per cent. We would all like to see that improved. We may argue between the two sides of politics about how we should go about that. But the reality is that in Aboriginal communities in the length and breadth of the country, even in good times, unemployment rates are usually stuck at about 80 per cent. In many Aboriginal communities, we actually say to that community, `Don't just accept the dole, go on to the CDEP scheme', which is a scheme that I support, but it is a work for the dole scheme. I think that has many advantages, but we do not require that of non‐Aboriginal people in this country. It seems to me that, there again in employment, they are a specifically identifiable group that, in fact, are disadvantaged compared with the rest of us.

Then of course we can get on to looking at the legal system and the representation in gaol. The truth of the matter is that if you are a 15‐ to 19‐year‐old Aboriginal youth and you come from Western Australia, you are going to be more than 50 times—five zero times—more likely to be in custody in one form or another than if you are a non‐Aboriginal youth in the same age band. I am not saying that if an Aboriginal youth commits a crime, they should not be locked up. But what I am saying is that, when you get into the areas of criminal activity or substance abuse and so on and so forth, those are usually products of the environment in which you have been brought up and the socioeconomic deprivation that you have suffered. Because Aboriginal kids suffer greater socioeconomic deprivation than the rest of our community, they tend to be overrepresented in our legal system.

Then of course you can get into the whole area of substance abuse. Again, it is not a racial thing. Across the world, in eastern Europe, in particular when the Berlin Wall came down, they found in eastern Germany—and since the USSR crumbled, they found in Russia—that, because of socioeconomic factors, crime is rife and substance abuse is rife in many of those countries. Amongst the areas of our community in Australia where substance abuse is most rife is the indigenous community because of the socioeconomic disadvantage that they suffer.

The reality of life is that in this country over the last 10 years, certainly over the last 50 years and probably over the last 200, we have tried a number of measures to deal with the disadvantage suffered by Aboriginal people. We have tried full integration, we have tried full assimilation, and the reality is that it did not work. Therefore, we have to say that, as for any disadvantaged group in our community, whether it be the handicapped, whether it be the mentally ill, or any other identifiable group, special measures are needed. The evidence is there that special measures are needed for the indigenous community.

I have criticised the former government for its failures in this area. I have acknowledged publicly its good intent but I believe that it did not make much difference, in the 13 years it was in government, to the situation of Aboriginal people. So we need to look for new ways. Just abolishing special programs and saying that these people have to be treated the same as everybody else has been demonstrated to be a failure in the past. If it is tried again in the future it will be a failure again. We have to recognise the cultural differences.
The member for Oxley, in her speech, complained that the Aboriginal people say, `This is our land.' To this she said—and again I quote from Hansard:
Well, where the hell do I go?

The answer is that she does not go anywhere. She sits pat. Freehold, leasehold, whatever land you and I, Mr Deputy Speaker live on, or the member for Oxley, or anybody else in this chamber, is totally unaffected. We have a legal basis on which we stay on the land we are on and to suggest otherwise is ridiculous. Nobody is going to move any non‐Aboriginal person off their land as a result of the native title legislation or as a result of the land acquisition fund or any of those things.

BREAK.PARA: When we talk about native title—and this is the context in which the member for Oxley raised the matter—we are talking about land that was originally owned by Aboriginal people and has been recognised by the courts as still vacant crown land to which they may have a claim, providing they can prove continuing association over the last 200 years.

Again the other side of the chamber and our side of the chamber may have differences of views as to how that legislation is being implemented and whether it is effective. There is no doubt that so far the only people to have benefited since the legislation was passed have been the lawyers. Not a single Aboriginal person has got a piece of native title land. But to suggest that because of things like native title we are all going to be kicked on, frankly, is scaremongering of the base kind.
The member for Oxley said also:
. . . I draw the line when told I must pay and continue paying for something that happened over 200 years ago.

This is a popular line in some quarters of our community, that we are paying for the damage that was done 200 years ago. Anything that this parliament does, and any money and programs that this parliament may decide to put in place in respect of disadvantaged people in our community, has nothing to do directly with what happened 200 years ago. It may be somewhat of an inheritance but what we are talking about is trying to fix the problems that are here today. I recounted earlier a number of the disadvantage factors for the indigenous community. We are trying to address some of those factors, as we should.
It was interesting, on a more minor mundane matter perhaps, but one which I think needs to be challenged, that the member for Oxley said:

Those who feed off the Aboriginal industry do not want to see things changed. Look at the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation. Members receive $290 a day sitting allowance and $320 a day travelling allowance and most of these people also hold other very well paid positions. No wonder they did not want to resign recently!

Let me inform the member for Oxley that I am a member of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation. I am the government nominee and I have been the coalition nominee for the last five years. The fact of the matter in terms of how the council functions is that the rates that are applied are the standard rates for any government body of this type. I have not heard the member for Oxley come in here and complain about the rates in respect of any other body, only the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation.

She might be interested to know that members like me, who are on the government payroll in other respects, do not get sitting fees. She might be interested to know also that many members of the council from outside of the government payroll choose not to take their fees or their TA, or donate it to their employer organisations or back to the process. In fact, very few take their sitting fees and/or their TA.

It is also interesting to note that the 25 people who are involved in that council meet four times a year as a formal council, plus other committee meetings and other activities on behalf of the council on a regular basis, and we meet at weekends. I have to say that I do not regard the fact that I have to go and stay in a hotel and I get a bit of TA which might give me an extra $50, perhaps, over my hotel bill as recompense for having to spend four of my weekends a year away from home. As you would know, Mr Deputy Speaker, and as the other members in here would know, we spend enough time away from home. We do that because we believe in what we are doing, not because we think we are on the gravy train.

The member for Oxley went on to say that reconciliation is everyone recognising and treating each other as equals and everyone must be responsible for their own actions. Exactly. When we treat indigenous people in this country like that, we will not have a need for organisations like the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation, but the reality is, of course, that we do not treat them like that.

Having talked about Aboriginal people, I want to raise another issue. The lady from Oxley said, `I believe we're in danger of being swamped by Asians. They have their own culture and religion and form ghettos and do not assimilate.' I say that is factually untrue and I challenge her to produce any substantive evidence. Of course there are migrants of all shapes, sizes, colours and hues that come to this country who may not be successful in our community, but there are thousands upon thousands upon thousands of immigrants that come to this country, including Asian immigrants, who do extremely well and make major contributions for the benefit of our country.

Look at some of the doctors, the heart doctors who are Chinese. Look at some of the Asians that we have in engineering and science. Look at some of the Asians who do so well in business or in sports. And what is wrong with coming here with your own religion? Do we say to the non‐Asians in our community that they cannot choose their religion? The very basis of our democracy is that we have freedom of choice of religion. How can you criticise people coming here from whatever their background about having their own religion? How can you criticise people, saying they all live in ghettos, when in my electorate alone people who are immigrants, including Asians, are spread right throughout the community and they are integrated into the community outstandingly?

The previous government introduced and we have continued a system whereby we give scholarships to the 500 highest achievers in the academic system at the end of the school year. In the last couple of years most of those people tend to have been Asians in my electorate. Those people are contributing, they are involved and they are doing an outstanding job. To make the sorts of comments the member for Oxley made is, quite frankly, nonsense.
The member for Oxley also talked about overseas aid. She said:

In this financial year we will be spending at least $1.5 billion on foreign aid and we cannot be sure that this money will be properly spent, as corruption and mismanagement in many of the recipient countries are legend.

There is no question that corruption and mismanagement in many of the recipient countries is absolutely appalling, but the reality is that the amount of money we spend is something like 0.2 per cent of our gross domestic product—a minute amount of the overall budget. When you go to some of the other countries around the world and you see the conditions that millions of people are living in, for a country like Australia not to have the charity in its heart and the goodwill to actually try to get out there and help some of those people—if we cannot do that, I frankly think we should pack up and go home.

I just came back from a delegation to India and Pakistan and some of the conditions in those countries are quite appalling. It is not the individual's fault. I went to a slum in one of those countries where people live in the most appalling conditions, conditions that we cannot even conceive of in this country. If we cannot afford to spend a small fraction of our wealth, which is still considerable in spite of all of our many economic difficulties, on helping those people, I think it is quite appalling.

In Pakistan, I went to a project where we were helping young children and where in fact this government has just cut back on our aid, as all members of this place will know. I would have to say that it was one of the elements of the budget that I would personally probably have wished to see turn out differently. However, I am not going to argue about that at the moment. But the reality is that we cut back on our aid and one of the projects that I went to see is not going to get its funding next year. There were children in this project that we are directly funding—not channelling through some government official so that it is all being syphoned off—where we have people on the ground, where we are supervising the project, where we are making sure that we pick the people who work in there and where every single dollar that we are donating in aid is actually having a direct benefit on the poor of this world. It seems to me that if we cannot do that, frankly, I would not want to be in this country or in this parliament. It is something that we have a moral obligation to undertake.

The member for Oxley talked about a whole range of other things. She talked about the Child Support Agency, she talked about the economy, she talked about national service—I might add that the green corps is a form of national service—but it seemed to me that the speech was riddled with no research, no facts, very little logic, nothing constructive, generalisations and simplistic solutions that have been proven in the past not to work. It might strike a chord with some, but it seems to me that she does neither the House, her electorate nor this country any service by making those comments. I oppose her views. I will challenge them and I will rebut them at every opportunity because I believe that is one of the reasons why my electorate has sent me here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mossfield, Frank, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the amendment moved by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Holt (Mr Gareth Evans). In doing so, I intend to comment on what essentially are two separate budgets introduced by the Howard government.

SPEECH.PARA: The first budget, cynically and deliberately introduced in electronic media and various press statements, was clearly designed to lessen the public outcry at the many broken promises and cuts to major government programs and services that had been introduced during the period of the previous Labor government. These included cuts to Aboriginal programs, cuts to labour market programs, cuts to the ABC, and cuts to the better cities program, which will have a devastating effect on electorates such as Greenway where we have such a new area and we need to have infrastructure development. The fact is that the Blacktown railway station, which is a great asset to the travelling public of western Sydney, was built under the better cities program. But we also had cuts to new migrant programs, cuts to higher education and the closure of government offices.

Put simply, Mr Acting Speaker, we heard a lot more about the 1996 federal budget prior to 7.30 p.m. on Tuesday, 20 August than we heard on the night or have heard since. This attempt to lessen the public outrage by deliberately announcing budgetary‐type decisions prior to the actual budget speech is a clear breach of Westminster tradition. This tradition is that there is no official statement by the government of the day about budgetary decisions until the budget speech itself. This practice was enshrined in the Westminster system of government by the British Labour treasurer, Hugh Dalton. When he discovered that he had unintentionally breached this custom prior to delivering his 1947 budget to the British parliament, he offered his resignation to the Labour Prime Minister of the day, Clem Attlee. If the government ministers opposite were to follow this fine practice there would be very few of them left and I believe that the people of this country would be a lot better off.

Of all the broken promises and cuts announced in this budget, the $1.8 billion cut to labour market programs was the most callous. It was callous because the government has said, `Yes, we have high unemployment. No, our policies are not going to reduce unemployment dramatically in the short term. High unemployment is going to continue into the foreseeable future.' They are right because only today we have heard that there has been an increase in unemployment from 8.5 per cent to 8.8 per cent. So what is the government going to do? They will wind back labour market programs and over time pass the responsibility of getting Australians back into the work force over to private enterprise—that is, unemployment is to join the profit queues of the rich and greedy.

The question I ask this government is: what happens to the unemployed during this lag time between winding back labour market programs and the coalition government's policies being enacted? Clearly the responsible and humane way to go would be to retain existing labour market programs, while ever we have this high unemployment, until new programs, if in fact they do work, come into place. But, no, the government is asking the unemployed to suffer further humiliation and financial hardship. Why? Because deep down the Howard government really and truly believes that there is a group of people out there who do not want to work. While the government experiments with some new‐fangled policy of developing a profit making growth industry out of getting people back into the workplace, I am making a special plea on behalf of the unemployed in my electorate of Greenway for the government to reconsider its decision not to fund the Skillshare organisation.

It is ironic that the first public duty that I performed after the budget speech by the Treasurer (Mr Costello), which announced the $1.8 billion cut in labour market programs, was to address a graduation ceremony for a skillshare organisation in my electorate. At this function some 25 job seekers received certificates for completing courses in building trades, hospitality and computer operations. What impressed me most about this function was the family atmosphere, the friendly atmosphere that existed, where people were made to feel good about themselves and good about their achievements, where their confidence had been restored and where they had been put in the right frame of mind to seek employment successfully. Where is the confidence of the unemployed people going to go now under this government's policy?

I was able to report to this graduation function that the skillshare program was able to boast a 63 per cent success rate, with some 47 per cent of skillshare participants going into permanent employment and a further 16 per cent going on to further vocational training. I was able to report also to this function that the Skillshare organisation is very cost‐effective. For a figure of about $1,000 you turn a social security recipient into a job seeker, who in most cases turns into a taxpaying local consumer of goods and services.

Even the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone, has conceded that skillshare is not a labour market program but is a `generally high quality infrastructure'. It was, and it remains, good for Australia and Australians. The government should think long and hard before it finally withdraws funding from this piece of high quality infrastructure.

I turn now to cuts in higher education. The government's decision to increase the HECS payment for new university students and the decision to start repayments at a lower annual salary will mean that many children from working class families in the west of Sydney will be denied a university education. This additional financial impost on students and families through reductions in Commonwealth finances and increases in fees will impact on the access that local students have to a wide variety of courses.

As well, it will impact most critically on new universities such as the University of Western Sydney, which is only now developing links with local industry leading to increased employment opportunities in western Sydney. The UWS is the jewel in the crown of the education network in western Sydney. It serves an area that has 40 per cent of Sydney's population but it can offer only eight places per 1,000 people, while the rest of Sydney has 32 university places per 1,000.

Professor Deryck Schreuder, Vice‐Chancellor of the University of Western Sydney, has been most outspoken about the cuts in funding to higher education. He is quoted in the local Blacktown City Guardian newspaper as saying:
The real level of cuts to UWS will be 15% over the next three years including long overdue salary increases to staff.
This is a serious blow to the youth of western Sydney because the university could lose over 1,000 places in a region critically short of opportunities in higher education.
Professor Schreuder went on to say:
It is also a serious blow to business and industry in greater western Sydney where the university is the second biggest employer in a region where employment is a major issue.
Again I quote Professor Schreuder:

The federal government's decision to attack the tertiary education sector will seriously handicap Australia at a time when it is economically, technologically and culturally competing in the world arena and for young universities such as ours cuts could not have come at a worse time.

Students in my electorate like Gunjan Aggarwal, whom I spoke of in a member's statement this week and who had an outstanding success in the 1995 higher school certificate, with 99.8 per cent, will have to travel considerable distances to attend other universities in Sydney to complete a degree in medicine, engineering or law. This new fee structure for higher level degrees will force many of these young constituents of Green way to seek alternative careers, and far less satisfying and stimulating careers.

I will give the final say on this issue to a constituent of mine, Mr Terry Fendick, who wrote to me on 17 August. While we have heard from the other side how good this budget is, we have had very few hard facts about what people in the electorates are saying. Well, here is what a person in the electorate of Greenway is saying about the cuts to higher education. He said:

On Friday (9 August 1996) the federal government announced a crushing blow to potential tertiary students of limited means. My daughter is one such person who was hopeful of gaining a tertiary placement in 1997.

Up until that Friday she was preparing herself to accept many long, hard hours of dedicated study plus the cost of student union fees, writing materials and many, many reference/text books, and after all that emerging from an extremely intense four year university course with a $10,000 HECS debt. However, now she is devastated having to face a HECS debt of nearly double that previous repayment.
I suppose my daughter and many like her would have accepted a twenty or even thirty per cent rise in their HECS commitment, but double seems to be unfair and unreasonable.

The government seems to have taken a shallow view of university funding and in the long term may regret this decision when it is forced to recruit professional expertise from overseas because it discouraged highly motivated students in Australia from seeking further education.

That says quite clearly what I am sure a lot of people out there, the battlers in western Sydney and in other electorates, are saying. To add to that, I will quote from another letter from a constituent of mine, a Mr Steve Adamantidis of Kings Langley. He wrote:

. . . reeling as I am by the callousness of the Howard/Costello budget, the brunt of which will be carried by people like me and my family (being in my 50s on a disability support allowance and having a son at uni) which will be severely affected both by the cuts to the pension criteria and the unemployment allowance criteria as well as increased HECS repayments and not getting any of the benefits like rebates for health insurance or child allowances.
That letter is from another western Sydney battler speaking on this Howard budget.

BREAK.PARA: I will turn now to another very important issue in my electorate, the issue of child care. Under the previous Labor government the Blacktown local government area was approved as a high need area for new community based long day care places, family day care places and outside school hours places. Under Labor, western Sydney had 361 places for every 1,000 children compared with the New South Wales average of 326 places per 1000. Blacktown also had the highest relative level of long day care supply in western Sydney. Under Labor the availability and affordability of child-care facilities increased considerably.

All this will disappear under the coalition's heartless cutbacks. The removal of the operational funding for community based long day care centres will seriously affect young families who send their young children to community and council operated child-care centres. Blacktown Council operated 20 long day care centres. These centres were operated on a break-even basis. Fees are set taking into account all forms of operating costs. There is no profit from the service and all surplus funds are returned to keep fees at a minimum.

If the council is to provide the same level of child-care service, fees for children attending long day care centres will rise by $23 per week, a hugh amount for the battlers of western Sydney, taking the fee to $161.50 per week. Any fee increase will have a major impact on young, working families. It will force one parent to leave work to look after their children or else force parents to pay higher fees. Either way, this decision is going to have a major impact on Mr Howard's western Sydney battlers.

Community child care carried a greater share of the more expensive areas of child care : under two year old, disability and at risk children. Low‐cost community child care is most likely to be the only option for parents in less well-off areas.

I will now move to another area, aged care: the aged is another group which has done particularly badly out of this budget. This is extremely disappointing because Aged Care Australia made strong representations to all candidates prior to the March election. I recall receiving correspondence from them and personal representations. They drew attention to the growing problem of dementia within our society and the need for additional money to maintain or replace aged care buildings. They also referred to the need for increasing finance to cover spiralling costs of daily care of nursing home residents. With our aging population more people are making use of community care. Additional funds are urgently needed in this area also. We simply cannot wish these problems away or try to dump them on charitable groups. It is our collective responsibility to accept this challenge.

Aged Care Australia in their pre‐election representations sought urgent government action to develop in 1996 a new scheme to assess the unique care required for people with dementia that better reflects the additional cost of providing care in hostels, nursing home and community care packages. All candidates were advised that there are presently over 240,000 people with dementia throughout Australia and the number is growing. While most people with this illness live in the community there does come a time when family carers have to seek respite care in a nursing home or hospital. At this stage governments have not recognised that people with dementia need additional personal care over and above what is already provided in a nursing home or hostel. Increasing numbers of people living in nursing homes and hostels have moderate to severe dementia. What did aged people and the aged care providers get in the budget? Firstly, they got a pretty big fright. This fright was in the proposal that people who are not on a pension would have to pay an up-front fee of—and the figure here is not clear but certainly we could say—$30,000 upwards which is negotiable. These are people who were not on a pension. Entering a nursing home necessitated, it was first suggested, the sale of the family home.

I received several letters from people who were still in the work force who were supporting a sick partner either at home or in hospital. The question these people were all asking was, `Where will I get the up‐front finance to get my partner into a nursing home. Will I have to sell the family home?' Political expediency rather than a caring heart has caused the government to reconsider this proposal. What else did the needy section of our community get out of the budget? The residential aged care system will be put into reverse with a deteriorating system having no funds available for new capital works, replacements or upgradings in 1996‐97. The promise of special funding for dementia patients to apply from 1 January has not been honoured. The most unkind cut of all, Mr Acting Speaker, was the withdrawal of the in-principle funding for some 87 new nursing homes in New South Wales; and at least one nursing home in my own electorate, the Holy Family Nursing Home at Marayong, has been affected this way where they did have an in-principle agreement under the previous government to provide 11 new beds. So as not to interfere with the forward planning, it would have been expected that any reasonable government would have at least honoured existing agreements.

The members opposite in the debates I have heard so far, Mr Acting Speaker, have tried to suggest that in this area of aged care that the public has accepted the government's proposal but I would suggest there has been quite a deal of criticism and I will refer to this particular article which was in the Catholic Weekly of last week. It says:
Aged care row. Concerns for nursing homes. Proposed restructuring of aged care system by the government has been met with criticism by church and charity groups.
If I could just quote from this article:
It is also planning to drop strict auditing requirements that ensure the money is spent on patient care.

Francis Sullivan, executive director of the Australian Catholic Health Care Association. . . , said, `The Government has taken away a very strong regulatory requirement that ensures government money is put in for care.'
He said one of the primary differences between hostels and nursing homes is hostels are generally run by church or charity groups while most nursing homes are run by private operators for profit.
He believes—
I am quoting Francis Sullivan—
poorer areas, such as western Sydney, will suffer.

In conclusion, Mr Acting Speaker, it is clear that this budget has been prepared by bean counters, authorised by bean counters and delivered by bean counters. It has no soul, no feeling and no hope for Australians generally. It is a disappointment, true, but it is really a disaster for every needy person who used to rely on government—(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Billson, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker, the first budget of the coalition government lays the foundations for a better future. Despite the many legacies and problems left to all Australians by Labor, the Howard coalition government's first of many budgets is a sensible package of repairs and positive initiatives for the future. The budget is the first step in ending the Labor fantasy that they could somehow `belt the Bankcard' year after year to fund unsustainable levels of expenditure. The twentieth of August 1996 was rejection day for the Labor notion that current-day excesses could simply be passed on to our children as debt.

SPEECH.PARA: Labor's last dishonest legacy to the Australian people was a $10.3 billion budget deficit, a deficit that the now Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) thought was going to be a surplus—a $718 million surplus—a surplus he assured Australian voters that his government was on track for; a surplus that proved to exist only in his imagination; a surplus that the same officials at his fingertips later informed a conscientious coalition Treasurer was not a surplus at all.

After the smoke and mirrors were cleared, Australians were greeted with the Beazley black hole. Labor's phoney and fudged claims of surplus simply disappeared. In fact, the Leader of the Opposition's ability to make a surplus disappear to reveal a whopping big deficit made him look like the David Copperfield fiscal magician of this House. In fact, you could almost see the transformation of a Labor dodgy surplus to more deficit and more debt for Australians to bear.

But there was more to the Leader of the Opposition's `Copperfield Combo'. This surplus he assured us all was there was resting, like a trophy to Labor's deficit reduction strategy, on the fiscal credibility of the member for Brand (Mr Beazley). There it was. You could almost see it. And then, with a wave of coalition budget honesty and accountability—puff!—it was gone. Not only was the surplus gone to reveal a huge budget deficit, but so was the Leader of the Opposition's fiscal credibility. It just vanished. There was a $10.3 billion budget deficit just left hanging there, an opposition leader without fiscal credibility and a disgraced Labor Party with no idea of how to approach one of its ugliest creations. It was not a pretty sight, Mr Acting Speaker.

It was a legacy left by Labor to be repaired by the Howard coalition government; a repair job that Labor can only snipe and gibe at; a fiscal restoration that Labor cannot contribute to and can barely comment on, given the credibility-free zone the opposition leader created through his `Copperfield Combo'.
Economics commentator Christopher Gosselin said in the Age on 21 August:
Whether the Opposition or Democrats like it or not, the country cannot afford to continue running at a deficit. To do so undoubtedly puts pressure on interest rates. . .

I am pleased to see that the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Kernot, agrees that to prevent the passage of appropriation bills is a recipe for economic chaos. The budget is a $7.2 billion two‐year turnaround in Australia's finances. Apart from helping families, the other clear aim of the budget is to cement in the gains that have recently allowed interest rates to fall half a percentage point. Mr Acting Speaker, this has already meant an extra $65 a month, cash in hand, for families in the electorate of Dunkley, who hold an average mortgage of $100,000.
The media has been largely complimentary about the budget. Terry McCrann in the Herald‐Sun on 21 August said:
It is fair, it is responsible—it sets out to fix a huge and extremely dangerous fiscal time bomb. Most importantly, it is an honest budget.
Alan Wood in the Australian on 21 August commented:
The horror figures in this Budget. . . are the $69 billion of deficits accumulated during the last five years of the Labor Government.
It is interesting, Mr Acting Speaker, that now one of those people who have contributed to that deficit is wishing to stand as the Labor candidate in the seat of Lindsay.

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! It being 2 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 101A. The debate may be resumed at a later hour. The member will have leave to continue speaking when the debate is resumed.

—I inform the House that the Deputy Prime Minister is absent from question time today, as he is overseas on government business. The Minister for Foreign Affairs will answer questions on his behalf. I also advise that the Attorney-General and the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel are absent from Canberra on government business. Their questions will be respectively answered by the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and the Minister for Defence.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Are you aware that your employment minister has set the sole criteria on which voters can judge your performance? Are you aware that, when asked by Kerry O'Brien on the 7.30 Report last night whether your policies will reduce unemployment, she said, `Gee, we won't get re-elected if it doesn't . . . As I said to you, we won't get re‐elected if it doesn't.' With unemployment up from 8.5 per cent to 8.8 per cent, and with youth unemployment up 2½ per cent to 27.6 per cent, will you be encouraging the voters of Lindsay to take her advice?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Any hope that the Labor Party had learnt humility from 2 March has been completely dynamited away.
—Order! Members on my left might start the day off calmly. Don't get too excited.

—There are a couple of things that I would like to say about the issue of unemployment. The first is that it is perfectly plain from today's unemployment figures that the worst of all the legacies left to us by the defeated Keating government is high unemployment.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—You have been in office for six months.

—The Labor Party is seriously asking the Australian people to believe that a government that has been in power for six months carries more responsibility for unemployment than a government that was in power for 13 years. That is your absolute gall—the absolute insult—that you are delivering to the Australian people.
—You are sacking people. It is your unemployment.
—The member for Prospect!

—You are insulting the Australian people. That is why the people of Lindsay threw you out. They threw you out because you were responsible for the highest unemployment since the Great Depression. The people of Lindsay threw you out because you caused the highest level of unemployment since the Great Depression. You failed the people of the western suburbs of Sydney, and that is why you were thrown out.
—John Howard—failed Prime Minister. Jobless Johnny.
—The member for Denison!

—It is very interesting that the Leader of the Opposition should lead on the subject of unemployment. The reality is that unemployment in this country will not be turned around until the policies of the new government are allowed to operate. Those policies include the passage of the budget and the passage of the industrial relations legislation. They also include all of the other measures that are designed to improve the operating conditions of small business in this country.

ANSWER.PARA: I say again to the people of Lindsay and to the people all over Australia: for 13 years Labor demonstrated it had no answer to the problem of unemployment. For 32 consecutive months under the Hawke and Keating government, the level of unemployment was higher than it was at any time under the previous coalition government. For 32 consecutive months that was the situation.
You have the nerve and the gall to come in and lecture us about unemployment. You ought to hang your head in shame for the unemployment legacy you left us on 2 March.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Prime Minister. Given the fact that today, Prime Minister, you announced a new initiative which will provide new opportunities and a real focus for rural and regional Australia, could you tell the parliament the types of areas to be examined by your new Supermarket to Asia council and how these deliberations will improve prospects for Australian food producers and Australia as a whole?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker, I thank the re-elected member for McEwen for that question and I place on record my appreciation and the appreciation of the government for the interest that she has taken, as a person representing a regional area of Australia, in the government's initiative that I first outlined in November last year as Leader of the Opposition to the National Farmers Federation.

ANSWER.PARA: I am very pleased about the establishment of the prime ministerial council, which is to be chaired by me and which is to include four senior ministers: the Deputy Prime Minister; the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy; the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism; and the Minister for Transport and Regional Development. I am also happy to say that the council includes Mr Reg Clairs, the Managing Director of Woolworths; Mr Murray Rogers of the Australian Food Council; Mr Donald McGauchie, the President of the National Farmers Federation; Mr David Mortimer, the Managing Director of TNT; Mr Malcolm Irving, the Keating government's appointment as Chairman of the Australian Horticultural Corporation and a well‐known Sydney merchant banker; Mr George Kailis of the Kailis group; Mr Garry Ringwood of Amcor Ltd; Mr Joe de Bruyn, the National Secretary of the Shop, Distributive and Allied Employees Association and a very respected trade union leader; and Professor Adrian Clarke, the Chairman of the CSIRO.

This is a very representative group. The goals of the council are important to the future of agriculture in this country. I believe this is one of the most valuable initiatives for rural and regional Australia that has been launched by any government in this country for some years. I hope—there is reason for that hope by virtue of the attendance of the opposition spokesman on primary industry, the member for Perth, at the launch of the council today—that the council does draw the support of the opposition.

The total east Asian food market is projected to be $685 billion by the turn of the century. Eighty‐three billion dollars of that is met by imports. Food processing is the largest manufacturing sector in Australia. It is now 20 per cent of manufacturing turnover and it is growing at five per cent a year.

The combination of the enormous economic growth in the Asia-Pacific region plus the natural population increase and the tremendous surge within that population increase in the size of the middle class in Asia‐Pacific countries, which naturally carries with it a larger demand for more varied and more sophisticated foods, means that if we can marshal our resources in an effective, competitive fashion there are great opportunities to be won for regional and rural Australia from this particular initiative. I believe that the presence on this council of so many people with varied interests and the cooperation of the interests that they bring will guarantee that this will be one of the most valuable initiatives ever undertaken by any government in Australia. It lays down a sound foundation for the future economic prospects of people living in rural and regional areas of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister and follows directly on from the answer to the question that I previously asked him. In the course of his answer he repeated this claptrap about if only the government's economic policies are given an opportunity to work then we will all be whistling Dixie.

—Mr Acting Speaker, I raise a point of order. My point of order is that on every occasion the Leader of the Opposition asks a question he starts with a mini‐speech. He ought to be reminded of the standing orders and it ought to be made clear to him that it is inappropriate for him to do that.

—I thank the Leader of the House for his point of order. I point out to the House that questions cannot be debated nor can they contain arguments, comments or opinions and they certainly may not become lengthy speeches or statements. I am sure the Leader of the Opposition will get to his question.

—I ask the Prime Minister: are you aware that Professor Wootten, the principal author of the NILS report commissioned by Senator Vanstone, said this week that the government's labour market reforms `would not do anything to reduce unemployment in four years' and that his study `strongly indicated that the government would be left with an unemployment rate of eight per cent by the end of the decade'? Is this revelation about your policies the reason why you will not table the NILS report or set an unemployment target?

—The answer to the first part of the question is yes, I am aware of what he said. I would say further in answer to the question that his view—along with the views of many other people, including, for example, the Labor appointed and coalition continued Secretary to the Treasury, Mr Evans, who said in a speech, I think only about 10 days ago, that there was a direct link between unemployment and labour market reform—
—So what?

—You do not like Evans. Make up your mind. You appointed him as Secretary to the Treasury. When the Secretary to the Treasury, who not only is the principal economic adviser to this government but also was the principal economic adviser to your former government, says there is a link that is to be ignored. You appointed him. He has served both governments.
—What about unemployment targets?

—He has asked me questions about targets in relation to unemployment. Let me remind the Leader of the Opposition—the man who helped preside over the worst unemployment since the Great Depression—that for 32 consecutive months in the 1990s, which is when your Labor government was in power, unemployment was higher than it had been under any government since World War II. That is the sort of unemployment record that you have given to the Australian people. The Leader of the Opposition claims that the Labor Party was on track to achieve five per cent unemployment by the turn of the century.
—Release the report! Table the report!
—Order! The member for Batman should restrain himself.

—However, I remind the House that in 155 months in government—it was far too long—the Labor Party never got unemployment down to five per cent. In three out of 155 months it managed to get unemployment below six per cent. No wonder no‐one believed Labor when it claimed that it was on track to get unemployment down to five per cent.
—Tell us your target.
—Order! The member for Hotham!

—I repeat that unemployment in this country will not be turned around until the new policies of the new government are in operation. It is perfectly obvious to everybody in Australia that for the last 10 years at least we have been on the wrong track with unemployment in this country. A new track is required. Until we are able to get our industrial relations policy through the Senate, until we are able to get our budget through the Senate and until we are able to get other policies into operation, you have no moral or political credibility to criticise our performance on unemployment—no moral or political credibility at all.
—I seek leave to table the government's report from NILS.
—Order! Before I call the next question, I would suggest to the member for Fremantle that she has no need to try to compete with the member for Prospect for gaining my attention.

—My question is addressed to the Treasurer. I refer the Treasurer to the budget announcement of a contribution surcharge on higher income earners to improve the fairness of the current arrangements for taxing superannuation. Can the Treasurer advise the House as to the status of the implementation of this fairness measure?

—I thank the honourable member for her question. Let me make it clear that the government has introduced this proposal to improve the fairness of superannuation. A superannuation system that delivered 33 per cent concessions to upper income earners but did not deliver anything like that benefit to lower income earners was not a fair concession. The government moved, with its budget announcement, to deal with that. The government welcomes statements by the Australian Democrats that they support this equity and fairness measure. The Labor Party is apparently yet unable to come to a view on it.
—Ask us about it.
—Let me make it entirely clear—
—We would support it.
—You support it, do you?
—Well, we—
—Did you say you support it?
—We would support it but we would want—
—`We would support it.' Good. Thank you. That will do. That is all we want. Thank you very much. I could send you some questions.
—Oh, good.
—Yes, come on.
—You would like to ask me a few questions.
—No, I would like you to sit down.
—And what are you going to do?
—We are going to support—
—Order! Resume your seat!
—And what are you going to do?
—Order!
—We are going to support this proposition—
—The honourable Leader of the Opposition, resume your seat!
—But we are going to move amendments.
—Ah, ah! But to move an amendment.
—You can tell us—
—Order! Resume your seat!
—Oh, to move an amendment!
—Sit down! The Acting Speaker is on his feet.
—Order! I say to both sides of the House that I know it is Thursday, it is the end of the week. Let us limit the cross-table conversation and the abuse of the word `you'.

—I welcome the fact that the Leader of the Opposition supports equalising the tax concession and dealing with tax unfairness, which he overlooked for 13 years in government. I would be interested to see the amendment that he moves because, as is the case so often in this area, we have seen the Labor Party use amendments as a cover to try to hide their real position.
—I'll be moving a few amendments on this one, sport.

—You are backing away already. You know you are. The information required to be supplied by superannuation funds to the Australian Taxation Office should not be significantly more than they already require for the proper management of members' accounts other than the requirement to provide tax file numbers. Legislation prepared under the previous Labor government and currently before the Senate will enable superannuation funds to request tax file numbers.

BREAK.PARA: In the case of defined benefit superannuation schemes and unfunded schemes, the government has announced the establishment of an actuarial advisory committee to advise by 31 October 1996. The surcharge on higher income earners will involve certain changes to administrative procedures, with most of these falling on the ATO and superannuation funds. The costs are a necessary part of providing a fairer system. The changes are prospective. They provide the opportunity to streamline the administration of superannuation.

The Australian Taxation Office is consulting widely with the superannuation industry to ensure the new arrangements are introduced in the most efficient and cost-effective manner. Of course there will be some up-front costs in designing the new systems, but every effort will be made to ensure that the costs do not actually increase more than is necessary and do not provide additional costs to those who are not affected by this.

Electronic commerce is the key to ensuring the proposal works efficiently to bring about efficiency in superannuation in the area of information exchange. Suggestions that it would be more efficient for the Australian tax office to deal directly with around 8,000 employers rather than the 140,000 complying superannuation funds are dubious, and these would not take account of privacy considerations.
Let me make it entirely clear that this is a fairness measure. This is an equity measure. Full consultation will be undertaken to introduce it. It will improve the operation of superannuation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. I refer again to the performance of the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs on the 7.30 Report last night when she was asked, `Unemployment will fall?' and she replied, `Gee, we won't get re-elected if it doesn't.' Mr Prime Minister, do you agree with your minister? If not, why not? In light of today's disastrous unemployment figures showing an increase from 8.5 per cent to 8.8 per cent, with 35,000 more Australians unemployed than a month ago, what unemployment rate do you as Prime Minister think you will need to guarantee your return at the next election?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The member for Batman talking about unemployment is really a prime example of an arsonist claiming respectability as a firefighter. It really is. This man's leadership of the Australian Council of Trade Unions had more to do with the legacy of the high unemployment we have inherited than any person who was outside the ranks of the former government.

ANSWER.PARA: Of the many legacies inherited by the new coalition government on 2 March, none was worse than the legacy of high unemployment. You know and everyone of your fallen comrades on 2 March knows that your failure to deal with unemployment was one of the major reasons why you were thrown out of office and one of the major reasons why we were given authority. I say again to the Leader of the Opposition, and I say it to anybody on the front bench of the Labor Party: Australia's present high unemployment, which remains the major social and economic challenge of this government, is overwhelmingly a product of your government's failure.
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You can make noise. Noise is no substitute for reality. You can shout. You can interject. You can guffaw. You can bellow. Nothing can alter the fact that you ran the country for 13 years. You drove unemployment to higher levels—

—Mr Acting Speaker, I raise a point of order. Once again it seems neces sary to bring to your attention standing order 59. I ask the Prime Minister to direct his remarks through you. While he is doing so, he might like to tell us how many people have lost their jobs in the Hunter in the last six months.
—Resume your seat.

—For 13 years the former Labor government ran the affairs of this country. Under that government, unemployment went to higher levels than we had experienced since the years of the Great Depression. For 32 consecutive months under the Hawke and Keating government, unemployment was higher than it was under any other government since the end of World War II. In those circumstances, it is an outrageous piece of political bombast for the former Labor government to now shed crocodile tears over the high rate of unemployment that it left us to mop up.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development. Is the minister aware of press reports that Australian National is to advertise for expressions of interest for elements of its business enterprises? Can the minister advise whether this is so and why this is happening when a decision on the future of Australian National has not yet been made by the government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Adelaide for her question. Yes, I am aware of reports of the advertising of AN's assets for sale, certain aspects of their business enterprise for sale. I am also aware of reports of major job redundancies at AN. Some 950 job redundancies have been reported as likely to occur at AN at any moment.

ANSWER.PARA: It is a good question that the honourable member for Adelaide has put: how could this be so when the government has yet to decide on the future of AN following the findings of the Brew report? It is an interesting question. The answer to the honourable member for Adelaide is this: these reports about the possible sale of AN's assets and of major job losses at AN emanate from the fact that these sales and these job losses were planned in the business plan of the previous Labor government—

TALK.START.PARA: —The previous Labor government that devised the business plan from which these reports now emanate.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course, it is a very interesting proposition to consider as to how much did the previous government inform the workers of AN and the public of Australia about the business plan that it had developed for AN which has now led to these proposed measures possibly being undertaken. Both the former Minister for Transport, the member for Kingsford-Smith, and the former Minister for Finance were well aware of this business plan last year as it was developed. Indeed, there was correspondence from the former Minister for Finance congratulating AN for the business plan that was under way at the time.

Indeed, it is an interesting proposition to put to the House as to how much of the truth about AN's plans did the former government reveal to the workers of AN and to the people of Australia. For example, when the former Prime Minister, Mr Keating, and the former transport minister, the member for Kingsford-Smith, visited AN's workshops at Islington during the election campaign, did they inform them that they had developed and were approving a business plan which would lead to 950 job losses in the next financial year or indeed which would lead to the sale of parts of AN's business? Did they inform the workers at AN's workshop of that when they spoke with them? No, of course they did not.

It proves the very point that I was making in the House yesterday: the previous government deceived and betrayed the workers at AN over the future prospects of AN, as indeed it deceived the public of Australia. This government has inherited that problem and it is this government which will resolve it to the satisfaction of all Australians. But you can rest assured that, if the previous government had been left in office after the 2 March election, the workers at AN would have realised the betrayal of their Labor colleagues in the administration of their business.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans, Gareth, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Does the Prime Minister remember in July last year saying in his second so-called headland speech, `The new coalition government will have one unswerving, overriding, national goal, g-r-o-w-t-h'—`growth—real growth, sustainable growth'?
—Oh, well done!
—I do not believe we need the spelling lesson.
—That is what he says: `g-r-o-w-t-h'; it is all spelt out. There you are. It was a very big help. We got the message. It was very clearly spelt out: g-r-o-w-t-h.
—Table that.
—Yep. There it is; away you go.
—All the questions and answers. Put that down, Gary. Table the questions.
—No, that is the speech; there is your headland speech, July last year.
—Order! Is the deputy leader seeking leave to table it?
—I am seeking leave to table it.

QUESTION.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you still believe all that, why do your own budget papers reveal that your policies will produce, right up to the turn of the century, significantly lower growth than that which Australia enjoyed in the four years before your election? How is less growth going to give us the additional jobs that we need to counter the disastrous trend toward even greater unemployment which is revealed by today's job figures?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition has stirred himself to enter the fray about employment and growth. Let me say in response to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition that achieving a higher rate of economic growth is a major goal of this government. As I have said on a number of occasions, and I guess the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in his calmer moments might agree with me, the only way you can really have a sustainable reduction in unemployment in this country is to have a much faster rate of economic growth. We need to take the speed limits off growth.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me strike a bargain with the Deputy Leader of the Opposition: let the Labor Party allow us to implement the policies we were elected to implement and then let us see what happens to economic growth in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —We got four per cent. Remember that.
—If you are interested in economic growth and if you are interested in reducing unemployment, you will facilitate the passage of our industrial relations legislation.
—We got four per cent.

—The Deputy Leader of the Opposition crows about economic growth under the Labor Party. It was economic growth under the Labor government that left us with an unacceptably high level of unemployment. So you have nothing to crow about with your economic growth. If you cared about the future of unemployment in this country, you would let us implement our industrial relations reform—then you would really see economic growth in this country take off.
—Order! Before I call the next question, I suggest to the member for Denison that he has had a charmed life all week and there are not many of them left.

—My question is to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Minister, could you outline benefits for the veteran community in the recent budget? Have you had feedback as to how the veteran community have received the announcements from that budget?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Scott, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to inform the House that the government has kept its key pre‐election promises to veterans and will continue to improve the ways in which their service to Australia is recognised. Before the election we said we would review genuine and significant anomalies. We have done that in the process of this budget. We have already said—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The member for Lyons! The member for Grayndler!

—We said that we would provide as part of those anomalies extra medical grade footwear and a wider choice of spectacles for those entitled veterans. This is particularly important for those veterans who live in rural Australia. We will ensure that a war widow's access to a pension where her husband has died of a war related injury is automatic, without having to re‐establish her husband's cause of death. The special recognition of the status of veterans is that those veterans who receive a part disability pension will now have their full entitlement that used to be once paid by the Department of Social Security delivered by my department—
—If they have their own teeth.
—You may make a joke of it over there. I don't make a joke of the veteran community.
—What if they have to go to a nursing home?
—Order! The member for Dobell.

—You ought to be ashamed of yourselves, over there. Your leader ought to call you into line. We said that there would be no charges to go to the Australian War Memorial—and there will be no charges to go to the Australian War Memorial. I am also pleased to advise that we have received endorsement from the ex‐service community for our budget. I would just like to quote from a letter in the Herald‐Sun on Monday, 2 September. It is from Bruce Ruxton, the State President of the RSL. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: The RSL congratulates the government for the added assistance veterans will receive from the new budget.
He went on to say:

BREAK.PARA: Under the previous government, the Department of Vetereans' Affairs got a raw deal.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not what they said about Con Sciacca. They gave Con Sciacca life membership.
—The media release from the RSL says:

BREAK.PARA: Under the previous government, the Department of Veterans' Affairs got a raw deal.
The government has recognised the special needs of veterans—

TALK.START.PARA: —They gave life membership to Con Sciacca.
—Order! The minister will resume his seat until the members on my left settle down and we have a little bit of quiet and a little bit of order.
—Mr Speaker—
—Oh, here he comes.
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Dobell.

—On a point of order, Mr Acting Speaker, there is a constant stream of abuse. Yesterday, for example, Mr Acting Speaker, you warned members on the other side. Within two minutes the member for Denison, the member for Batman and the member for Kingsford‐Smith were simply ignoring your request for some reasonable decorum in the House. I invite you to consider all of the standing orders—and apply them.
—I thank the Leader of the House for his advice.

—The RSL said that the government has recognised the special needs of the veterans, cleared up several anomalies in the legislation and made a very welcome commitment to funding the Australian War Memorial. We do not take those endorsements for granted. What we intend to do is to build on our commitments that we gave prior to the election and seek further endorsements from the ex‐service community who clearly appreciate what we on this side of the House are trying to do to help our veteran community.

—Is the Treasurer aware that the new superannuation contribution surcharge may hit middle income earners, including workers in some industries who earn overtime payments equal to or more than their base salary? Does he agree that these people may find themselves paying a surcharge, even though their superannuation contributions are quite modest, being based on their base salary?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The superannuation surcharge will apply to people with incomes phasing in from $70,000 to $75,000. Whether you would call that modest or low is up to you but I would have thought that somebody who was on $70,000—including employer contributions, up to $85,000—was in the upper ranges of an income earner. They are most certainly on the top marginal tax rate—the 49 per cent tax rate. For a deductible employer contribution at 15 per cent, that gives them a 33 per cent tax concession.

ANSWER.PARA: If you are on $20,000 you are on the 20 per cent tax rate and for a deductible employer contribution of 15 per cent it gives you a five per cent tax concession. How could you possibly hold out to somebody on $20,000 that they will get a five percentage point tax concession and to somebody on $200,000 that they will get a 33 per cent tax concession? We are even getting silence on this point from the opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Silence is golden.

—Silence is golden. We welcome that from the opposition. It will impact in the way that I have described. People who are on base salaries or overtime who come within that income range will come within the application of the surcharge. I think it's fair; I think the Australian community thinks it's fair. Even the warped fairness views of the opposition apparently apply in a situation like this. I think it's a well overdue reform.
—Mr Acting Speaker—
—The honourable member—no, the honourable member for Kooyong.
—On a point of order, Mr Acting Speaker: you clearly saw me get the call first and you called me.
—I did not call you. I am observing the convention of the House and I have called a member of the government.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Georgiou, Petro, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to the minister's remarks about Australia's relations with India made in the House yesterday. I also refer to the minister's speech on Australia's relations with India and the New Horizons program made in Sydney last week. What is the government doing to upgrade Australia's relationship with India?

QUESTION.PARA: Mr Gareth Evans interjecting—

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Downer, Alexander, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Kooyong for his question. I notice that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition is still at his gracious best after his doorstop this morning. Cheap, cheap, Gary. Cheap.
—Please address your remarks through the chair, Minister.

—The government is deeply committed to strengthening our bilateral relationship with India and has already signalled that commitment to the Indian government. As I pointed out to the House yesterday, we do not want to let the differences of view we have had with India over the comprehensive test ban treaty disrupt the excellent bilateral relationship that we have.
