ANSWER.PARA: On the fourth of this month, I launched the major Australia-India New Horizons promotion that will take place in India in October and November this year. It is a program which will include expenditure by the Commonwealth government of about $6 million across several departments and also support from quite a number of businesses and some state governments.

New Horizons will lead the government's initiative for 1997, which will be known as the Year of South Asia. It is a very substantial undertaking that demonstrates the importance the government attaches to building our bilateral relations with India, particularly in the fields of trade and investment.

BREAK.PARA: I just want to add that the government also accords a very high priority to working with India on a range of regional issues. We welcomed India becoming a dialogue partner of ASEAN, and we strongly supported, after we came to government, India's recent membership to the ASEAN regional forum—support that has been well understood and well appreciated by the Indian government.

Australia and India are also working closely together to promote greater cooperation in the Indian Ocean region. During the course of this week, a meeting of officials is being held in Mauritius. At that meeting, Australia and India, together with our other Indian Ocean regional partners, are exploring proposals for an Indian Ocean regional economic association.
So the overall point I want to make in answer to the member's question is that Australia is according a very high priority to upgrading our relationship with India. I think that is very timely.

India has a population of over 900 million people. It is a country which has gone through a substantial economic transformation over the last five or so years. That economic transformation is leading to much higher rates of domestic growth in India and the opening of its markets to investment, including investment from Australian businesses. The comprehensive test ban treaty issues apart, we are finding India to be an increasingly valuable partner in regional institutions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Prime Minister. Prime Minister, I refer to your continued refusal to set an unemployment target. Are you aware that the Governor of the Reserve Bank, Bernie Fraser, today said, `I don't see any reason why we couldn't be aiming to get' (unemployment) `down to five or six per cent'?
—By when?
—By the end of the decade.
—He did not say that.
—Order! The Treasurer!

—If Mr Fraser thinks it is possible and your employment department gave you advice saying it was possible, why won't you commit to a five per cent unemployment rate by the end of the decade that will give real hope to jobless Australians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I start by saying that the member for Hotham has quite deliberately, quite knowingly and quite dishonestly misquoted the Governor of the Reserve Bank. The second part of my answer is to repeat a comment made some time ago—in fact, three years ago—by somebody, who said:

ANSWER.PARA: Our commitment, as a government and as a nation, should not be to any arbitrary unemployment number or rate.
Not to any arbitrary unemployment number or rate.
Our commitment must be to the reduction of unemployment as rapidly and as completely as possible.
They, of course, were the words of the now Leader of the Opposition, the then Minister for Employment, Education and Training.

Can I say to those opposite again—and to use the words of the then minister, the now Leader of the Opposition—the commitment is to the reduction of unemployment as rapidly and as completely as possible. That can be facilitated when, to start with, the Senate passes the workplace relations bill, a bill which will produce flexibility in the labour market. Mr Evans, the man appointed by the former Keating government and reappointed by the incoming Howard government as the principal economic adviser to both governments, sees the link between a freer labour market and the level of unemployment. Many commentators and observers see that link.

I say to those sitting opposite that you can ask these questions as frequently as you like, but it will not alter two absolutely unassailable facts. The first of those facts is that the high level of unemployment that we now suffer is a direct result of Labor's failed policies. That is point No. 1. The second point is that, until the new policies of the new government are in operation—and, specifically, are allowed to be in operation—the Labor party will continue to carry the moral and political responsibility for Australia's high level of unemployment.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government. Can the minister provide details of the Australian paralympic team result at the Atlanta Paralympic Games held in August 1996?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Smith, Warwick, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for Forde for her question. Indeed, it is an appropriate question to have because at lunchtime today here in Glebe Park, Canberra, one of the final welcome home parades for our triumphant paralympians was held. The paralympians were spoken to by me, and I was able to congratulate them on behalf of the government but, more particularly, on behalf of the whole parliament, because I felt sure the whole parliament would want to extend congratulations to the wonderful efforts of the elite athletes with disabilities who performed so well in Atlanta.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable member asked for specific details about the level of performance. We won 42 gold medals, 37 silver medals and 27 bronze medals and finished second overall on the number of gold medals won. This compared with our Barcelona performance of 24 gold, 27 silver and 25 bronze.

The Australian medallists set 18 world records and six Paralympic records. Those areas where we did particularly well were: athletics, where we won 43 medals; swimming, where we won 44 medals; and cycling, where we won 10. We also saw gold medals in basketball and judo.

There were many wonderful performances but two athletes in particular were outstanding in world terms and certainly far surpassed anything that Australian athletes have ever done before. Louise Sauvage won gold medals in the 400, 800, 1,500 and 5,000 metre wheelchair track events, and Priya Cooper won gold in the 100 freestyle, the 400 freestyle, the 100 backstroke, the 200 individual medley, silver in the 50 metres freestyle and bronze in the 100 metre butterfly. They were two absolutely outstanding results.

BREAK.PARA: Overall, Australia won 106 medals in the Paralympic Games. If you put that in perspective, the United States would have to have won 1,484 medals to match our performance. It was an absolutely outstanding performance, and I was delighted to be present at Sydney airport with the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Fischer, to welcome them when they arrived back recently.

TALK.START.PARA: —When did they arrive back?
—The member for Prospect!

—Of course, none of these performances could have happened without the support of coaches and team management. More particularly, I made mention today of the support that these athletes have received from families. Those of you who have been involved at all with Paralympics—and I know that the member for Forde has—will know that the strong support these athletes receive from their families is absolutely outstanding. I think we ought to all pay a tribute to those families for what they do.

BREAK.PARA: The results that we saw in Atlanta augur well for the activities of the Paralympics in Sydney in 2000 and, as already mentioned previously, the government is extending strong support of $25 million for the team in the year 2000.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. I refer again to Bernie Fraser's endorsement today of a five to six per cent unemployment target—
—By when? Tell us by when.
—Order! Members on my right!

—To the departmental advice given to Senator Vanstone in March that five per cent was achievable by 2001 and to the NILS study conclusion that this government is presently on track for unemployment of eight per cent by the end of the decade. Are you aware that the difference between having eight per cent unemployment and five per cent unemploy ment in 2001 is just on 300,000 jobs? In light of today's disastrous unemployment figures, how long are you going to persist with growth destroying and job destroying policies which will have this result? And what will the result be? A result where more than a quarter of a million Australians who desperately want and need jobs and who could have jobs will not have jobs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I make a couple of points in reply to the member for Batman. The first is that, interestingly, he did not repeat the distortion by the member for Hotham.
—Deceit and distortion.
—Set a target.
—Why don't you withdraw and apologise.

—The member for Hotham quite deliberately, knowingly and dishonestly misrepresented what the Governor of the Reserve Bank said. Can I say—through you, Mr Acting Speaker—to the member for Batman: you can ask as many of these questions as you like, and I would be happy to answer questions from you all day. I would be very happy to stand here all day and answer the questions, but nothing can alter the unassailable fact that for 13 years you people sitting opposite ran the affairs of this country and you drove unemployment to its highest level since the Great Depression.

ANSWER.PARA: For 32 consecutive months under Labor it was higher than it was at any time during the term of office of the Fraser government. You left a number of terrible legacies on 2 March; none was worse than the legacy of high unemployment. Until this government's new policies are allowed to be implemented, until we are given a fair opportunity to turn the situation around, you will be held responsible as you should be by the Australian people for having created such a disastrously high level of unemployment.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. I refer the minister to the ABS figures recently released showing that about one in three households now has a computer and that the rate is rising rapidly. What action is the government taking to ensure that Australian school students have access to technology that will improve their learning opportunities and help overcome information rich and information poor inequalities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Dr David, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for Cowan for his question. The government has put forward a number of initiatives to ensure that Australia's three million school students will have access to the world's most advanced technologies and to improve their learning opportunities. These initiatives are supported by the increased funding for all schools announced by the government in the budget. Australia's 10,000 schools will be receiving an additional $167 million in 1996‐97, a five per cent increase in real terms and including a $45 million literacy and numeracy strategy.

ANSWER.PARA: The federal government, through Education Network Australia, has negotiated a breakthrough computer bulk purchasing deal, and this agreement will save Australia's 10,000 schools up to $55 million over the next three years.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?

—There will be a $55 million saving to Australia's 10,000 schools—in addition to the $167 million increased funding in the budget. The bulk purchasing agreement is going to enable schools across the nation to buy computers, Internet modems and other technology hardware at significantly discounted prices. It is estimated that schools will save up to 30 per cent on each purchase, and the cheaper prices are also going to be available to higher education institutions, to training and vocational education institutions as well. It is a breakthrough agreement which allows schools across the nation, particularly small and rural schools, to improve and provide students with the nation's most advanced technologies.

PARA.BREAK: The government's modern Australian apprenticeship and traineeship system will also provide opportunities for young people to gain an education with the highest level of technology. An advanced technology training program will help create and promote apprenticeships in new industries, such as multi media, and other technology based industries. That program is part of a $71 million package to modernise the training system. One of the main roles of the government's new forum of teacher professional associations will be to ensure that teachers have access to professional development opportunities in these new technologies.

ANSWER.PARA: The federal government is committed to ensuring that Australia's school students and apprentices have every opportunity to capitalise on the technology revolution. This is going to be of particular benefit to students in regional Australia. It will provide them with the links that they need to gain an equality of access to information with students in all other schools. Of course, the member for Hotham is interested in regional Australia because he seems to be adopting the Mao strategy of mobilising the countryside and the leaders in the Labor party and then finally targeting the centre. That is what he is on about with his regional strategy. But our regional strategy is going to provide Australian students with the opportunities they have been denied over the last 13 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is again to the Prime Minister. Are you aware that in Victoria—after three years now of big budget surpluses, including the one announced yesterday—the unemployment rate in that state is projected to remain at over eight per cent and that, for the first time in the three years that they have been accumulating those surpluses, the rate of employment growth is itself predicted to drop? Where is the evidence from Victoria—where your ideological soul mates have been running the joint now for three years—that growth destroying and public sector job destroying budgets, such as you have brought down here, contribute anything to unemployment reduction?

—The Deputy Leader of the Opposition is attempting to shift the attention of the Australian public from the simple fact that you ran this country for 13 years—not 13 months, not six months, not five years but 13 years—and you drove unemployment to levels that we have not seen since the years of the Great Depression. I know you do not like it being repeated. But the more questions you ask me, the more opportunities I will have to remind the Australian people that you ran the country for 13 years. You drove unemployment to levels we had not seen for 60 years. You had to go back to the early 1930s to find the levels that Keating produced and you supported in the early 1990s. You left us with a number of very bad legacies, and none was worse than the legacy of high unemployment. Let me make a promise to those sitting opposite that every time you raise the question of unemployment for months and months into the future—
—Tell us your target. More and more people are unemployed.
—Order! I would just like to advise the member for Lyons that he is standing on very thin ice indeed.

—Not even that will divert my train of thought. Through you, Mr Acting Speaker, let me just tell the Deputy Leader of the Opposition that, every time you raise the question of unemployment in this place or elsewhere for months and months into the future, I am going to remind the Australian people that it was your policies—the policies of the defeated Labor government—that drove unemployment to its highest levels since the years of the Great Depression. It was your policies on employment that caused the legacy of high unemployment, which we will only be able to fix when the policies that we were elected on are allowed to be implemented.

—My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Can the Treasurer inform the House why he directed the Development Allowance Authority to not accept further applications under the infrastructure borrowings concession? Can the Treasurer further advise the House whether applications already lodged with the Development Allowance Authority will be affected by this decision?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker, in response to my request, the Development Allowance Authority advised me on 6 Sep tember 1996 that it was assessing applications for infrastructure borrowings of $26.5 billion—many of these received immediately prior to the 1996-97 budget. That was approximately seven times the value of infrastructure borrowings' certificates issued to applicants during the period from 5 March 1995—the date the former Treasurer called for applications for the tax incentive—to 9 September 1996. If all these applications were to be approved, the future costs to the revenue could well exceed $500 million per year.

ANSWER.PARA: The act states that a regulation made before or during the financial year may specify an amount as the intended maximum cost to the Commonwealth for the financial year of taxation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on; somersault, doggie. Woo‐oo‐o!
—The member for Werriwa!

—The maximum amount is $150 million for 1996-97 and $200 million for 1997-98. Following consideration of that advice, which was provided to me on 6 September, I considered that the applications on hand were likely to meet or exceed the maximum amount for 1996-97.
—Woo‐oo‐o!
—If you want to take a trip, the member for Werriwa, you can do it very soon.

—I directed the Development Allowance Authority on 10 September not to accept further applications for infrastructure borrowings after 5 p.m. that day until next year. This is an interim measure to allow a full assessment of the costs to the revenue.

ANSWER.PARA: An indication of the response from industry was the following quotes reported in the Australian Financial Review of 11 September. Mr Nicholas Moore, Executive Director of Macquarie Corporate Finance, is reported to have said that the suspension of applications would be `good on balance, and give the opportunity for cool thinking'. Mr Dennis O'Neill, the Chief Executive of the Australian Council for Infrastructure Development, is reported to have said that the decision was `understandable, and probably quite prudent'. Let me make it clear, Mr Acting Speaker, that this is a direction that is in relation to the current financial year and, at the conclusion of the current financial year, the opportunities will open again in relation to infrastructure bonds.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Prime Minister, given that today's figures demonstrate that you put another 8,000 young Australians out of work last month, what are you going to do to protect the wages of those who are in work? Given that your own budget papers admit that your policies will allow a young, full‐time apprentice to be paid as little as $70.30 per week, will you support an amendment to the workplace relations bill to unequivocally guarantee that youth wages will not be cut?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I just say in reply to the member for Hotham that the reason that the unemployment rate went up this month, despite the increase in jobs, was that it was influenced by the participation rate.
—Oh!
—Could I take a point of order, Mr Acting Speaker, on the question of relevance? My question referred to absolute numbers not affected by the participation rate.
—There is no point of order.

—I do want to say this, through you, Mr Acting Speaker, in reply to the member for Hotham: I repeat that the reason the unemployment rate went up this month, despite the increase in jobs, was that it was influenced by the participation rate which went up by 0.3 per cent. This reflects a healthy labour market. It reflects the fact that at the same time as demand for labour is increasing so is the supply. I say, Mr Acting Speaker, that they were not in fact my words; they were the words of the member for Hotham on 8 December 1994.

ANSWER.PARA: Can I say in response to the member for Hotham that I believe, and all members of the government believe, that the passage of the workplace relations bill, more than any other measure that this government can bring in—

TALK.START.PARA: —What is your target? Young people are suffering.
—I warn the member for Lyons.
—Will be to create those conditions in the labour market which are more likely than any other policy to bring about an improvement in the unemployment rate.
—Could I ask a supplementary question, Mr Acting Speaker? Specifically—
—Wait. I will hear your supplementary question. I remind you of the condition that it must be related to something raised in the answer of the Prime Minister.
—Will he unequivocally guarantee that youth wages won't be cut?
—No, I am sorry; I cannot allow that question.

—Mr Acting Speaker, my question is addressed to the Minister for Health and Family Services. Is the minister aware of the concerns of Australian medical students about the budgetary announcement that Medicare provider numbers will in future be issued only to recognised general practitioners, specialists and those in supervised training? Could the minister please advise the House of the benefits to the Australian health care system of this decision, and outline the career prospects for medical graduates under this new system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I am aware that there is genuine concern amongst medical students at the change, and that is understandable. There are two very substantial benefits to this change. The first is that it will increase the standing of general practice by not allowing it to be an area that just receives people who do not want to go anywhere else. It will increase the quality of general practice. The second thing it will do is it will help constrain the unrestrained growth of Medicare, which is essential for its long‐term viability.

ANSWER.PARA: On the issue of career prospects for medical students that the member raises, I make the following comments. The work of the Australian Medical Council is successful, it is bearing fruit, and we are finding that specialist positions are expanding. There may be up to 600 places next year for specialists, so there will be greater opportunity there than there has been in the past. Secondly, the number of general practice places will be 400, and we are having discussions with the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners to make sure that that training is sufficiently flexible to take into account the needs of women or people who want to have part‐time or interrupted training. Thirdly, a good number of medical students today do not choose to practise clinical medicine on graduation; they may go into academia or administration and will not have a need for a provider number.

In the end, the number of doctors that may miss out, so to speak, will depend on two things: the number of overseas‐trained doctors coming to Australia and medical student intakes. I am very optimistic that this measure will reduce the number of overseas‐trained doctors seeking to come to Australia, something that successive governments have been trying to do for a very long time but have been very unsuccessful about. But I am also optimistic that we might be able to get a reduction in 1997 in medical student intakes.

All that together I think will mean that career prospects are actually very good and far better than many students fear. For the honourable member's information, I am meeting with representatives of medical students and resident trainees from all around Australia next week, and if there are any implementation concerns we will do our best to meet them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker, my question is addressed to the Prime Minister. If, as you claim, no new or existing young workers can be paid less under your workplace relations bill—
—I claim nothing.
—Why have you been forced to introduce a top up for employees?
—In view of the points of order that I have had from your side of the House, I thought I might remind you that I have claimed nothing. Address your remarks through the chair.
—Mr Prime Minister—
—Ha, ha!
—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Mr Prime Minister—
—Ha, ha!
—Order! Members on my right!

—If, as the Prime Minister claims, no new or existing young workers can be paid less under the workplace relations bill, why has the Prime Minister been forced to introduce a top up for employees? Is it because, as the government's budget papers admit, `changes flowing from the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill may result in apprentice and trainee wages falling below the minimum level of unemployment allowance'?
—You are debating your question.
—Isn't it true that the minimum level can be as low as $70.30 per week?
—It is not a question.
—Order! The member for O'Connor.

—Will the Prime Minister fully guarantee that the wage top up is a permanent feature of your government's budgets, or will it only last until the government's next budget? Is that the real reason why the Prime Minister won't support an amendment to the bill to ensure that no new or existing young workers can receive less take‐home pay?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Through you, Mr Acting Speaker, could I say to the member for Batman that if he evinced a real concern about youth unemployment in this country he would do two things. He would accept his own personal direct responsibility as President of the ACTU for the high level of youth unemployment, because it was the award driven, union dominated training approach of the former government that built massive rigidities into the Australian labour market and is one of the reasons why youth unemployment reached levels of 27 and 28 per cent under the government of Paul Keating and Bob Hawke. If you really want a new deal, if you want an arrangement—

—Mr Acting Speaker, I raise a point of order. The Prime Minister was not addressing himself through the chair. I wonder why it is that the Prime Minister and the Treasurer have on occasions up to 10 times not addressed their comments through the chair—
—Order! You do not have to wonder about anything. You have made your point of order. Resume your seat.
—And the member for Batman is the first one you have named in relation to that.
—I warn the member for Wills.

—It is perfectly obvious that the workplace relations approach of the government towards a training and apprenticeship scheme which is going to give to young Australians the prospect of a real job with absolute guarantees against exploitation—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I can only say to those sitting opposite that, if you are really interested in helping young Australians get real jobs, you will vote for our workplace relations bill and leave behind your outdated trade union ideology.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I think a bit of repetition will help the opposition. Will the government's workplace reforms assist young people retain their jobs?

—Order! Resume your seat! He suggested that the opposition needed repetition.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reith, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Acting Speaker. I thank the honourable member for his question. For those of us who have been here for some years and have witnessed at first hand Labor's economic record and the failings of their record, to have them lecturing us by way of a question on unemployment is absolutely incredible. We feel it is bad enough that they oppose measures to fix the problem that they themselves created.

ANSWER.PARA: During question time we have had a number of questions from the opposition about the impact of our workplace relations bill. The reality is that not only are they opposing measures designed to fix the problems that they created but they are also opposing certain provisions that go to the existence or otherwise of junior wage rates. They feign concern about the young unemployed in this country, but the truth is that within the existing Brereton law sitting there like a time bomb waiting to go off is a proposal to abolish junior wage rates, which on the estimates of the Retail Council of Australia could cost of the order of 200,000 jobs for young people out of a total of 285,000 jobs. Not only are they feigning concern about the situation facing young people; in the Senate they are preparing to vote against the proposition that will actually secure the jobs of young people.

As yet another example from the Leader of the Opposition of a public position and a private position which are at variance, I find out today that in meetings earlier this week with certain people between the Leader of the Opposition and the shadow minister for industrial relations they conceded that the abolition of junior wage rates would cost young people jobs. You have conceded that this week because you have privately said to a number of people that you would support an amendment to extend the existing exemption in respect of junior wage rates. It is a matter of some shame that you should be publicly advocating the abolition of junior wage rates but privately admitting that that policy—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker, I draw to your attention standing order 59.
—It is a bit trivial when I have already spoken to the minister.
—Mr Acting Speaker—
—The member for Canberra, who has been most vocal all week, is finally getting up to say something. What is your point of order?

—Mr Acting Speaker, notwithstanding the nature of your invitation, I wish to raise a point of order which goes to the question of relevance. It cannot be a relevant assertion for the minister to be making that remark. That remark is absolutely untrue.

—There is no point of order. Resume your seat. I was about to say to the minister that I would be grateful if he could address his remarks through the chair so as not to excite his colleagues on the left.

—I am very keen for you to be as fully informed as others, Mr Acting Speaker. Here we have a little private cabal to make sure they got the line right. The fact of the matter is that, if we abolish junior wage rates next year in accordance with the Brereton plan, a lot of young people will lose their jobs. Don't you come in here and lecture us about young people's jobs when it is your public position to secure the abolition of junior wage rates that will put a lot of young people onto the unemployment queues.
—Mr Acting Speaker, on a point of order: the minister has continued to defy your instruction on standing order 59.
—Resume your seat.
—Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

If so, would you please explain or advise what actions have been followed. Will the Speaker be pursuing damage claims on behalf of members and senators?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Mr ACTING SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I advise the House that on 4 July the ACT Trades and Labour Council wrote to the Presiding Officers regarding the proposed demonstration at Parliament House on 19 August. On 13 July the Presiding Officers wrote back to the Trades and Labour Council approving their request and imposing four conditions.

ANSWER.PARA: On 3 September 1996 the Presiding Officers wrote to the Trades and Labour Council advising that some conditions had not been met and asking for the payment of $91,000 which was the cost of the damages. Yesterday the President of the Senate was asked a question regarding this and, as a result of that, the Trades and Labour Council of the Australian Capital Territory issued a press release yesterday.

Have final decisions been made about retrenchments or redundancies? If so, will you report to the parliament on the decisions and the implications for the staff of the parliament? Has the matter been reported to and discussed with the House Committee? If not, when do you or the Speaker propose to refer it to the committee? What prior discussions have been had with unions and staff with regard to this matter?
—I thank the honourable member for his question. I am unaware of what action has been taken, but I will certainly investigate it and respond to him.
—Mr Acting Speaker, could you advise the House as to when you expect to announce a date and details of the by‐election for the seat of Lindsay?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Mr ACTING SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for the question. Yesterday, after receiving advice from the Chief Executive and Principal Registrar of the High Court of Australia that the High Court, sitting as the Court of Disputed Returns, had ordered the election for Lindsay held on 2 March 1996 was absolutely void and having received legal advice that the Acting Speaker could exercise the powers of the Speaker in relation to the issue of writs, the Acting Clerk contacted the Australian Electoral Commission with a view to ascertaining appropriate dates for the election which might form the basis for consultation with party leaders and Independent members.

ANSWER.PARA: During discussions with the Electoral Office, it became apparent that there seemed to be an emerging opinion which questioned the right of the Speaker to issue a writ for an election in such circumstances, primarily due to doubt as to whether there was a `vacancy' in the House of Representatives for the purposes of section 33 of the constitution. The House should be aware that, of the five similar circumstances where elections have been declared null and void, the Speaker has issued a writ on four occasions. In the fifth instance, involving Mr Cleary in 1992, the by‐election would have been subsequent to the resignation from the House of Mr Hawke. A writ was not issued in the light of an impending general election, although the Speaker's authority to act after the High Court's decision was not called into question.
Honourable members should be aware that section 33 of the constitution provides:

Whenever a vacancy happens in the House of Representatives, the Speaker shall issue his writ for the election of a new member, or if there is no Speaker or if he is absent from the Commonwealth the Governor‐General in Council may issue the writ.

As the Speaker is currently absent from the Commonwealth on parliamentary business, the Governor‐General in Council may, of course, issue a writ in the present case. However, I repeat that the larger issue is whether the Speaker, if present, would be empowered to issue the writ, as occurred in the past. Moreover, without in any way reflecting on the office of Governor‐General, I believe that the process normally followed in respect of such elections has been appropriate.

Members would be aware that the Speaker, having ascertained from the Electoral Office dates which might be considered, has consulted with the party leaders and Independent members before making a decision. The treatment of the issue is clearly as a parliamentary matter. For the Governor‐General in Council to issue the writ, the decision would be one made by the government.
I have requested that the situation be investigated as a matter or urgency. I will, of course, keep the House informed of future developments in the matter as I become aware of them.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Mr ACTING SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —That's the National Party for you.
