INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Brand (Mr Beazley) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The need for the government to commit itself to targets of employment, particularly in light of the concern arising from today's unemployment data which means that the aspirations of thousands of Australians, and particularly young people, for access to a job is made much more difficult.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley, Kim, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —A very interesting thing happened last weekend. Last weekend we saw a sea change in the government's presentation of its case on the issue of unemployment. This totally poll‐driven government suddenly came to the conclusion that—whilst they felt very satisfied with their budget reception out there—growing, swelling in the community was an understanding and a concern about one thing: whatever they had to say in their budget about all the conceivable public policy issues that interest the average Australian, there was nothing—nothing except a completely bleak outlook—on the question of employment.

SPEECH.PARA: They came to realise what every person in the public knows: you cannot talk about families, you cannot talk about young people and you cannot talk about the needs of people in or out of the work force unless you have one thing at the very centre of your policies. There is no substitute for a job—not any social security payment, not any charitable institution—in keeping people's families together, in keeping people satisfied with themselves and their circumstances, in keeping for people the opportunity of a decent retirement. That, after six months in office, suddenly struck them like a silver bullet.

What did we have immediately after that? We had the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) on every conceivable airwave over the weekend selling a piece of snake oil economic claptrap that, somehow or other, his policies of sacking people, his policies of depriving people of wages, which he says he is not doing, his policies of destroying people's opportunity in the labour market and his policies of destroying people's capacity to get special assistance to get themselves back into the labour market after being long-term unemployed were all amounting to a strategy that would improve our position on employment as time went by.

In question time today the Prime Minister was saying, `Don't blame us for any circumstances in which we find ourselves. We have only been in office for six months.' Indeed you have only been in office for six months. What have we seen since then? From day one, with your stupid propaganda against us, confidence in the business community and amongst consumers has been plummeting. Every measure of consumer confidence and business confidence has been plummeting during that time.

As Australians out there contemplated the fact that our very small Public Service was being made even smaller, as they looked at all the forms of assistance which have ensured that we have had a decent performance from the manufacturing industry over the last 13 years—as all of that was threatened with being carved away—and as they watched all the labour market programs, which go to levering people into decent jobs in our community, go out the window, what Australian employers did, be they state, federal or local employers in small or large businesses, was haul in their expectations and haul in their decisions to employ new people, batten down their hatches, go into their bunkers and knock off jobs.

What was a position of continuing improvement and job growth became a position of despair for so many Australians. The unemployment figures released today are a direct product of what you have been doing over the course of the last six months. There is no escaping them. Better than that, you know there is no escaping them.

We no longer see Senator Vanstone and the minister who will follow me in this debate, the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Dr Kemp), as they were in the first six months of the year out there saying, `Don't worry about unemployment targets. Don't worry about employment. Challenge the figures because the Bureau of Statistics does not really measure these things properly. Let's set up something at NILS and get a bit of advice on how we ought to be looking at unemployment. Forget about these statistics. Forget about the measures, even though the measures are universally approved as the appropriate way to measure unemployment. No, we do not think we will be able to get unemployment below eight per cent before the end of the century because of these huge problems that are upon us.'

That is the rhetoric of the last six months. That rhetoric, which is so in keeping with the intentions in this budget, went out the window last weekend and what we got was snake oil, economic claptrap. It has been exposed by some of those sent out there to produce the earlier statistics. How extraordinary it was to pick up the Sydney Morning Herald and see a report from Professor Wootten who did one of those studies to supposedly come up with a proposition that we ought to take no account of the way in which things have been measured in the past and we have to have a new scenario in relation to what employment opportunities—I will not say `employment targets'—might be.

Professor Wootten had a specific question put to him which was along the lines of the one put to the Prime Minister today who claimed so much about his industrial relations policies. What did he say? He said that over the next four years he did not think the measures would `do anything for unemployment'. For the rest of this century it will not do anything for unemployment. This is one of the government's advocates when in opposition in years past and one of the government's researchers.

The government has been trying desperately over the last six months to get out of the minister's department advice that all the targets that we put up were unachievable, that we should have no targets at all and that really we can live with eight or 10 per cent unemployment. They have not been able to get that out of that department so they went to NILS to get it out of them. What did they get out of NILS? They got a torpedo amidships straight into the heart.

Professor Wootten could be forgiven for going off the theme in that particular context because I bet he had not been advised of the change of lines after the polls over the weekend. They forgot to ring Professor Wootten. They rang round all their spokesmen. They rang Senator Vanstone. She appeared on the 7.30 Report last night. She said, `Forget all the things I have been saying about unemployment, Kerry. We should be able to get unemployment down. If we do not get unemployment down we might not get elected at the next election. Gee, what a thought.'

Poor old Professor Wootten was left hanging out to dry on the previous advice that came forward from the government. He did say that perhaps some time into the distant reaches of the next century we might see things coming out of these industrial relations policies that might actually produce a few jobs. He said that we should not think about anything over the next four years. That is the most comfort you can get from your own advisers in this area.

You are already accountable for the last six months. You are already accountable for these figures. What do we see in the budget? If you do not want to be accountable for these particular figures this month take a look at your budget figures. When we were in office we achieved growth in jobs at the rate of about 200,000‐plus a year for the last four years. What do you say in this budget? You say that we are going to get 125,000 jobs this year. We might by the fourth year, thank you very much, begin to approach in terms of job creation the levels that the Labor government did at a canter over the previous four years.

Your position as far as unemployment is concerned was completely exposed in the budget. If we put in place your industrial relations policies, put in place your budget cuts, put in place measures to sack bucket loads of public servants and put in place your labour market programs, what we will get out of the hat is the rabbit of a rate of growth about half a per cent to one per cent less per annum than was achieved by us. When you pull out that rabbit and put it back you then pull out its twin. The twin has jobs on it. What does the twin say, `This is a rabbit that is about two-thirds the size at best of the previous one that has been operating so effectively in creating jobs over the last four years.'

TALK.START.PARA: —It's a hamster.
—That is right; they pulled out a hamster. They pulled out a hamster for the job growth targets that they put forward.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem with this government is that it has spent 13 years on employment, frozen in aspic. An extraordinary task was imposed on us during our 13 years in office. We absorbed, by creating employment and catering for changes to our institutions and to our labour market programs, an extraordinary sea change in the structure of the Australian labour market. That extraordinary sea change was the admission of women—the majority of women now; it was not the case before—into the work force. That is what we presided over: an extraordinary sea change in the life of Australians.

Those opposite are frozen in aspic because they remain hostile to those women. They do not talk about choice. Let us keep talking about choice. There is no choice in what they are proposing. That is rhetoric. The reality is there is an attack on the capacity of women to stay working. We presided over that sea change. Our job growth was absorbed by that.

The Prime Minister was up today talking about participation rates. He might well talk about participation rates but, if we had had the puny participation rates that he presided over when he was Treasurer, do you know what the maximum figure on unemployment would have been during the 1991 recession? Seven per cent. Do you know what the figure would be now? We would be having an argument with you now, with the last set of figures, about the growth in unemployment from 3½ per cent to four per cent. That is what we would be talking about to you now had it not been for the fact that we had to deal with that massive surge in the participation rate.

You had a puny task; we had a massive task. But let me tell you: you now live with the consequences of that. You have now got to deal with the fact that we have a completely changed basis to our labour market position. But you have got a plus: over the next decade the rate of growth of the Australian labour market, operating at about 2.2 per cent regularly while we were in office, is going to fall to one per cent. We absorbed that enormous increase in our participation rates. Therefore, the task over the next five or six years compared with the task that we confronted is a bagatelle. And, confronting that bagatelle, what do you do? In your own anticipation, you leave unemployment operating at eight per cent to 8½ per cent.

What you will have to understand, because you will see some truly shocking rates for the long-term employed over the next few years, is that one of the other things we had to deal with was the technological change right through the industrialised world that produced a totally new pattern of long-term unemployment. The labour market programs which we put in place—those which you have now dismantled—targeted individual needs in the individual communities in which they operated whilst addressing points of entry into the labour market. It was not based on some broad, general theory; it was what they needed. It is no accident that we were generally regarded in the industrialised world as the most successful devisers of labour market programs. The Working Nation paper, produced by the member for Hotham (Mr Crean) when he was employment minister, was regarded as being exemplary.

BREAK.PARA: Some of the public servants from your department you have been sacking so vigorously over the last few years—

TALK.START.PARA: —Few years?

—Few months. They are going to do quite well outside. They will be going around the region telling people how to set up good labour market programs. They have a marvellous personal economic opportunity. Unfortunately for them, their marvellous personal economic opportunity is not to be replicated by the people whose concerns they once looked after.

BREAK.PARA: You will be judged. Senator Vanstone was absolutely right on one thing: you will be judged on jobs when the next election comes around. Families are not fooled. They are not fooled by budgets which give with one hand and take more with the other. They are not fooled by notions that women ought to get themselves out of the work force so they can get a $9 a week increase in their taxation arrangements or that families should adjust their incomes so they can get a $7 increase. They are not fooled by that. They are not fooled by what is happening in relation to child care. They know that their families need them in work. They know that their families need work. They know that their kids need an opportunity, and they know they will make a judgment about you on whether or not that opportunity is provided.
I think you are just beginning to realise that. Unfortunately for you, you have no mechanism in place to deal with the problem. You are going to experience that wave roll over you. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Dr David, MP

TALKER.NAME: Dr KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training and Minister Assisting the Minister for Finance for Privatisation)

TALK.START.PARA: —Here we are, at the end of the first full sitting week after the budget, and what have we seen? We have seen the worst performance of an opposition in living memory. The opposition have been nothing more than a demoralised rabble over the couple of weeks since the budget was brought down. They have failed utterly to make any credible case whatever against the budget. It is obvious why that is so: about the only person who knows much about the economy and economics is sitting over there on the back bench, and they have a weak opposition leader—

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Laurie Ferguson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are the clever one in the family. You should come and sit down the front here. Swap over with your brother. The opposition have failed to make any credible case against the budget. The reason for that is they have an exceedingly weak opposition leader who has made no satisfactory reply to the budget. We have seen the public reception of that reply. They have treated the opposition's reply to the budget with complete contempt.

SPEECH.PARA: We have a shadow Treasurer who has turned in the worst performance in living memory—the worst performance that I, certainly, can remember—of any shadow Treasurer. The shadow Treasurer (Mr Gareth Evans) has come down from the Senate to the House of Representatives. He did us the honour of joining us here in the House of Representatives so that he could run for the leadership, and now he realises his total irrelevancy, that he is suffering from relevance deprivation syndrome.

What an inspirational message that was to the backbench of the Labor Party! He is saying to his colleagues, `We're all irrelevant now. We're all in opposition.' So we can write off the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) and we can write off the shadow Treasurer. It is obvious that there is no direction coming to the opposition from there.

We have a manager of opposition business who is more interested in numbers than either of them. But the problem is that he is not interested in the numbers in the budget papers; he is interested in the numbers in the party room. He cannot wait to mobilise those numbers first of all against the shadow Treasurer and, I have no doubt, later against the Leader of the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I ask the member for Capricornia to take his dolly out of the House of Representatives.
—There is no point of order.

—But I do not think that the Leader of the Opposition needs to worry too much, because the member for Hotham and Manager of Opposition Business (Mr Crean) could never get any numbers right in government. He certainly does not show much quality in getting the numbers right in opposition. He missed out on the deputy leadership. Whenever he sets a target for himself—whether it be a target in the party room, or a target in the economy with unemployment or a target within his Working Nation program—he never reaches it. That must explain why the Leader of the Opposition is still looking reasonably comfortable.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us have a look at some of these missed targets. We have this most extraordinary hypocrisy being put before the House today that somehow or other the government should take seriously the proposition by the Leader of the Opposition that the government should set targets. What was the record of the opposition when it was in government in achieving targets?

If we look through Working Nation, and we are fortunate to have an evaluation of it, we can see what happened to some of those targets. One of the targets was to reduce the number of people unemployed for 18 months, those in the job compact, by 47 per cent. Despite all the redefinition of the long-term unemployed into the short-term unemployed, the former minister did not even come close to achieving that target. His target was to increase job referrals for the long-term unemployed so as to help them. The fact is that job referrals for the long-term unemployed actually fell by eight per cent.

The Labor Party in government said that it would increase the number of subsidised jobs for unemployed people to 190,000, yet it managed to get only 54 per cent of that target. It said that it would lift the number of women in labour market programs, but women's share of labour market programs actually fell by two per cent.

The fact is that anyone can set shonky targets. But targets do not create jobs; policies which address the fundamentals of the economy create jobs. There was never any chance of Labor achieving the five per cent target. The Manager of Opposition Business in the House has the nerve to get up and say, `Go on, government; set a target. It will create hope.'

He kept talking about the five per cent target. Look how much hope it gave the Australian people. It gave them so much hope that they swept the former government out on a tide of outrage over the failure to put in place policies that had any credibility whatever. The former government had absolutely no chance of achieving that target.

The Manager of Opposition Business in the House referred to a briefing document from the department of education. He told the House that it supposedly says the Labor Party, when it was in power, was on track to achieving five per cent. Nobody reading that document could possibly believe that is what it said. It made no prediction or statement whatever about the state of the labour market in the year 2000. There was no possibility of that target ever being realised and the Australian people knew that. Setting that target did not help the former government. This government is not going to get into the business of setting misleading targets before the people, because it is concerned to emphasise the substance of policies that will actually create real jobs.

We come to the Leader of the Opposition, this man who in grand hypocrisy stands up before this House and says, `You should do what I actually said in government we weren't going to do.' On 30 June 1993, in a speech to the National Press Club, he said:

Our commitment, as a government and as a nation, should not be to any arbitrary unemployment number or rate; our commitment must be to the reduction of unemployment as rapidly and as completely as possible.

That is not an unreasonable statement. He failed completely to put into place the policies that would produce that reduction in unemployment. Unemployment did not come down; unemployment stalled. The fact is that the slowdown in the labour market which is still here as a legacy of the previous government began after April 1995. From April 1995 the whole trend of employment growth began to falter.

BREAK.PARA: In the previous year before that, Paul Keating was pumping money into the economy. He was having one of his last big spending binges, a spending binge that the weak Leader of the Opposition failed to prevent. The Leader of the Opposition was the then Minister for Finance. He could have done something. He probably had private thoughts about what he was going to achieve in the Expenditure Review Committee and how he was going to rein in government spending.

What happened? Paul Keating, the then Prime Minister, just rode right over the top of him and we had another of these big spending budgets. As government spending was pumping up the economy, inevitably on a short-term basis, growth in the year up to April 1995 was 4.6 per cent. In the following 12 months growth was much weaker at 1.2 per cent, because the fundamentals that were necessary to sustain growth and to provide Australians with real job opportunities had not been set in place. So the Leader of the Opposition rejected targets in government and now has the nerve and arrogance to come before this House and say, `We weren't prepared to accept those targets. I never believed in targets; but you should set targets.'

Of course, the Australian people know better. They saw right through the Labor Party when they put themselves up before the election, targets and all—the targets of the member for Hotham but not, as we see, targets that have any credibility with the present Leader of the Opposition. The fact is that the Leader of the Opposition says things now that he was never prepared to say in government. In government he was one of the more reasonable members; he had some reasonable things to say. He told the head of Telstra that he probably supported the full privatisation of Telstra but now, apparently, they do not even support one‐third privatisation.

The Leader of the Opposition said he did not believe in targets but now he says he does believe in targets. The opposition said that we should bring the budget back into balance over three years. Now they say, `We don't believe that is the case any more.' There are people—probably the member for Hotham—pushing him on saying, `Be more aggressive, Kim. Say a few things that will put them on the back foot.' Put us on the back foot indeed!

The government has never looked so strong; it has never had so much support from the people. It has never had so much support from the business community—the people who are going to have to create those jobs—as it has today. The fact is that the opposition has put in a pathetic performance over the two weeks of parliament since the budget. The shadow Treasurer is absolutely fading out at the moment. He was so convinced of his capacity to lead the charge against the government that he left the country.

TALK.START.PARA: —He went to Manila.

—He went to Manila in the two weeks after the budget was brought down. He is fading away and he is an acute embarrassment now to the opposition. Let me just tell the opposition some of the fundamentals they have failed to address. Australia needs savings. What did the opposition do when it was in government? It piled up deficits totalling around $60 billion over five years when the country needed savings. Those deficits were the deficits that the opposition leader as Minister for Finance was too weak to be able to prevent.

BREAK.PARA: If jobs are going to be provided, the fact is that they are going to be provided mainly by small business. What did the Labor Party do? It loaded small business with the unfair dismissals law that made small businesses around this country unwilling to hire full‐time staff. The Leader of the Opposition is living in a dream world. It is almost hallucinatory to hear his talk about job creation under the Labor Party. In the six years from July 1990 to the election how many additional full‐time jobs did the Labor Party create? There were an additional 7,100 full‐time jobs across the whole six years, with unemployment running from a million to about 800,000.

With only 7,100 full‐time jobs it is no wonder this country has an unemployment problem. It is no wonder that today we are seeing such figures. There are two aspects to today's figures that are worth giving some attention to, because the Leader of the Opposition even misrepresented those today. The fact is that there was a growth in employment in these figures and the figures also showed that many people who had been discouraged were flooding back into the labour market in the hope of finding jobs, precisely because they believe this government has a credible approach.

Tragically, at the moment, those jobs are not there because the Labor Party is holding up in the Senate the government's job creating labour market programs. Until the Labor Party is prepared to pass those programs and until Australia is allowed to get the full benefit of the policies that we have put in place—the fair and responsible policies that were brought down in the budget and the fair and responsible policies in the workplace relations legislation—those jobs are not going to come through.

The Labor Party never realised that if young people are going to get jobs they have to be literate and numerate, and they have to get training which leads them to real jobs. At the end of the opposition's term in office, between 10 and 20 per cent of young Australians coming out of primary school did not have adequate literacy or numeracy skills. That was something employers would tell them every time they visited any business—if they ever visited the businesses which were supposed to employ young Australians.

Those opposite spent hundreds of millions of dollars churning young Australians through unemployment programs that did not lead on to real jobs. It is up to this government to solve the problems. We didn't create those problems, but we are going to fix those problems by getting back Australian savings and by bringing the budget into balance. We are going to address the problems of escalating debt that were left by the Labor Party to this country. We have increased spending on young people in crucial literacy and numeracy programs and put into place programs that will give real jobs. That is the difference between the government and the opposition. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Martin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I consider that today in Australia is a day of shame; to think that one‐sixth of the way through what is a normal period of government for the Howard government unemployment has increased from 8.5 per cent to 8.8 per cent. More importantly, the Australian community is concerned because there are 36,000 more unemployed Australians today than there were when the Howard government was first elected on 2 March. But, worse than that, there are 35,000 more unemployed Australians today than there were last month. That is why I consider that if you have any determination in life you ought to be prepared to establish a target and to measure your performance by such a target. That is what life is about.

SPEECH.PARA: I agree with the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone): the major issue confronting the Australian community at the moment is the question of unemployment. The problem is that the Howard government does not regard the question of unemployment as a core issue—despite the fact that during the election campaign the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) went around Australia trumpeting his concern about the issue of unemployment. I refer to the fact that the then Leader of the Opposition, the now Prime Minister, gave 80 speeches during that election campaign—80 speeches, interviews of one kind or another, press statements, et cetera. In more than 50 per cent of those statements and speeches, the Prime Minister tried to lead the Australian public to believe that he was concerned about the issue of unemployment.

Where are we one‐sixth of the way through the term of this Howard government? We are in a situation where 36,000 more Australians are unemployed as a result of the performance of this government. I can understand why the Prime Minister does not regard Senator Vanstone in a very popular light today. The Prime Minister is concerned that Senator Vanstone correctly said last evening on the 7.30 Report that there is one issue and one issue alone that the Australian community is concerned with: the question of unemployment. I will tell you why. The Prime Minister should have listened to that respected economist Dr Chris Caton when he said in the Australian on 19 June this year:

BREAK.PARA: Unemployment, rather than a lower budget or current account deficit was the number one economic problem facing the federal government and that the deficit disease has been overly diagnosed.

Dr Caton was correct. It is about time ministers such as the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott) faced up to the fact that, in representing the people he now looks after—people such as my father, people who were children of the Depression who regarded the postwar reconstruction of Australia and the question of making available decent labour market programs the number one issue then—he ought to be ensuring that their children and grandchildren are given the same opportunities that Ben Chifley gave the people that he now represents—the children of the Depression who went away to fight in the Second World War.

The real problem is that the Howard government are seeking to ensure that the Costello con, on the basis on which the budget is based, is perpetrated throughout the Australian economy. They like to talk about records. What was John Howard's record when he left office? I know he likes to forget this record. It was a legacy of spiralling underlying inflation of 10.5 per cent, an unemployment rate of 10 per cent and massive industrial turmoil.

As the former President of the ACTU, I am pleased to say that we faced up to our responsibilities to come to terms with a legacy of inaction and, if anything, we are fighting to accept responsibility for the key issues that confronted Australia prior to 1983—the issues of unemployment, the issues of inflation and the question of a willingness by working people to sit down and cooperate and work with the business community. Let us consider the record: an inflation rate of 2.5 per cent and the lowest level of industrial disputation in this country since 1940.

Those opposite want to talk about the question of jobs. I remind this House that we were prepared to set ourselves targets and seek to achieve those targets by one important ingredient—sitting down and working with the Australian community. Our approach to government in Australia is that it is one nation. There is an obligation on this government, an obligation on this parliament, to work with all sections of the Australian community. That is what the concept of one nation is all about—irrespective of where you live, irrespective of your background, irrespective of your level of income, irrespective of your gender, irrespective of whether you are an indigenous person or a person of a non-English speaking background.

The role of government is to intervene and assist; the role of government is to go out of its way to ensure that our primary concerns are met. Our primary concern—unlike what the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, the member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp), understands at the moment—is jobs. We established a target in 1993. Not only did we establish a target; the government of the day was given a mandate to implement that target. Our target was to create 500,000 jobs. We were also prepared to risk establishing the target in 1996 of 600,000 jobs. What was the record of government for the period 1993-96? It was in excess of 700,000 jobs.

The problem is that the first Howard budget is a no jobs budget. The minister for education likes to talk about the importance of small business. I, like the minister, regard small business as being very important for the purposes of job creation in this community. I would also like to remind the minister of what his departmental briefing was on accepting responsibilities. That departmental briefing states:
Yes, small business is important.
But it also says in black and white, in no uncertain terms:
Unless large business manufacturing employment also picks up . . .

You know large business: those business operations that you have taken all industry support away from not only in metropolitan Australia but also in regional Australia in the manufacturing industry and service industry—the growth industries of Australian employment. It then went on to say:
However, the increase in small business manufacturing employment required to achieve 200,000 job targets for the manufacturing industry as a whole would be very substantial.

Unlike the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Tim Fischer), I do not regard labour market pro grams as tiddlywinks jobs programs. I urge the Deputy Prime Minister, the minister for education and the member for Goldstein to get out in Australia, to sit down and talk to people who have benefited from these programs. Go to Ballarat. Go and talk to the clothing worker I spoke to in Ballarat last week at the training Skillshare centre. She was getting a labour market program opportunity then because of the TCF restructuring program that we put in place. The problem is that in the Howard budget that TCF program was knocked off in no uncertain terms at a time of exceptional need.

Let us go to Victoria—the minister's home state. In Ballarat, 31 jobs have gone from Oliver and Stevens Footwear; in Bendigo, 54 jobs have gone from Argos Clothing and ADI; in Horsham, 120 jobs have gone from Holeproof; in Thornbury, a town in my electorate, 240 jobs have gone from Clarks Shoes; in Preston, 106 jobs have gone from Windsor shoes. This government suggests that we do not need decent labour market programs.

The minister ought to go to Rockhampton and talk to the city council, talk to the local Skillshare centre, talk to the local community, talk to the churches, talk to the Red Cross and talk to the Country Women's Association. All those groups and associations have benefited from Working Nation and I will tell you why—it is because they put resources into the local community. Those resources have enabled the establishment of the infrastructure that was necessary in the local community, including the Moore Creek restoration program and the heritage village in Rockhampton. They are the types of programs that gave the long-term unemployed a second opportunity in life.

I will tell you what the real problem is today. The Lindsay electorate needs to send this government the message that, one-sixth of the way into the term of its first government, it ought to front up to its responsibilities. It ought to front up to the fact that there is one issue and one issue alone that those electors care about at the moment—they care about their kids' future, they care about their grandchildren's future and, in some instances, they care about their mums' and dads' future. They care about jobs.

Government members ought to go out and talk to them. Go to the Mamre's Skillshare centre at St Mary's and sit down and talk to those Sisters of Mercy. Sit down and talk about the benefits of Working Nation. I consider that the coalition policy is a pathway to unemployment. That is what it is—a pathway to unemployment. There are 35,000 more unemployed this month. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew, Neil, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to participate in this debate because it is time people on both sides of this parliament recognised that, so long as there are 850,000 unemployed people out there, all the debate will be about is empty words and empty rhetoric. I am heartily sick of the nonsense dished up by the member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson) and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley), who have both suggested that there were 500,000 new jobs created under their government. Even if that were true, I would like the member for Batman to tell me why it is that unemployment under your government and under us for the last five months has continued to rise.

SPEECH.PARA: Fundamentally, none of us stand here with clean hands. It is all very well for the member for Batman to scurry from the chamber when the direction of the debate no longer suits him. The simple reality is that he has nothing to be proud of. The figures that we are concerned about today are figures that we as the government inherited from the opposition when they were in government.

There is no room for passing judgment in this debate. There is no room for people to stand up and say, `Look how well we've done and how poorly you've done.' There is no room for the former government to come in here and suggest that, in some magic way, they set and met a target that solved unemployment. That is nonsense, and the figures today reinforce the fact that that is nonsense. All that the previous government endeavoured to do in its job creation strategy clearly failed. Today's figures are grim testament to the failure of the previous government and its job creation strategy.

BREAK.PARA: Members of the previous government expect us to stand here and apologise, when we have scarcely been in government long enough to get the seat warm, and certainly not long enough to bring into practice the very policies we want to use to address unemployment. On top of that, we are frustrated by another chamber that does not recognise the challenge that we recognised before we came into government and have attempted to address. There is no sense of respectability or responsibility in any of the debate that has come from the opposition benches today on this subject of unemployment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or humility.

—Or humility, as my colleague says. It is inexcusable for anyone, in the face of what is crippling unemployment across this nation, to come in here and say, `This is not our fault; it's yours.' I cannot believe that my colleagues on the opposition benches would be so damnably callous towards the unemployed.

BREAK.PARA: The simple reality is that it does not matter whose fault it is. There is a real problem that needs to be addressed, and all of the evidence staring us in the face shows us that the techniques used to address that problem over the last 13 years have failed miserably. The coalition are about doing something about unemployment. We are being frustrated by not having a majority in the second chamber, so the things that we know must happen have not happened. But we are about doing something about it, and the budget handed down by the Treasurer (Mr Costello) last month was the first step in addressing the problem of unemployment.

What did the Treasurer propose? First of all, he proposed to rub out the deficit. Those opposite will say, `Oh, dear me. All you worry about is dollars and the state of the economy, not the state of the unemployed.' If I do not worry about the state of the economy, I create an impossible position for job creation in Australia. So we recognise our first obligation, which is to take a step towards balancing the books so that Australian small businesses and Australian investors—even overseas investors, dare I suggest—will say, `This is a nation we want to invest in,' and in the process will create some job opportunities.

The member for Batman came in and suggested that the minister at the table, the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Dr Kemp), had said that this was not a core issue. What an affront that must have been to the minister, who has spent his life endeavouring to find ways to get the young unemployed and the long-term unemployed off those queues and into jobs. What the member for Batman needs to realise is that this side of the House is full of people who have had experiences as both employees and employers and know something about what is needed to bring the two together.

What members of the opposition never recognise is the problem every employer faces when he or she has job opportunities that need to be filled. Those employers fear filling them because of the possible consequences of a necessary dismissal that will be treated as unfair. I have employers who want to employ people but refuse to put them on because the current unfair dismissal laws discourage them from doing so. We are about doing something about that, but we are being frustrated in the other chamber.

My phone rings almost as frequently with employers with job opportunities as it does with unemployed people seeking work. What does that tell you? It tells you that there are jobs out there waiting to be filled and there are some young people not prepared to fill them. That means that we need to look at the way in which we encourage young people to make themselves available for work.

Much was made by members of the opposition in this debate of what they saw as their proud record and what they saw as the Labor Party's proud record. The name of Ben Chifley was dragged into the debate as if all that was white in employment terms rested with the opposition and all that was black with the government. Statistically that is not right; emotionally that is not right. There is no defence for that sort of jaundiced approach to Australia's employment history. The reality is that the coalition has as much to be proud of in its job creation record—and I am being generous because, in fact, we have more to be proud of statistically—as the opposition. Yet none of that has been recognised in any of the debate that has occurred this afternoon.

Does the opposition genuinely believe that this side of the parliament—made up, as I said, of employers and employees—is not aware of the dilemmas that employers face and of the frustrations that employees face? Do you think that we are not aware of part of the solution which, in a society such as ours in which manual work is disappearing, means that we need to apply some imagination to find new job opportunities? We are about it.

We recognise that new job opportunities will be created when we encourage more job-sharing. We recognise that there is no shortage of Australians with two-income families where both partners, for example, are over 50 years of age and saying, `We would be very happy with an income and a half instead of two incomes. We would be very happy to create another opportunity for another Australian to be employed.'

We could do so if the more flexible industrial relations policies of the Liberal and National parties applied. But, oh no, we must not tamper with industrial relations policy; we must not introduce more flexibility that would allow that sort of job-sharing and create more job opportunities. If anyone should stand condemned for today's unemployment figures, it is those who were so recently on this side of the House, those who had the opportunity to do the very things we would have encouraged, but they refused to bite the bullet. Here we stand, prepared to have a more flexible labour market, prepared to encourage employers to take on employees; and here we stand, frustrated by the actions of the ALP in the other chamber.

Much was made of labour market programs and of what was alleged to be the failure of the new government to deliver effective labour market programs. In common with a range of people in this parliament, I have had a good deal to do with labour market programs and new work opportunity schemes. I can tell you they were great for the former government, running into the last election, to temporarily reduce unemployment figures and so talk up the state of affairs for them. But in terms of creating any full-time jobs—not a chance.

We are not about mickey mouse schemes, not about new work programs that I encouraged in my electorate because it made me look good; we are about full-time job opportunities as a result of labour market programs that mirror apprenticeships. We have nothing to apologise for. We stand for real jobs; we stand for reducing the unemployment queues; and we stand for giving unemployed young people and the long-term unemployed a new opportunity.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (BUDGET AND OTHER MEASURES) BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Ruddock, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock, Philip, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr RUDDOCK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the bill be now read a second time.

This bill introduces many initiatives affecting the social security portfolio that were announced either as part of the government's 1996 election commitments or as part of the 1996 budget. The government made election commitments to carers. It is now proposed to give effect to these commitments by changing the name of the carer pension to the carer payment and by extending from 10 to 20 hours per week the number of hours that carers may spend in employment, voluntary work, education or training without affecting their qualification for carer payment. There will also be an increase in the number of days in a calendar year, from 42 to 52 days a year, that a carer may temporarily cease caring without affecting their qualification for carer payment. These initiatives will commence on 1 July 1997.

At the moment, youth training and sickness allowees receive a rate of $65.75 a fortnight, even if their parents' income and assets would have otherwise either resulted in a lower rate or precluded them from payment. The bill provides for the abolition from 1 January 1997 of this minimum payment for customers aged under 18. The parental income test will then be applied to determine the actual rate of payment. This will ensure that there is a more consistent payment structure for youth, as there is no such minimum for Austudy recipients.

The Social Security Act 1991 and the Student and Youth Assistance Act 1973 will be amended from 20 September 1997 to consolidate and simplify voluntary work provisions in those acts. A person aged 50 and over, who is not subject to an activity agreement, will be able to satisfy the newstart allowance activity test by undertaking approved full‐time unpaid voluntary work for an approved organisation for an unlimited number of days per year for at least 32 hours in a fortnightly period or by a combination of unpaid voluntary work with an approved organisation and suitable paid work for at least 40 hours in a fortnightly period.

Similarly a person aged under 50 who is not subject to an activity agreement and who has received income support for at least three months will be able to satisfy the activity test by undertaking full‐time voluntary work with an approved organisation for six fortnights in their first 12 months of income support. A person will still be required to be available and willing to undertake suitable paid work.

BREAK.PARA: Mr Deputy Speaker, the government made an election commitment to improve and tighten administration of the activity test for unemployment payments. This commitment was made in response to community concerns that only those people who are genuinely unemployed and actively seeking to participate in the work force should receive payment. The measures contained in this bill seek, as part of a wider package of initiatives, to increase community support for assistance to the unemployed by enhancing the integrity of the program.

The measures will tighten the definition of `unsuitable paid work' for job seekers, change the non‐payment period for activity test breaches, replace the current deferment period arrangements for administrative breaches with rate reduction provisions, tighten activity test breach provisions relating to voluntary unemployment and refusal of a job offer, reclassify certain breaches as activity test breaches, extend the non‐payment period for moving to an area of lower employment prospects from 12 to 26 weeks and clarify the operation of the employer contact certificate provisions.

In addition, amendments are included in the bill to change the industrial action provisions in the Social Security Act and the Student and Youth Assistance Act to ensure that where a person is unemployed as a result of industrial action the person will remain disqualified for payment for six weeks after the industrial action has ceased.These measures relating to the unemployed will commence on 1 January 1997.

Mr Deputy Speaker, the bill also contains two discrete measures dealing with waiting periods to be implemented from 20 September 1997. First, the unused annual leave waiting period will be abolished and replaced with an income maintenance period. The new income maintenance period rules will ensure that leave payments are treated as income from the date of payment over a period equal to that for which the leave refers and apply to newstart, sickness, partner, widow and parenting allowances. Secondly, the maximum length of the liquid assets test waiting period, which applies to claimants of newstart allowance, youth training allowance and sickness allowance, will be extended to 13 weeks and will be variable depending upon the person's available funds.

Mr Deputy Speaker, the bill gives effect, from 20 March 1997, to a number of measures relating to people who are sick and who claim, or are receiving, certain social security payments.A 14‐day grace period will be introduced so as to allow a person to renew qualification for sickness allowance, or to renew exemption from the newstart or youth training allowance activity tests, through providing the necessary medical certificate after the expiry of the person's previous medical certificate.

The sickness allowance qualification rules will be amended by removing the loss of income qualification. Also to be amended are the sickness allowance qualification rules and newstart allowance and youth training allowance activity test exemption rules so that the sole criterion for the continuation of sickness allowance, or exemption from the newstart or youth training allowance activity test, will be a continuing temporary incapacity for work.

Lastly, backdating of disability support pension, newstart allowance, sickness allowance and youth training allowance will be permitted through the deemed earlier date of lodgment of a claim in circumstances where a sick or disabled person makes a telephone inquiry about claiming payment and then lodges a claim formally and qualifies for payment.

Due to its conceptual and procedural complexity, the earnings credit scheme is difficult to administer and is also difficult for social security recipients to understand. The limited understanding of the scheme by social security recipients puts in doubt its value as a significant incentive to take up casual work opportunities. Given this, as well as the relatively high costs involved in the administration of the scheme, the government has decided to abolish the earnings credit scheme in respect of both pensions and benefits.

Mr Deputy Speaker, the bill introduces amendments to abolish the earnings credit scheme from 20 March 1997. The government has also decided to abolish the employment entry payment from 20 March 1997 and the education entry payment for all but certain pensioners from that date.

Provisions for assistance to widows and partners were reviewed in the 1996 budget context in response to the need to develop a more rational and integrated social security system, simplify the payment structure and improve services to customers. As a result, the bill gives effect to a number of measures designed to provide common payment conditions for older women without recent work force experience who either are a dependent partner or who lose the support of a partner later in life, as well as ensuring common payment arrangements when customers attain age pension age.

First, qualification for widow allowance will be extended to women who are aged at least 50 years of age and who were widowed, divorced or separated after turning 40 years of age. Secondly, conditions of payment of widow allowance and partner allowance will be aligned, including common phase‐out arrangements, a common definition of recent work force experience and common access to ancillary payments.

Thirdly, qualification for partner allowance will be extended to Austudy, Abstudy and student financial supplement scheme partners. Fourthly, there will be an earlier phase‐out of widow B pension such that there will be no new entrants to this payment and by automatically transferring widow B pensioners of age pension age to age pension.

Finally, arrangements for customers of age pension age will be rationalised by no longer granting widow allowance and partner allowance to people of age pension age and by automatically transferring widow, partner and mature age allowance recipients attaining age pension age to age pension. These measures are to be implemented from 20 March 1997.

Mr Deputy Speaker, the bill provides for the assessment processes for disability support pension to be tightened to ensure that those people whose impairments have only a relatively small impact on their overall ability to work will not qualify for that pension. Rather, they will receive a more appropriate income support payment. To assist in this process, revised impairment tables, which are used to assess whether a person's impairment is 20 per cent or more, are being introduced from 1 January 1997.

The government decided in the 1996 budget to limit payment of child disability allowance arrears to a period of up to three months where a person has made an earlier claim for a payment similar to child disability allowance and was qualified to receive child disability allowance at the time of this earlier claim. Currently, child disability allowance arrears of up to 12 months may be paid in such circumstances. The bill gives effect to that decision from 1 January 1997 and will result in child disability allowance being treated consistently with other social security payments.

Mr Deputy Speaker, the bill provides for the amendment of the compensation recovery provisions of the Social Security Act so as to include age pension as a compensation affected payment. The proposal will only apply to age pensioners who receive compensation for economic loss. Age pensioners who receive compensation for non‐economic loss only will not be affected. The proposal will only affect an age pension if the compensation is received on or after 20 March 1997 and the person's provisional commencement date for age pension is on or after 20 March 1997.

The compensation recovery provisions of both the Social Security Act and the Student and Youth Assistance Act will also be amended from 20 March 1997 to enhance the treatment of lump sum compensation payments by using a single pension cut‐out point as the compensation lump sum preclusion period divisor.

For compensation lump sum payments received on or after 20 March 1997, the divisor used to calculate preclusion periods will be changed from the all persons average weekly earnings to the amount above which no pension is payable to a single person under the income test, currently $397 a week. Further, the preclusion period will be applied to the compensation recipient only and not to his or her partner. This means that for lump sums received on or after 20 March 1997, recovery of past payments to partners will not be made, nor will partners be precluded from receiving any future entitlement they may have during their partner's preclusion period. The existing rules will apply in respect of those compensation lump sum payments received before 20 March 1997.
The bill also includes a number of amendments to the Student and Youth Assistance Act so as to align the compensation provisions of that act with corresponding provisions in the Social Security Act.

Mr Deputy Speaker, the bill includes a number of amendments that are designed to improve the targeting of non‐cash assistance to retirees and low income earners, restore equity by preventing cards being given to people otherwise not entitled and simplify card administration.

The health benefits card will be abolished and health care cards will be issued to sickness allowees. The `savings provisions' that allow people receiving family allowance supplement prior to January 1992 to receive a health care card will be repealed. These people will now have to test their eligibility under the normal four‐weekly income test. Similarly, the modified income test and savings provisions that allow certain social security pensioners to receive concession cards after cancellation of pension will be repealed. These measures will take effect on 1 July 1997.

The bill provides for the removal of the concessional treatment applied to `deposit concession money', as defined in the Social Security Act and the Student and Youth Assistance Act, from 20 March 1997. As a result, the `below threshold rate' of extended deeming will apply to the first $2,000 of available money or deposit money of a person other than a person who is a member of a `pensioner couple' as defined in the Social Security Act. The `below threshold rate' will also apply in all cases to the first $4,000 of available money or deposit money of a `pensioner couple'.

Mr Deputy Speaker, the Social Security Act and the Student and Youth Assistance Act will be amended, from 1 October 1997, to provide for recovery of social security payments that have been paid to persons in excess of their correct entitlement but which are not currently recoverable as debts. In addition, where possible, the debt creation provisions will be rationalised.

The recovery of overpayments will occur according to the means of a person to pay. This will improve equity between customers, some of whom are now able to retain more than their correct entitlement even though they have ample capacity to repay, while others with limited finances are obliged to repay their debts.

Finally, Mr Deputy Speaker, the bill provides for the modification of the advance payment scheme for recipients of social security entitlements. The modifications include removal of a `permitted purpose' as a qualification requirement for an advance payment, reduction of the maximum advance amount to $500 and restriction of the number of advances payable to a person to one advance in 12 months. This measure will take effect on 1 January 1997.
I commend the bill to the House. I also present the explanatory memorandum in relation to the bill.
Debate (on motion by Ms Macklin) adjourned.

BREAK.PARA: 47C Meaning of unacceptable cross-ownership situation

PARA.TAB: For the purposes of this Act, an unacceptable cross-ownership situation exists in relation to a pair of airport-operator companies (the first company and the second company ) and in relation to a particular person if:
(a) the person holds a particular type of stake in the first company of more than 15%; and
(b) the person holds any type of stake in the second company of more than 15%.
Note: A person's stake includes the interests of the person's associates—see the Schedule.

TAB.TAB: 47D Acquisitions of shares

PARA.TAB: If:
(a) a person, or 2 or more persons under an arrangement, acquire shares in a company; and
(b) the acquisition has the result, in relation to a particular pair of airport-operator companies (the first company and the second company ), that:

TAB.TAB: (i) an unacceptable cross-ownership situation comes into existence in relation to the pair and in relation to a person; or

(ii) if an unacceptable cross-ownership situation already exists in relation to the pair and in relation to a particular person—there is an increase in any type of stake held by the person in either the first company or the second company; and

PARA.TAB: (c) the person or persons mentioned in paragraph (a) knew, or were reckless as to whether, the acquisition would have that result;

BREAK.PARA: the person or persons mentioned in paragraph (a) are guilty of an offence punishable on conviction by a fine not exceeding 400 penalty units.
(1) A member of a pair of airport-operator companies must take all reasonable steps to ensure that an unacceptable cross-ownership situation does not exist in relation to that pair.
(2) A company that knowingly or recklessly contravenes subsection (1) is guilty of an offence punishable on conviction by a fine not exceeding 500 penalty units.

(1) If an unacceptable cross-ownership situation exists in relation to a pair of airport-operator companies, the Federal Court may, on application by the Minister or a member of the pair, make such orders as the court considers appropriate for the purpose of ensuring that the situation ceases to exist.

PARA.TAB: (a) an order directing the disposal of shares; or

(d) an order that any exercise of rights attached to shares be disregarded.
