SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr SHARP
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the amendments be agreed to.

The government is pleased to see back in the House the Airports Bill 1996 and the Airports (Transitional) Bill 1996 in substantially the same form as was proposed to this House. I believe it is a strong endorsement of the overall approach of the government to allow private capital and innovation to support the provision of essential infrastructure in this country.

There is no doubt that the Federal Airports Corporation has done an excellent job both in developing Commonwealth airports to the point where they provide a very healthy level of non‐aviation revenue supporting the cost of providing airport infrastructure, and in cross‐subsidising between airports to ensure that each Commonwealth facility has a good standard of passenger facilities.

The next stage of developing these airports is to remove the constraints to pricing and investment created by the network cross‐subsidies and to allow each airport to reflect the aspirations and the economics of its location. I expect that the sales process will now move into high gear and we can expect to see substantial activity from bidders and their consortiums and speculation about favoured parties.

My colleague the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey) has established sale conditions and outlined recently the open and transparent process to be followed. He has also noted that the Australian National Audit Office will be involved in assessing the performance of the process after the event. All expectations of airport owners and requirements of the bidding process will be established clearly in advance of the process commencing. Part of the clarity that we are providing the bidders and airport users is included in the bills under consideration this afternoon.

BREAK.PARA: The government has itself put forward some amendments to ensure effective cross‐ownership restrictions between Sydney and the first phase airports—a matter which I foreshadowed as possible in my comments when the bills were last before the House. I am pleased that these have been accepted by the Senate. We also gave close consideration to the amendments proposed by the Greens. I note with some pride that the government did not resist many of them.

Indeed, there has been a very helpful and positive exchange between us on environmental matters. The government always intended a strong environmental regulation regime to apply at airports. Indeed, by comparison with the environmental regime on airports which existed under our predecessors, this government has moved light years ahead of the Labor Party. So, in many areas, the Greens' amendments reflected things that we intended to do as a matter of course under the environmental management plan or environment regulations, both of which are to follow from the Airports Bill.

The government will accept the bill as amended. It is a matter of no little significance that the legislation to reform the investment in and the development of airports in Australia is one of the first pieces of legislation to pass under this government. May this herald a continuing stream of transport reforms from my portfolio.

In conclusion, I thank all those people who have contributed to the debate, particularly Senator Tambling, my parliamentary secretary, who handled a great deal of the debate in the Senate on my behalf.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tanner, Lindsay, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition is not opposing the amendments to the Airports Bill 1996 and the Airports (Transitional) Bill 1996. The bulk of them are amendments that the opposition proposed in the House. They were defeated then but subsequently were agreed to by the government in the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to make some comments on some of the matters contained in those amendments. Firstly, with respect to the cross‐ownership rules, we have had the last minute insertion of Perth. That has amused many of us. Obviously, it means that the Premier of Western Australia has been asleep or out of touch with what is going on in the world.

The Premier of Victoria was running around on the question of the cross‐ownership rules for some time, as were many other people. But, apparently, Richard Court has just woken up to the fact that the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) is selling his airport and that he had better do something about it. So he got on the phone and said, `Hey, I want some cross‐ownership protection as well.'

That says a considerable amount about Richard Court's awareness of what is going on around him. It also raises the question of how much muscle Dean Brown has. Why isn't Adelaide in there as well? Maybe Tony Rundle should be asked the same question. It also indicates that the state branches and state governments still run the Liberal Party and the coalition and that, if they say jump, the federal government is going to ask how high.

It also indicates—I am sure that the minister will be pleased to hear me say this, although he will not admit it—that the Treasurer (Mr Costello) has been an absolute pushover on all of this. Originally, the Treasurer rolled the minister in the cabinet on this question and managed to have no cross‐ownership rules at all. Then his arch enemy, the Premier of Victoria, got into the act. We indicated that we would be opposing it in the Senate, and the government got a bit worried. So the Treasurer was pushed back to the position that prevailed in the previous legislation that the Labor government put forward.

Now, as a result of a phone call from Richard Court, the Treasurer has been pushed back even further. The worry is that the total return from the sales to revenue will be diminished accordingly. I am also concerned to make sure that this is not some sort of shonky exercise designed to assist some local mates of Richard Court who have their eyes on the airport and would like to reduce competition for it. I urge the minister to pay very close attention to the sale process of Perth airport as a result.

The other comments I would like to make relate to the situation in regional ports. It is unfortunate that no emphasis has been placed on ensuring local ownership of regional ports. It is also unfortunate that there is no provision for ensuring full competition with respect to general aviation as between ports, particularly in the major cities. It is possible, for example, to have one owner for all the airports conducting general aviation activities in Sydney and Melbourne, which means that the potential for competition will be minimal.

I also have a number of concerns on the sale process. Some of those concerns were addressed in a letter to me from the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey) in recent times. But I have a number of outstanding concerns, particularly with the pricing regime and various aspects of disclosure.

The minister has indicated that he will tell the bidders what the tendering requirements will be but he has not indicated whether anybody else, such as the parliament, will be told. It is incumbent upon the minister to indicate to the parliament precisely what the bidding regime will be, what requirements will be placed on bidders and what information will be required.

He should also be telling us what the basis of the pricing regulation is going to be, what the commencement point will be. Will it be the current price? Will it be the intended increased price that the FAC is seeking? Where will the base be for CPI minus X? That is something that we still have not determined. There are a number of other matters that I would like to see clarified. I have recently written to the Minister for Finance on this matter and I would sincerely hope that he responds to my letter as quickly as he did to my first letter. Although the fact that my current letter has not got a run in the Financial Review might slow him down a bit.

I turn to our overall position relating to cross‐ownership rules and to the sale. As I have indicated, the opposition does not have a problem with the insertion of the cross-ownership rules and does not oppose the insertion of Perth, although it does ask some questions about the distinction with Perth—why Perth should be in there while Adelaide is not, and what the reason is for putting it in the cross‐ownership provisions at the last moment, as has occurred.

This really does raise some questions about the minister's control over the whole process and the extent to which he has been consulting with affected parties. Are we to believe that Richard Court has been completely unaware of these issues—that he has no idea that the airport is going to be sold and that he has only just discovered that there are some concerns for Perth that he needs to address? Or is it the case that the minister has failed to consult adequately with state governments and other interested parties? I do not know the answer; I would be interested to know it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr SHARP
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will respond to the comments by the shadow minister for transport. I thank him for the support he is offering for the passage of the Airports Bill and also for the support in the Senate. He made a couple of points in his remarks, some of which he made clear have been addressed in correspondence he has had with the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey). Of course, it is the Minister for Finance who is now responsible for the asset sales task force which will be handling the actual sale of these airports—or the long-term lease, to be more correct.

SPEECH.PARA: The shadow minister raised a couple of points which were also raised in the Senate earlier today by Senator Collins. They go to why Mr Court suddenly showed an interest in this matter. I will recount the history of the matter. A Senate committee, chaired by Senator Winston Crane, held a hearing some time back at which the Western Australians raised the issue of some cross-ownership provisions. We took the opportunity to consider that matter. Consultations had been undertaken with the various state Premiers—Mr Court in Western Australia, Mr Brown in South Australia and Mr Rundle in Tasmania. Mr Court was interested in having some cross-ownership provisions apply in the bill. Neither Mr Brown nor Mr Rundle felt it was appropriate for their states.

So what we have done in this bill is simply try to reflect the interests and concerns of those people who raised the cross-ownership arrangements in the Senate hearings and also to reflect the interests and concerns of those premiers whom the government has consulted. That is the reason for the cross-ownership provisions introduced into the Senate today. Of course, the shadow minister would know that we did introduce cross-ownership provisions for Sydney and Brisbane and Sydney and Melbourne which reflected to a great degree the cross-ownership provisions which the previous government had introduced in the legislation they brought into the parliament. The desire to introduce that reflected the content of the debate that we had here in the House of Representatives the last time we discussed this matter.

It is greatly unfair to try to paint Mr Court as not being on the job. I can assure you that Mr Court has been on the job for a considerable amount of time in regard to this issue. He has been following due process and has been properly consulted, and his concerns have been reflected in the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tanner, Lindsay, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —And he no doubt likes little children as well. I want to follow up on the comments of the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) with a couple of other matters relating to the amendments. I am taking the liberty to do so as we are dealing with the amendments in globo. With respect to the process of sale, I would be interested in receiving further information on—I have written to the Minister for Finance about these matters—who is going to be consulted about the content of regulations governing airport operations. The Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey) indicated in his letter to me that there would be consultation about this issue, but he did not say who would be consulted.

SPEECH.PARA: Further, what guarantees will be given that, once the regulatory regime is established, it will not be subsequently fiddled with to favour the interests of a particular successful bidder or group of bidders? That is something that, as I have indicated elsewhere, is a particular concern given the outrageous things that have happened in the tendering process with the casino in Victoria. In that case we have seen Hudson Conway have a range of subsequent changes made to the regulations governing the operation of the casino to allow it to expand substantially. Of course, these opportunities were not available to the losing bidder at the time that the original tender was called. I am very concerned to ensure that the same sort of thing does not occur with the airport tendering process, particularly given that we have a variety of international interests involved. It would be a disaster for Australia's reputation internationally.

Additionally, how will a pricing regime be managed if an airport operator seeks to change the basis of aeronautical charges? It is a bit hard to apply CPI minus X if at some time an operator comes along and says, `We now want to charge per passenger' or per something other than maximum take‐off weight.

The second matter I would like to refer to quickly is the question of environmental issues. It is rather ironic that the minister should make some play of having done rather well with the Greens. Of course, the matters he refers to are also matters that ALP senators supported, with one exception which the government did not support—and I will refer to that in a minute. It is rather ironic when you consider what is going on with the proposal at Holsworthy, which clearly is environmentally crazy. It is right next to the Woronora dam and is part of the Woronora catchment area. It is adjacent to a national park. There are serious noise problems for people who were assured—as I indicated in my adjournment speech last night with respect to a sale of land by the Defence Housing Authority—as late as only a fortnight before the minister indicated that Holsworthy would be looked at as an airport site, that there was not going to be any airport there. There are also deficiencies in the EIS process. So it does not behove the minister all that well to try to parade in green clothing when it comes to airports when we consider what is going on with Holsworthy.

PARA.BREAK: I think it is also worth noting the delay, which has finally been demonstrated in the budget papers, that the Holsworthy option is causing in finding a solution for the construction of a second airport, which is clearly necessary to solve the problems with Kings ford‐Smith. The $73 million provided for in our forward estimates in the previous budget has been taken out of this year's budget and not replaced in subsequent forward estimates.

SPEECH.PARA: My final comment relates to the amendment that the Greens moved and which had Labor support but which was unsuccessful. I simply clarify that that amendment would have expanded the area of consultation for airport owners and required them to actually make statements in their airport master plans as to how they proposed to deal with noise problems up to the area of 20 ANEF, which is much broader than the 30 ANEF band which was ultimately adopted.

To be fair to Senator Tambling, I point out that he correctly stated that this would potentially place excessive pressure on future owners to insulate houses as far afield as the 20 ANEF band. He did not state explicitly that this would cost $1 billion to $2 billion. He did say that if the worst possible outcome occurred and they caved into this pressure that is what would have occurred. This has been reported and interpreted as meaning that the Greens' amendment, which we supported, would have added $1 to $2 billion to the budget deficit. That is entirely untrue.

All it would simply do is place an onus on airport owners to consult more broadly and to develop strategies for noise amelioration more broadly than the outcome has imposed upon them. Whether that would have involved the expenditure of money, changes in other arrangements such as flight paths or a decision not to do anything at all would have been entirely a matter for those involved. The suggestion that that proposal would have caused additional expenditure of great magnitude is simply incorrect. I thank the House for the opportunity to refer to these matters. As I indicated, the opposition will not oppose these amendments or the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McClelland, Robert, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the amendments to the Airports Bill. I wish to express some concerns my electorate has about the environmental issues surrounding Kingsford‐Smith airport. That airport is operating in a very inconvenient, to say the least, mode for residents of my electorate. On 20 March this year the govern ment opened the east-west runway without obtaining an environmental impact statement. This has caused great suffering to residents in my area and has had an effect on schools, hospitals and buildings generally.

SPEECH.PARA: The government made a promise prior to the federal election to undertake the same noise amelioration program for areas under the east‐west runway as is being undertaken at the moment for areas under the north‐south flight path. Regrettably, while that program will shortly commence in a very limited area, funding in this year's budget for noise amelioration work under the east-west flight path has actually been reduced. The question that immediately arises is how adequate that noise amelioration program will be when, in effect, one area is being deprived of funds to supplement another area. It is causing very real and genuine distress. I am constantly receiving phone calls and complaints from school principals and the like.

I appreciate that the issue of aircraft noise is an intense political one. I fear that, in relation to the environmental issue, the east-west runway is being used for statistics when during quieter periods of the day planes could take off over water. By way of example, last Saturday and Sunday I had the displeasure of painting the outside of my home. They were still days but even so during the middle of the day numerous planes flew over my area. I believe there is no reason the east-west runway had to be used during that period.

It is significant that in August 1994 a plane crashed into Botany Bay shortly after leaving the southern end of the north‐south runway. On my reckoning, if that plane had taken off on the east-west runway it would have landed in about Brighton, which is a heavily populated area. In 1990, a plane took off from the east-west runway and swung around in an endeavour to get back on the tarmac, but unfortunately it did not make it and crashed on the north‐south runway killing all eight people on board.

The statistics show that the great majority of air accidents occur within eight kilometres of an airport and primarily during take-off. The issue of planes taking off is of great significance. If an accident occurred it would be not only a matter of human tragedy but also a matter which I surmise would bring down the government. I ask the government to sincerely look at its policy on Sydney's Kingsford‐Smith airport. Clearly, this policy of planes using the east-west runway for the sake of proving statistics and saying that it is being utilised is a recipe for disaster. It does not need to occur. Those planes could be taking off over water.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Latham, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Senate amendment to ensure that the minister does not have the power to exempt a leaseholder from environmental and planning considerations and public consultation for an airport site. I do so after having had my views on this matter fashioned by the government's handling of the Holsworthy airport proposal. Just recently, some 50,000 submissions were made on the draft EIS guidelines for the Sydney second airport. Senator Hill, the Minister for the Environment, said that this was an attempt by residents to clog up the process. He said this despite a clear government promise to have open consultation, full public involvement, a full environmental assessment.

SPEECH.PARA: We have the Minister for the Environment breaking that commitment, breaking that promise, by saying that some people are trying to clog up the system. You cannot clog up a system whereby people are fighting for their livelihood, where people are fighting for their home values, where people are fighting for their families and their lifestyle. That is what we are talking about with Holsworthy and the south-west of Sydney.

The great bulk of the 50,000 submissions relate to Holsworthy because many people are concerned about the project. Many people have signed petitions. I know the member for Hughes (Mrs Vale) has received them, along with submissions on the guidelines. I have received them. The member for Banks (Mr Melham) and the member for Fowler (Mr Ted Grace) have received them, and even the member for Macarthur (Mr Fahey) would have received some.

So the government, because of its track record and the comments Senator Hill made on the draft EIS, needs to be watched. I also believe that we should not be entrusting the member for Hume, the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp), with those sorts of exemptions because the documents I have seen lodged by the proponents of the Lawrence Hargrave project identify him personally as their champion within the coalition. Why should the minister, that same person, have the power to exempt this airport proponent, this private consortium, from public consultation once an airport site is established? That is also a very legitimate concern, and I raise it with regard to that second Sydney airport proposition.

I also have a concern about the process whereby, without any public announcement, apparently without revealing the advice from the Department of Transport and Regional Development, the draft EIS guidelines for the second airport have an increase in the capacity of the proposal from 275,000 aircraft movements per annum to 360,000. Of course, before the election nobody mentioned Holsworthy airport, and the coalition certainly did not mention its plan to increase the capacity for the second airport by 30 per cent. The member for Macarthur, I think the member for Lindsay, who has now gone to meet her maker in a political sense, the member for Macquarie (Mr Bartlett) and the member for Parramatta (Mr Ross Cameron) all said, `We'll make the airport smaller. If we can do away with a second Sydney airport, we will.'

The government has gone back on that commitment and has increased the capacity for Sydney's second airport by 30 per cent. People in the seat of Lindsay and all the electorates in the south-west of Sydney should bear that in mind: this is a clear broken promise. If people in Penrith or Holsworthy or along the western or south-western population corridors in Sydney think a vote for the coalition is a vote for a smaller second airport or no second airport at all, they are mistaken.

It is very important that the member for Hume reveals the basis of the advice by which he has decided to increase the capacity from Labor's planned 275,000 aircraft movements per annum—it was clearly in our draft guidelines in January—to a whopping 360,000. We have all this after 10 years, even 20 years, of debate about airports in Sydney and when the Department of Transport and Regional Development and the FAC have said we need less capacity at the second airport. Their big plan and all their forecasts have always been geared around the idea of expanding Mascot, because the second airport would be an unrealistic proposition. Such was their advice for many years—that we need less capacity, not more.

So where out of the blue did the member for Hume come up with a 30 per cent increase in capacity? This man, this member, this minister, needs to be watched. I have got my eye on him in every sense. I certainly agree with the Senate amendment that ensures he does not have the power to exempt the project of which he is a champion, the Lawrence Hargrave project, from proper public scrutiny and consultation on those vital environmental and planning issues in the south-west of Sydney.

The other interesting thing is that all the rhetoric the minister has used about where the planes come from and where they go to—allegedly over the national park—is word for word in that project's submission. Not only is he their champion; he is their echo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price, Roger, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to be able to speak on the amendments and in particular again acquaint the House of my interest in the whole issue of airports. It is true to say that out in my part of the world Badgerys Creek was an issue. I have already stated to the House that I have had a long history of supporting a second airport in Sydney, but I have to say that the climate of people's attitudes in the last 11 years has changed somewhat.

SPEECH.PARA: I particularly want to tell the House about a meeting that occurred at Memorial Hall at St Marys in my electorate. I understand Jackie Kelly was invited to go—I was certainly under the impression she was, although I am now aware this is disputed—but did not front. The important point is that the Liberal representative, who is now the parliamentary secretary, Senator Bob Woods, gave clear undertakings there would be a go/no go clause in the EIS.

BREAK.PARA: Under New South Wales state legislation, if an environmental impact statement is commissioned, at the end of that study a recommendation must be made on balance that the proposal, whatever it is, go ahead or not go ahead. I think this is a good thing. Of course, that decision can be overridden by a minister, and no doubt that minister would explain why they might override such a decision.

It is true that our environmental legislation does not make such a provision, but the important thing honourable members in this chamber need to understand is that during the last election it was promised that Badgerys Creek, and presumably now Holsworthy, would be covered by the same commitment: that there would be a go/no go clause. I regret to inform the House—it pains me to say this, actually—that there ain't such a provision. This is a clear indication of deceit.

It is all very well to say that the minister is going to make the ultimate decision about EISs, and that is true. But when you go to the people particularly out in my electorate—and it is true to say that there were people from the electorate of Werriwa, from the electorate of Lindsay, from my electorate and from the electorate of Prospect; they were all there at that meeting, as well as locals—you will find that they were promised a go/no go provision, and it is not there.

The whole issue of Sydney West airport—and we had this problem when we were in government; now the present government has the same problem—is to try to restore some confidence in the whole process. When you make an undertaking that such a critical provision will be within the framework of the EIS draft guidelines and it is not, you suffer a credibility gap; you actually damage the whole process, and that is what you are doing.

With any new airport in any metropolitan or urban location, the idea that you can have 24-hour operation is just ludicrous. I know the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) has pointed out the difference between the standards applying in the United States and the standards that we are applying in Australia to night flights. If I was one of the keenest advocates of an airport at Badgerys Creek, it is true to say that I had long given away the aspiration of a 24-hour operation. But I think that is what you will get if Badgerys Creek goes ahead or if Holsworthy goes ahead—a 24-hour operation. This is going to have a tremendously adverse impact on people wherever such an airport may be located.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I see that my time is running out. I just wanted to thank you for the opportunity to again remind the House of my interest in this matter. This issue of a go/no go clause in the EIS may be taken up in the Lindsay by-election. We will see then what people's reaction is to this matter. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay, Leo, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak briefly on the proposals in the Airports Bill and the generality of the effects of airport ownership on Sydney airport. We may have got a long way towards resolving some of the problems of Sydney airport if the current government had allowed the previous government's legislation on the sale of Sydney airport to go through. The worry I have with the way the present government is conducting the arrangements with Sydney airport and Sydney West airport is that we could end up with the worst of all worlds: no decision being able to be made on Sydney West airport, so Sydney airport becoming the only airport for Sydney. The effect of that would be to turn all of south-western Sydney and part of the eastern suburbs of Sydney into a noise ghetto.

SPEECH.PARA: Since the election we have seen the government's disgraceful policy of so-called spreading the pain. The area of Earlwood is in my electorate. The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) grew up there. He will not attend the Earlwood Public School's 80th birthday celebrations because he knows that the people of that area will want to tear him apart. That suburb never had aircraft noise before. That suburb was a quiet corner of Sydney. People who have lived there for 30 or 40 years tell me that they have never experienced aircraft noise. Twenty and 30 planes a day are now flying over their houses. They really think that the Prime Minister—the local boy made good—ought not chance his arm by coming back to see them.

BREAK.PARA: What has happened in places like Earlwood and other parts of my electorate will be tremendously exacerbated if the government cannot make a decision on where to build Sydney West airport. The only solution to noise problems at Sydney airport is to get on with building another airport that will service Sydney. We have seen in the newspapers in recent days proposals both by airbus industries and the Boeing company to build these massive new 600-seat aircraft. Members can imagine the amount of thrust that would be needed to lift an aircraft with 600 people aboard it. Imagine that noise spreading all over that part of Sydney.

The government ought to get its act together. The government ought to hurry ahead and build Sydney West. The government ought to do away with the disgraceful traffic management arrangement that the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) has inflicted on the people who live around Sydney airport. Unless the government does that, that part of Sydney where nearly a million people live will turn into a ghetto. In the end, the financial imperatives will mean that the curfew will start to be sliced away. If you turn Sydney airport into a 24-hour operation airport, the lives of those people around there will be disgraceful.

The minister has done his best to ensure that he gets his way by looking after people in Liberal electorates and inflicting aircraft noise on parts of Sydney that never had this problem before. This is a disgraceful, dishonest attitude that the government has adopted towards the people of my electorate in particular. While I agree with my colleague the member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner) with the propositions he is putting forward, I also think the government should take on board the dire need to get on with the job of building a second Sydney airport so that we can do something to relieve the traffic at the current Sydney airport.
Debate interrupted; adjournment proposed and negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hatton, Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Senate amendments in relation to the long‐term leases of the airports. The major one that I want to look at and support is the one that stopped the government from exempting private airport owners from scrutiny by the Environment Protection Agency. The amendment that has been accepted by the government ensures that the Environment Protection Agency will have to scrutinise what private owners of airports do with those airports. It means that the consideration of the situation at Holsworthy will still be under the aegis of the Environment Protection Agency.

SPEECH.PARA: I note as well that when the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) was addressing these amendments he indicated that the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey), in looking at the arrangements for the long‐term lease of these airports, had ensured that there would be an open and transparent process in those financial arrangements. I hope we will have an open and fully transparent process when looking at the full environmental impact statement in relation to both Holsworthy and Badgerys Creek. I fear that in the past we have not had a completely open or transparent process when looking at the situation of Holsworthy.

Prior to the last election the then opposition did not give any indication whatsoever that they would be looking to put a second airport at Holsworthy. They gave no indication whatsoever that they would be seeking to include Holsworthy in the EIS that was undertaken in relation to Badgerys Creek. Likewise, prior to the last election they gave no indication, except for the action they took in the Senate, that they would stop the fast‐tracking of Badgerys Creek or that they had anything else on their agenda.

I find that in the past they really have not been open or transparent in relation to this matter. It is quite obvious that when they stopped the process of the fast‐tracking of Badgerys Creek there was something definitely on the agenda. Since the election we have found out that that was the inclusion of Holsworthy as a second site for consideration in the environmental impact statement of Sydney West Airport. This is despite the fact that for 10 years Badgerys Creek had been the place that was chosen, despite the fact that the government had spent more than $155 million on buying land for the development of that and despite the fact that the government had committed itself to the fast‐tracking of Badgerys Creek so it could be open for the Sydney Olympics.

We now know, after the election, that that is no longer possible—there will not be a Sydney West Airport open for the Sydney Olympics. We know absolutely that the government's preference is for the second Sydney airport to be at Holsworthy. That has come through very loudly and clearly, time and time again, in their comments—and the media commentators have picked that up very directly. The impact of not having had an open and transparent process certainly means there has not been enough time to consider the impact on Holsworthy and half a million people in the south‐west area of Sydney.

The impact of putting a second airport in at Holsworthy is that now we have an environmental impact statement process that is tremendously foreshortened. On this side of the House we have taken the position that the government should get ahead with Sydney West Airport—effectively that they should get ahead with building Badgerys Creek airport because that has been 10 years in the making—and that the long‐term lease of the airports and the question of Sydney airport need to be resolved as quickly as possible.

PARA.BREAK: It is very important for all the people in my electorate of Blaxland who voiced their total opposition to any second Sydney airport being at Holsworthy and it is very important to people in the surrounding electorates—the 500,000 people in the south‐west of Sydney—who do not want a second airport imposed on them in a process that, prior to the last election or since, has not been open and transparent and has been imposed on them in such a way that their lives will be entirely crippled. They will have a process where an environmental impact statement which attempts to cover the government's preference for Holsworthy will end up with them being bludgeoned into having the impact not only of Kingsford Smith but also of the second Sydney airport at Sydney West. So I commend the Senate and I commend the govern ment in taking up the Senate's protection—(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adams, Dick, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to comment this evening on the unemployment situation in Australia, especially in Tasmania. It is very good that the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Dr Kemp) is at the table. Unemployment took up some of the consideration of the House today in question time and in the matter of public importance. The figures have come out today of the trends in Tasmania, with the trending line going from 10.2 per cent in February to 10.6 per cent in August.

SPEECH.PARA: We have asked the government to give us a target, to lay down a figure—just as the previous government did—to give itself a benchmark so that we can make a judgment about it. It is what we are saying should be done in the workplace. We have a benchmark now in the workplace to get world best practice. We are asking the government to set a benchmark. We are saying, `Set a benchmark so that we can make a judgment against you.' But the government has failed to do that, and it has failed to do that because it knows that unemployment will continue to increase in Australia. It is going to show that it does not care about unemployed people.

I believe that unemployment in Tasmania will continue to rise because of this last budget and the government's attitude. There have been cuts in skillshare and in skillshare areas where people who have need of literacy and numeracy skills go. They are not the people who are getting into the TAFE colleges; they are people who have need of skillshare. You have cut 33 per cent out of the budget relating to them. New work opportunities, building skills in people, giving them the opportunity to get work right throughout Tasmania, have gone. As for long-term unemployed people having an opportunity to get back into the work force, you have given them nothing and taken everything away.

You have failed the test as minister, and your government has failed to set a target for us, to give itself a benchmark so that people can make a judgment about it. You have failed the test, and the government has failed the test. The continuing attacks on regional areas which you have made in this budget have hit my state enormously. Tasmania is very regional, very isolated and, when you take some of the actions that were taken in this budget, they affect it greatly. You have betrayed us as a state, as you have betrayed the other regions of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I remind the honourable member that I have not betrayed his state.

—I hope not, Mr Acting Speaker. Let me just touch on a couple of points where I can detail how Tasmania has been treated and how unemployment will increase in our state. There are 380 places to be cut from the University of Tasmania. Those people will either join the dole queue or, if they are lucky enough to gain employment, will replace somebody who was going for that job. Thirty places will go out of our maritime college, a major asset in the north and Launceston. According to the last report I saw, I think 33 per cent of the economic basis of that area of Tasmania is related to education. So this is a major blow for that region.

SPEECH.PARA: The 30 per cent cut to the Working Nation program will have enormous effects right through northern Tasmania and Tasmania generally. The cuts to road funding will have enormous effects in relation to tourism, as we were trying to increase access to certain smaller subregions in Tasmania. The ships bounty is to be abolished. It was the biggest employer in Tasmania, the main trainer of apprentices, the main trainer in Tasmania and the biggest employer of apprentices. Whack goes the ships bounty and other help that was structured to assist and build skills into that area.

The Tamar regional environment study, which highlighted the needs and opportunities associated with that area, became an economic tourist and recreation centre. There were opportunities identified in that report and pushed forward by the regional development body, but with the loss of $150 million out of the regional fund they have nowhere to go. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Randall, Don, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to draw to the attention of the House the facts about the Perth airport and the government's position in relation to airport noise. These are in contrast with the inaccurate and misleading comments made about me and the Perth airport by the member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith) in the House last evening. By the way, unlike the member for Perth, I notified him that I would be speaking on this matter this evening.

SPEECH.PARA: The member for Perth was factually incorrect—incorrect when he said that the government had dropped a compensation package for noise affected areas surrounding the Perth airport and incorrect when he said, about compensation, that there is one rule for Sydney and one rule for others. The government has not dropped a compensation package for noise affected areas surrounding the Perth airport because the package did not exist. It may have existed in the fertile mind of the member for Perth.

BREAK.PARA: The member for Perth said that there were contracts for a noise audit or a scoping study. Presumably these studies were going to lead to the compensation package that he was talking about. Was there a contract for the compensation package? Was that also on the then minister's desk? Although they were on the desk of the then Minister for Transport, the honourable member for Kingsford‐Smith (Mr Brereton), the writs had been issued for the federal election, which meant that these supposed contracts could not be signed.

We are expected to believe that these contracts were there all the time. It is a bit like saying that the cheque is in the mail. In other words, it was a pre‐election pork-barrel; it was a con. The Minister for Transport did not know when the federal election was going to be called, otherwise he would have been better prepared and had the contracts signed. I do not understand how the Minister for Transport, a member of the previous cabinet, did not know when the election was going to be called because almost everybody else in Australia knew when the election was going to be held.

If these studies were so urgent, so important, why did the former Labor government not act sooner? The member for Perth has been in government since 1993. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) was the former member for Swan. He could have done something about it. What did they do? What did they do in 13 years of government? Nothing but tokenism on this issue.

The member for Perth is incorrect in saying that there is one set of rules for Sydney and one for other places. In Sydney, compensation was awarded to people whose residences fell within the 40 ANEF contour band and the 30 ANEF contour band. Even though Senator Margetts also wanted people within the 20 ANEF contour to be compensated, thankfully commonsense has prevailed here. In Perth no residences fall within the 30-plus contour. The 30‐plus footprints are found over industrial land, 35‐plus over the airport's buffer zone and 40‐plus over the airport.

This is quite a different situation from Sydney. In Sydney 4,380 residences north of the airport are within the 30 ANEF contour. In Sydney 151 residential properties fall within the 40 ANEF contour. As I said, in Perth no residences fall within the 40 or even 30 contour.

In Perth, Airservices Australia calculate the Australian noise exposure forecast—the ANEF—contours for the FAC. That is how we know what the contours or footprints are. Airservices Australia have microphones in place around the areas surrounding the airport, including residential areas, to measure the noise emanating from aircraft. A further acoustic study would only duplicate this.

Airservices Australia continually run compliance studies to make sure aircraft are complying with their regulations and restrictions. These address the noise impact of flight paths. The member for Perth, who became so interested in the airport last year—yes, last year—leading up to the election, is aware of the monitoring which is done around the airport.

I look forward to representing the people of South Guildford. I do not think, as the member for Perth said last night, they are in shock and horror at this prospect, because they already know that I am not going to make wild promises of things that might not be delivered, as the former government did leading up to the election. I am not going to irresponsibly promise things and build up their hopes only to have them dashed.

I have already helped the people of South Guildford, when I made representations about the sewerage problems in their area to the state government and saw Premier Richard Court about it. Sewerage work is now being undertaken in South Guildford, and the people of South Guildford know that that has nothing to do with the member for Perth.

The member for Perth has irresponsibly imposed a cruel hoax on the people of South Guildford by bringing an unnecessary focus on their residences. I hope his actions have not had the result of devaluing their properties by amplifying this perceived problem in the area.

PARA.BREAK: The ALP clearly do not want the problems of the people of South Guildford. Their member obviously no longer wants to repre sent them. I wonder whether the people of South Guildford know that the ALP asked for South Guildford to be removed from the electorate of Perth in their submissions to the Australian Electoral Commission. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomson, Kelvin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —On Saturday, 17 August, the Sydney Morning Herald carried a feature article by Mike Seccombe on the federal Treasurer (Mr Costello). That article contained the following paragraph:

SPEECH.PARA: When his brother, Tim, was approached by the Democrats, before the last election, to run for them in the Senate, Peter—
who is the federal Treasurer—
. . . sent Kroger to see him. He wined and dined Tim, then told him: `You don't belong with them; you're really one of us. What do you want?' He offered jobs.

On the face of it, the actions of Michael Kroger, a former president of the Victorian branch of the Liberal Party, appear to be a breach of the Commonwealth Electoral Act. Section 326(2) of that act relates to bribery and, for the information of the House, it reads as follows:
A person shall not, in order to influence or affect:
(a) any vote of another person;
(b) any candidature of another person;
(c) any support of, or opposition to, a candidate, a group of candidates or a political party by another person;
give or confer, or promise or offer to give or confer, any property or benefit of any kind to that person or to a third person.
The penalty for an offence against section 326(2) is $5,000 and/or two years gaol.

The article makes it quite clear that Tim Costello was considering running as a Senate candidate for the Australian Democrats. The dinner was organised with a view to influencing his candidature by encouraging him not to run. The claim that jobs were discussed at this dinner brings the events of that evening very much into the realm of section 326 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act.

BREAK.PARA: This is a very serious matter. Public confidence in our political system should be maintained at all times, and we need to ensure that all Australians know and respect the Commonwealth Electoral Act. There is a special responsibility, I believe, on people involved in politics—like Michael Kroger—to ensure that their actions do not undermine public confidence. The language of the act deliberately includes a wide range of actions, because these actions undermine the integrity of our political system.

In that respect, Michael Kroger is no different from anyone else concerning the law. The Sydney Morning Herald article suggests very strongly that Mr Michael Kroger may have broken the law, and I call upon the Australian Electoral Commission to immediately launch an inquiry into this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johnston, Ricky, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 September the Chief Justice of the High Court ordered that a by-election be held for the seat of Lindsay. This by-election has to be held because the Labor Party is a bad loser. The former member for Lindsay, Miss Jackie Kelly, the woman the people of Lindsay chose to represent them in the federal parliament, was ruled ineligible for election because she was still employed by the RAAF when she nominated for the seat. Isn't that the crime of the country? To have the audacity to serve in this nation's defence forces and to also want to serve the people as an elected member of parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I have no hesitation in telling you, Mr Acting Speaker, that the people of Australia are far better off having a young, vibrant, intelligent woman like Jackie Kelly as their representative than they would be having one of those tired, old, menopausal male has‐beens that Labor keeps putting up for re‐election.

Look at the Labor Party. They have a quota system for women, but it hasn't done the Labor women much good, has it? If Australians want more women in this House, then don't worry about the Labor Party's rigged quota system. If Australians want women in parliament, then vote Liberal. Vote for Jackie Kelly.

The background to this by-election shows just how deeply and sincerely the Labor Party believes in democracy. That failed, old, has‐been Ross Free sought to have himself declared elected without going back to the electorate for a by-election. There was an 11½ per cent swing against him just last March. Does he really think the people's decision counts for nothing? Labor was thrown out of office because of its arrogance, and here we have a typical example of that arrogance in Ross Free. What is Ross free of? Ross is free of scruples. He is free of morality. He is free of conscience. He is free of ideas.

Ross Free is also free of the burdens of office but he doesn't like the people's decision. He thinks his lust for power should override the wishes of the constituents of the seat of Lindsay. He is typical of the triple Ms in the Labor Party—middle-aged, misogynist men. I see them sitting on the opposition benches with about as much life in them as a martian rock—primitive life forms, squatting in all their obsolescence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member will resume her seat.

—Mr Acting Speaker, on a point of order: I have listened to this disgraceful attack on the High Court and the constitution by the member opposite and have not said anything yet. However, once the honourable member starts to decide to attack other members of the House, as she has just done, she ought to do that by substantive motion, or you should call upon her to withdraw her remarks.
—I thank the honourable member for Watson, but the honourable member for Canning is not attacking any individual member of this House.

—Mr Acting Speaker, in relation to your ruling, Speaker Snedden in the past on a couple of occasions, as you would be well aware, ruled that it was improper for members to make an attack on a group of members and say that that could not be rebutted by a member. If a member makes an attack on groups of members, as we did and were called to order by Speaker Snedden for attacking the Liberal Party, it is not appropriate for the member for Canning to get up here and make the same sort of broadbrush slurs against members of the opposition.
—I again thank the honourable member for Watson but I do not believe there is a point of order.

—Once again, women are the underdogs. Jackie Kelly put up a valiant fight to gain a massive swing and win a strong Labor seat, which the Labor Party now want to steal from her. They did not want a by-election. They wanted their no‐hoper installed in the seat without letting the people have their say.

—Mr Acting Speaker, on another point of order: the member for Canning said, `The Labor Party tried to steal this seat off her.' As a member of the Labor Party, I take offence at that and I ask that those remarks be withdrawn.
—If you take personal offence—
—I absolutely do.
—I do ask the honourable member to withdraw.
—I withdraw if the member thinks so. They did not want the by-election and they wanted their no‐hoper installed in the seat. (Time expired)

—Tonight I rise in the House to speak on an injustice being perpetrated by this government and, indeed, aided and abetted by the opposition. The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) made all the right noises about a more democratic parliament in this place as the 38th Parliament gathered at the end of April. He has trumpeted the dramatic increase in the number of questions being asked. I can only say that I am glad I did not have to suffer the disgraceful question times of the former Labor government—for most of those I have observed here serve precious little purpose and continue the grandstanding and theatrics that the public, in the galleries and through television, detest.

BREAK.PARA: The major point I want to make tonight is to highlight the total contempt with which the government and the Leader of the House (Mr Reith) regard the rights of the Independent members. We have been consistently asked to deal through the opposition whip when trying to access speaking lists. This is unacceptable. My fellow Independents and I are non-government members of this House—we are not opposition. We will not be party to a speaking list convention that has no role in the democratic parliament. We are not only being asked to submit speaking requests to the opposition whip but also being asked to have them in a week ahead.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's not true; that's a lie.
—Order! The honourable member for Watson will withdraw that comment.
—Mr Acting Speaker, I wrote to his colleague today and said they should have them in the day before. It is a mistruth for him to state this here tonight.
—You will withdraw the word `lie'.
—I withdraw the word `lie' and say it is an absolute mistruth what the member is telling to the House tonight.
—Those were the indications I had. Until that, I was not aware of that letter today.
—Talk to Filing and get him to put you in the picture before you come in here.
—The member for Watson!

—I have no relationship with the opposition, as is obvious, nor with the whip's offices of the Liberal, National or Labor parties. The constitution confers no exclusivity on political parties. In a letter from the Clerk of the House to the Independent member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) on 23 May, an explanation of procedures for Independents nominating for joint parliamentary committees was set out. In respect of those joint committees, an Independent member is able to make his or her nomination direct to the Speaker. Mr Acting Speaker, this is exactly the arrangement I have been seeking with most other Independents for the past six months in relation to speaking lists.

BREAK.PARA: Earlier today, Madam Deputy Speaker Sullivan used standing order 86 to effectively rule my colleague the Independent member for Curtin as disruptive and obstructing business. A motion of dissent to this ruling was eventually gagged by the Minister for Defence (Mr McLachlan) who said, `They—the Independents—can't be allowed to have their say too often.' This is typical of the arrogance—this party political arrogance—that the people of Australia were led to believe would be tempered by this new government and new Prime Minister.

The Leader of the House told the House earlier today that `on any fair interpretation of standing order 86, the Independents are disruptive'. That is demonstrably untrue. I have sought only the democratic right to gain independent access to the speakers list on bills. The current compilation of the list is a convention. The parties and party whips are not recognised in the constitution. Standing orders are the rules of this House, and they are the rules I abide by.

To have access to the opposition Labor Party list is unacceptable, unworkable and undemocratic. I accessed the Labor list once—for my first speech—until I fully understood the system. There is a procedure in place for other speeches in this chamber where we deal with the Speaker to ascertain our speaking opportunities, according to a strict formula which he or she also applied during question time. It is under this system I am able to speak now. It is fair, and I accept it. Why, for democracy's sake, can this system not be adopted in debate on bills where the Speaker uses his or her discretion to inject us into the debate? We seek no more. By invoking standing order 86 today, Madam Deputy Speaker denied fair and democratic access to the non-party members in this House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry, you cannot reflect on the chair. If you wish to, you must move a substantive motion.
—I will withdraw that. For the minister to think—let alone say—that `we cannot be allowed to have our say too often' is, I believe, a disgrace.

BREAK.PARA: The people of Calare gave me a strong vote in March based largely on my Independent stance and my determination to lift the standard of representational democracy. I understand there are members on both sides who can see the democratic logic of our argument. I hope the government see how counterproductive and cynical is their attempt to force Independents into a system we want no part of.

There must be an independent line to the speaking list—that can only be through the Speaker or through the Chief Government Whip in consultation with the government, opposition and the Independents. There were five Independents elected to this House on 2 March. It is likely there will be another elected to the New South Wales parliament soon. (Time expired)
