SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Graeme, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In supporting the Australian Animal Health Council (Live‐stock Industries) Funding Bill 1996, I think what must be made clear is that it is putting another impost on Australian primary producers and I am concerned that we continually do this. We continually do this on the basis that we say we have their agreement. I am not at all sure that this is so. It is very clear if you look at the wool industry, which is in a crisis, that the Wool Council does not represent the overwhelming view of growers. Yet the government and, for that matter, the opposition seem intent on backing this very small group and other noisy elements without any real consultation with the wool growers themselves. This is a situation that I believe has to be addressed.

SPEECH.PARA: In addressing this bill, one cannot escape putting AQIS—the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service—under some sort of scrutiny. For while it is true that a clean, green image is of great value to Australia, it is not at all clear that AQIS is in fact defending this. AQIS's job is, in my view, to make sure that Australia is kept as free as possible from the scourge of pests and diseases that exist overseas and do not exist in Australia.

There seems to be an element within AQIS—I suspect it is an element at the very highest level—that is obsessed with a rationalist economic view of the world which says something along the lines of `It will be better when we have all the same diseases throughout the world, and then we can play on a truly level playing field.' In fact, I have heard this view espoused by senior people in DPIE, and I have no doubt that it infects the very senior levels of AQIS. I want to make it clear when I attack AQIS that I am not attacking the staff, many of whom do a dedicated job. I have had them complain to me recently about the lack of facilities and funds to do the job properly.

BREAK.PARA: The decisions made by AQIS in recent times seem to owe more to politics than they do to science. GATT has become God. The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade is held up by both parties as some sort of shining star of a level playing field and free world trade. It is, of course, nothing of the sort. It is interesting to note the actions of other countries who sign GATT agreements. They immediately go out and try to find a way around them. For example, in fairly recent times, the French, having signed a GATT agreement, were within a few weeks banning Norwegian fish on the grounds of health. I am sure those grounds were totally spurious, but I commend the French government for protecting its industries. I just wish that our own government and the former government could have had the same enthusiasm.

I want to look at a few of the things we have had inflicted on us recently. I believe that the reason Canadian pork was allowed in, despite the real risk of some diseases, was the threat to our beef exports. The Canadians had simply said, `If you don't do this, we will cut your beef.' We sell beef to the world—a very corrupt market—on price or quality, and that is the basis upon which the Canadians buy it. After having signed the agreement, they suddenly cut our beef anyway. It was something they were always going to do. There is a lesson there, but it is a lesson that I doubt will be learned.

Chicken meat is in the same category. There are diseases overseas that would be devastating if they arrived in Australia. Newcastle disease is one. Minister Anderson has said not to worry about newcastle disease, because it could be brought in on migratory birds. If it could be brought in on migratory birds, it would have been here long, long ago. The truth is, of course, that any migratory bird holding the disease at the contagious stage would die en route. It would not get here. The fact that it has never got here is an indication of that. That was a very naive statement by the minister.

We have had the salmon debate. It is true that the last government did not allow the importation of salmon. One had the feeling it was inevitable and that things were moving in that direction, but the election saved it in the interim. I only hope that we will show a little more fortitude and not allow salmon products into Australia. This is not an economic argument in Australia, because our people are selling their salmon at a premium on world markets, against Canadian salmon. But, at the same time, we do not want people, such as Coles or Woolworths, importing dumped salmon and dropping it on the market here.

I have some recent examples, some of which were actually referred to by the member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey). I must commend the member for O'Connor. I thought he spoke very well on this issue. Canola seed has been drawn to my attention by several constituents. Canola seed was imported from New Zealand. I am not sure that it was a superior strain; I think it was simply a cheaper strain. My inquiries tend to indicate that the importer—and, in fact, the agent for AQIS—WAQIS, the Western Australian government inspection service, knew that the seed contained foreign seeds or weed seeds, 12 in all, some of them very serious.

Red shank is one seed and there is another plant there that has the potential to be a skeleton weed. It does not exist in Australia. It is called cleavers. Certainly it can cause a lot of trouble in Western Australia, not only because of the cost of eradication but also because of the damage it can cause due to the levels of insecticide that we would have to incur if that seed is to be eradicated. I believe the costs of eradication must lie with the Western Australian government and that eradication must be undertaken.

The golden apple snail is another example, brought in at the behest of aquarium owners. I am a fish fancier and I enjoy my aquarium and my pond but to allow a group like this to bring in a snail that could devastate parts of our industry is totally irresponsible. This golden apple snail is now in Sydney. It is one of the major pests of the rice industry. I am told there are about eight major rice pests, either insects or diseases, and we have only one in Australia. We have a big advantage. Why would we throw it away with this totally irresponsible action?

Fire blight is another one. Fire blight is a disease of apples that is prevalent throughout the world but it does not exist in Australia. New Zealand wants to sell us apples, although why we need New Zealand apples is beyond me. There is a lot of pressure there and one gets the feeling that the government does not have the political will to resist the New Zealand demands.

I believe if one were to use freedom of information legislation and one had the time and the resources, one would find that the department itself does not believe that the measures being proposed by the New Zealanders will guarantee no entry of fire blight. Fire blight is a scourge of the apple industry but there are some species of apples, particularly the traditional species, that tend to be able to weather it. Obviously, that is so otherwise New Zealand would not have a very big apple industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very costly to control.

—It is very costly to control because it is a fungal disease and fungal spores can get in anywhere. If they get into cardboard packaging then there is absolutely no guarantee fire blight will not arrive in Australia. Once it arrives here it is beyond control. It has never been adequately controlled in any country in the world where it has become established.

BREAK.PARA: There are new varieties of apples that are very susceptible to it but it totally devastates pears. The reason why New Zealand does not have a pear industry is, of course, that it has fire blight. The reason we have a pear industry—the Goulburn Valley is a great pear growing area—is that we do not have fire blight. It seems crazy to put at risk this industry in Australia simply because of some political pressure from New Zealand. I urge the government to totally reject the importation of New Zealand apples.

The reverse scenario also occurs, of course. AQIS has done things that I am aware of. It has been counterproductive when Australian companies have sought to export animals overseas. Just a few years ago I had a fellow in Western Australia who had an order for goats, paid for by the American government, to go to the Ukraine. He was going to source them out of Meekatharra. In fact, they were going to be flown direct to the Ukraine in very large Russian transport planes. However, AQIS stepped in and said that it could not allow this unless every goat was ultrasound tested before departure to make sure it was not pregnant.

I thought this was absolutely absurd and I went to some trouble to find out a bit more. The AQIS people told me they were frightened of the Animal Welfare League and that they had had a case where goats had been shipped out of Sydney to Korea and they had experienced very high mortality rates en route. When I inquired amongst the trade I found out that what they had done was allow goats to be shipped out without grading for size. They had on the plane billygoats, young female goats and kids, and all in the same pens. The billygoats had trampled a lot of the young nannies and kids to death and as a result mayhem had ensued in Korea.

When I asked AQIS what it was going to do, it said it was sending a team of vets to Korea—obviously, at growers' expense—to find out what had happened. I made it clear that I would look very unfavourably at this. It was quite clear what had happened. It should have realised when the goats were loaded. A bit of commonsense would have prevented that. Its draconian over‐reaction is so typical of what we have come to expect from it.

I have a processor in my electorate who has really pioneered the export of Australian scallops at high prices. He has been very successful. His name is Jimmy Chung from Far West Scallops—I am sure he will not mind my mentioning his name. We now import cheaper Canadian scallops and export ours at a premium price. He tried to get Indonesian sourced prawns into Taiwan. Taiwan has a policy of importing fish product from only Australia or Japan. Japan exports far more fish product than it catches. It obviously reprocesses and that gives it a very big advantage.

We wanted to get these prawns from Indonesia. These prawns are readily available on the Australian market and are considered perfectly good and perfectly adequate for Australian consumption. We wanted to repack them with wording that went along the lines, `Indonesian prawns. Packed and processed in Australia. Guaranteed fit for human consumption in Australia.' That was a form of words which would have satisfied the Taiwanese, but you just simply could not get that through AQIS. It would not allow them to be branded as anything other than Indonesian prawns. That absolutely outrageous decision was upheld by the minister.

There are lots of other examples. I saw in the paper the other day that Cannon Foods in Perth—a very competent organisation—is looking to export downstream processed Australian product. It had inquiries from Australian embassies to supply one of its chicken products. It wanted to supply those products to Australian embassies so that the embassies could use them as promotional food when they were entertaining people. This was banned again by AQIS. It was said that the small volume involved certainly in initial stages just could not be supported on the plans and the requirements that AQIS had.

It is quite clear that, if AQIS is going to have any relevance for Australia, it has to get back to its charter of protecting us from the import of pests and diseases. It also has to enhance the export of Australian product. In many cases, user pays is a fine catchphrase. But if the user has no say in what the standards and the requirements are, it really ends up as nothing less than extortion and an action by an Australian government entity in restraint of trade. AQIS's behaviour in this area can be documented—it is not good.

It seems to me that we should be encouraging a lot more bilateral arrangements. For instance, if a Japanese producer is happy with a standard in Australia—and why would it not be happy, Japan imports stuff from Third World countries whose conditions are horrific when compared with ours—then that is all that should be required. If that company is satisfied, that company can make its inspections as frequently as it likes and it can test the stuff on arrival. If that is what is required, then that is all that should be required in terms of exports. The government should clearly be facilitating trade, not in any way acting in restraint of it.

People feel that when you have a body like AQIS that it is doing the job. But I would say that Australia has never been under greater threat from the arrival of diseases. With the advent of air travel, we can cross the world in a single day. With the advent of migration of large numbers from Third World countries, the threat has never been greater. The threat posed by migrants wanting to bring with them material from their homelands is a significant threat. We need to be stepping up our quarantine.

Because this is something that affects the whole nation, it should not be charged just to exporters. To say `The user pays' is an absolute nonsense because, for instance, if foot‐andmouth disease were to get established in the Murray Valley, it is estimated that it would take two out of five jobs in Australia. It is in the national interest, not just in the interest of importers, that AQIS operates, and the government should accept that it has to pay a lot of these charges from the budget.

I think there is room for streamlining in AQIS, there is room for changes in procedures, but we cannot accept the downgrading of our quarantine regulations. The actions seem to be to downgrade quarantine regulations on incoming produce but to increase the requirements on stuff leaving the country. That certainly is illogical and irrational and it is something we have to address. If we do not address it, we are going to miss out on an enormous potential market that does exist in the world for downstream processed Australian food. I hope that the government will pay some attention to it, although the recent utterances of the minister indicate that this is unlikely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman, Alan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to pick up on some of the lines raised by my colleague opposite. In particular, I draw to the attention of the Main Committee and of my fellow Australians the discussions that are going on now in government circles concerning the Australian chicken meat industry and the prospect of imported chicken meat from the United States and Thailand. The previous government struggled with this issue for a lengthy period of time. The minister of the day, Senator Collins, was unable to make a decision but the indications were that he was willing to accept the risk of the import of processed chicken meat from Thailand. This has been a matter of real concern for the Australian chicken meat producing industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem is that in issues of this type there has to be some acknowledgment given that Australian producers will seek to protect their interests and their markets, and they will quite properly raise a variety of arguments to defend their position. The role of government in these circumstances is to determine whether the issues that the Australian producers raise are legitimate arguments or whether they are arguments raised purely to secure their own share of the market and prevent an attack from imports.

In this instance, I have endeavoured to examine the arguments of the industry and the arguments that government has consistently regurgitated, and those views are mainly the views of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service. Both Senator Collins and to a lesser degree Mr Anderson have been captive to the views of AQIS. That is understandable because many ministers are reluctant to be courageous or adventurous in an area where they lack expertise, and they have paid servants who supposedly possess the expertise to advise them. And so around Australia I have noted, both in the Sydney and Melbourne regions in particular, a concern expressed by members of parliament representing the view of their chicken meat producers.

In my endeavour to examine these matters I have attended meetings of expert veterinarians, of poultry experts who would be ranked as world authorities, who very much contest the view of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service that it is safe to import cooked chicken meat from Thailand. These veterinarians have written textbooks. One I call to mind is Tom Hungerford, an Australian name in the poultry industry and also one of very significant international standing. He, amongst others, says that the risk to the Australian poultry industry and Australian bird life is very great indeed.

The unknown factors are these: we do not know the hygiene, conditions or protocols that will be applied to the preparation of cooked chicken meat by the country from which we are importing. That is so indefinite, so dangerous and so likely to be done in chicken producing areas that diseases will be brought into Australia. Those diseases will spread through the Australian flocks and into Australian bird life. One of the downsides in the predictions made by the avian veterinarians is that there is a chance that 80 per cent of the Australian parrot population could be wiped out, because parrots are evidently very susceptible to newcastle disease. This could mean the complete elimination of some species of parrot and the survival of others at only a 50 per cent rate, with the average wipe‐out being about 80 per cent. I think that most Australians would reject risking that occurring.

AQIS is relying on the work done by Alexander, back in 1988‐89 or somewhere about that period, for a New Zealand firm. The extension of work carried out on egg yolks to the importation of chicken meat is a fairly tenuous link, but scientists are prepared to accept that newcastle disease can be killed under certain conditions, if a high enough temperature is applied for a sufficient length of time. That was the basis of Alexander's work done on egg yolks.

As a nation, we appear to be very willing to put at risk not only the economic circumstances and benefit of Australian families but also our heritage in order to gain the short‐term benefit of maybe trading in beef with certain areas around the world. We ought to have a consistent line that is understandable and arguable. We have a unique population of native fauna, and it must be understandable to anybody around the world that we need to protect that fauna from imported disease.

We also have an image that is green and clean for agricultural production, and that green and clean image is a great advantage to Australia in selling its commodities around the world. It is one of our strong marketing feats that we can claim that Australian production processes are minimally interfered with by disease and by the chemicals and treatments on which much of Europe and North America must rely in order to gain economic production. There would be nothing that would suit Australia's competitors more than having an outbreak of newcastle disease or fire blight in Australia to limit our economic capacity and also to limit the markets to which we could gain entry.

Therefore, I put to the House the significance of the Senate inquiry that is currently taking place into the protocols for the import of chicken meat. I wish to encourage veterinarians and those with expertise, as well as those in the Australian industry and Australian conservationists who care for Australian fauna, to take a very active interest in that current inquiry and, if they have expertise that is relevant to the inquiry, to come forward. Australian conservationists seem to be more interested in the ozone layer than they are in the Australian parrot population. They seem to be much more interested in whether there is going to be an appropriate amount of ozone miles above the earth rather than in whether the very population that makes Australia unique for its birds and animals will be allowed to survive.

I am amazed at the attitudes within the Australian Conservation Foundation. When I have written to them on this basis, there is either a failure to reply or a cursory telephone call. There is no real interest whatsoever in the things that, to me, matter as far as preservation of Australia's uniqueness and a real attitude of conservation go. They would rather get involved in chasing whales around the shores of Australia or in attending some esoteric conference—paid for by government, usually—where they discuss the ozone layer.

I think it is time that we dealt with the realities of conservation and exposed some of the so‐called conservationists as mere theorists lacking any scientific expertise or any practical experience in the areas in which they proclaim themselves to be expert. It is time that we started to deal with issues such as desertification and the import of goods from overseas that are likely to influence or interfere with Australia's bird population.

Finally, I wish to place on record some of the comments that I am receiving from the minister—but drafted, no doubt, by AQIS—which outline the significance of Australia's international trading position, our dependence on international markets and the need for us to establish a process that is transparent, that is liberal and that recognises that we are gaining access to markets in Japan, California or the Philippines. It would seem to me that to compare access to Japan for Australian rice—free of disease, of the highest quality and grown under conditions that cannot be emulated in Japan—with the entry from a disease ridden area of a commodity that has real risk and difficulty attached to it is a false comparison.

That does not mean to say that trading nations such as Japan, the Philippines or the United States would see it with Australian eyes. I understand that because trade is a matter of self‐interest; it is not always a matter where you can lay down rules of process that will be followed by the participants. There is a fair degree of self‐interest amongst Californian fruit producers to see that Australian fruit does not get into their area, and I understand that.

This is not an argument that we are having about the import of processed chicken meat to Australia that steers away from self‐interest. But I am raising today the fact that, if you put self‐interest to one side, there is sufficient scientific basis for us to reject the import of chicken meat into Australia without reference to any of the matters of trade or protectionism, or the arguments that are often raised by Australian producers or processors.

The AQIS argument runs the international trade argument. And it is very important that the Australian government and the minister are active in markets such as the Philippines, Mexico and the United States and, in the APEC context, are pressing for improved market liberalisation. But we have always had a claim that there ought to be market liberalisation because both our cost of production and the quality of our production exceed that of most other nations. We are lower in the production cost, and we are higher in the quality and lower in the contamination of our food products in particular.

At the very time that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) is launching our supermarket into Asia strategy, which is one of the great drives he has put together for us to be more effective in marketing into Asia, one of the most compelling arguments will be the lack of contamination and the high quality of our food products. So to mount the trade argument that we need to give away concessions which will ultimately run the risk of damaging that food quality seeks, in my opinion, to strike at the very basis of our most compelling and productive argument when we seek to trade with others.

The AQIS consideration of the whole of this newcastle disease debate has been that it is based on the work of Alexander and the extension of his work to apply to cooked chicken meat. In my opinion, AQIS has refused to consider the proper basis and the full gamut of the protocols, and has argued not only the trade argument but, in my view, a spurious consumer argument which says that the Australian consumer will benefit from cheaper chicken meat.

The exact benefit is about 30c per chicken imported into Australia, if they come as whole chickens. I think if it were put to the Australian people they would gladly pay that extra 30c per chicken in order to continue to eat clean Australian chicken and maintain the Australian parrot population. However, put that to one side.

The cost of cleaning up an outbreak of newcastle disease in Australia—if you can get it cleaned up—is roughly estimated at $30 million. If you spread the advantage to the consumer over a period of time it would be, say, $3 million a year over the 10‐year period. So if there is one outbreak of newcastle disease in a 10‐year period, all economic advantage is lost to the consumer, the Australian government and everybody else. The tenuous nature of what is being proposed here makes it impossible in pure business and logic terms, and I cannot see the political advantage either.

I would like to point out to AQIS that there needs to be a new day and age, and a change in the way in which they do things. My colleague has argued his cases. I am arguing the chicken case. I will also bring up an instance where some of my constituents sought to export product to Japan. They got a phytosanitary certificate from AQIS which said they had a clean product, and it was proved on arrival in Japan that the product was not clean. So one must assume it may not have been inspected properly or may not have been inspected at all. When confronted by my constituent about whether this product was clean and whether it was inspected, AQIS said, `Our phytosanitary certificate is just one of the mechanisms used to gain export and entry.'

The fact of the matter is that under the law of Australia you cannot send the stuff out without the certificate, and it is a law of Japan that they will not import it unless there is a government‐issued phytosanitary certificate. AQIS is saying, `It does not matter much whether we have it or not. It is a bit of paper that travels with straw, hay, or whatever, and we are just not really concerned about the status of that certificate.'

It would seem to me that, if we are going to build confidence in Australian exporters and with our clients overseas, the very first thing that AQIS must do is guarantee the quality of their certificates. And by guaranteeing the quality of their certificates I believe they will gain prestige for themselves, because nothing could be more significant for an Australian exporter to say than, `Here is an Australian government certificate that guarantees the quality of the product free from vegetable and animal contamination.'

If it were to be proved that, inadvertently, the inspection had not been done effectively or that there was a dormant disease or an insect egg that incubated in the process of transport and sprang to life on arrival in Japan, and the product had to be dumped, set aside or fumigated or had to undergo some such process, then I would have thought that if AQIS wanted to establish a real integrity they would guarantee their decision and they would guarantee the replacement of any losses caused both to the exporter or the importer.

Surely that would be a very small guarantee, spread across a period of years, and is a very simple commercial device practised by practically everybody who wishes to maintain a consistent market. I would have thought reinsurance or some sort of insurance covering the phytosanitary certificates issued by AQIS would be just an elemental thing that they should be looking at.

I am concerned about the prospect of imported chicken meat into Australia. I wish Senator Winston Crane well in his inquiry. I hope it is a very thorough and successful inquiry and that the Senate committee is able to draw on the full scientific expertise of Australia and overseas. I hope that they are able to examine very carefully the Alexander decision of 1988 on egg yolk and whether it can be extended to permit the import of chicken meat from Thailand. Above all, I encourage the minister and the department to maintain the clean, green image that Australian products have so much. It is our strongest selling point and something we must always maintain. I would also like to encourage AQIS to be proud enough of their organisation to be able to back their decisions and their certificates with guarantees that actually mean something in international trade markets—something of real worth, something that they will stand behind and something that we can feel as a nation we will support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins, Harry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, it is not often that I rise on matters to do with primary industry or agriculture. A former Minister for Primary Industries, John Kerin, used to always ask me when I was going to get up and protect the interests of the farmers of Thomastown. Anybody who knows the suburb of Thomastown knows that the predominant employment there is industrial. But today I find I rise here to speak on behalf of two of the 207 persons employed in agriculture in Scullin. In doing so, I indicate that it is not only on behalf of those people that I speak. In those industrial areas of my electorate, we have many food processors and they are very keen to see that the green and clean image of Australia's food produce is protected. It is that downstream processing of primary industry that is, of course, very important to the overwhelming number of people of my electorate.

SPEECH.PARA: Another reason that I find myself a bit bemused by the potential of my contribution in today's debate is that I agree nearly entirely with what the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) has said. This did have me a little worried but I have overcome that worry. I think that he outlined a very good case about the potential of decisions that might be made on the chicken meat industry.

The chicken industry in Australia employs around 62,000 people, both directly and indirectly. Many of these are smaller primary producers and are involved in many different stages of the production process. I have been approached, like many other members, by many chicken farmers concerned about the implication of the decision to allow imported cooked chicken meat on their livelihoods, on Australia's health and on our natural environment. I took the opportunity to visit one of these people who contacted me, who lives and works in my electorate. These people describe themselves as poultry farmers and I was very impressed by the quality of their operation. This farmer is one of the smaller primary producers. Each 10 to 12 weeks he receives about 25,000 day‐old chicks from the chicken processing company he is contracted to. For eight to 10 weeks the chickens are housed in the two large sheds on the farm, with sophisticated heating, water and feed systems. The chickens are given a course of feed, which is supplied by the contracting company. The nutritional content of the feed alters with the age of the bird.

At the completion of the cycle, the chickens are returned to the company. The mortality rate among the chickens is low, only around three to four per cent of the birds. The sheds housing the birds are then thoroughly cleaned and there is a two‐week break before the cycle begins again. The farmer receives payment for the batch of 25,000. It is not an enormous amount of money, after the farmer has deducted the cost of gas for heating, electricity and water. Water represents a large component of the cost.

The reality is that many of these smaller primary producers live pretty close to the edge with their running costs. Although these smaller primary producers run their own business, they are contracted to a chicken processing company and receive a set amount per bird for the cycle that the birds are in their care. Of course, it could be argued that they are in fact contracted employees of the chicken processing companies.

If cooked chicken meat is allowed to be imported, it is precisely these smaller primary producers who will be effectively locked out of the system. Rather than have contracts with many small farmers, the large chicken processing companies will undoubtedly prefer to deal with a chain of farms or with the big agribusiness farmers.

BREAK.PARA: The chicken farmer in my electorate is not just concerned with the effects of imported chicken meat on his own business, he is genuinely concerned about the health implications of the decision and the potential environmental consequences. As has been indicated, there has been work undertaken by AQIS and, based on those studies, they have come to a position. I assert it is still necessary to make certain that the conditions surrounding the importation of cooked chicken meat are satisfactory by further investigation. There are too many horror stories for it to go ahead without being 100 per cent in the clear.

For instance, and not totally unrelated, there are the stories of the Brazilian chickens pumped so full of oestrogen to quicken their development that they began to affect the speed of development of the children who ate them. I agree with the honourable member for Mitchell that it is pleasing to see that the whole issue has been referred to the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs Legislation Committee and I totally endorse the points of the honourable member for Mitchell in encouraging people to make submissions to that inquiry. I believe that in this instance an open public inquiry, such as can be conducted by the Senate committee, is appropriate. As the honourable member for Mitchell and others have said, we have to protect our image as an acclaimed producer in primary produce.

An earlier experience I had with AQIS involved a chicken meat processor who operates in the suburb of Thomastown. The operator came to me with a problem in getting the proper certification of his works on the basis of the quality of the water that was being used. What was interesting about this tale was that this operator was using the same water supplied by Melbourne Water to the surrounding suburbs. This was water that was good enough to be used in a domestic sense by the surrounding suburbs and it fulfilled World Health Organisation standards for water but, given the very tight and conservative nature of the requirements of AQIS, it was not of sufficient standard to be used in the washing processes in a chicken processing plant.

The irony, I thought, was that this business was about to embark upon a niche market in Asia for chicken feet. The thing that was a stumbling block was the quality of water. In the end, the operator solved the problem by installing an ultraviolet filtration system to ensure that the standard of the water enabled him to get the certification.

In conclusion, we need to see that this position of allowing in cooked chicken meat is investigated thoroughly. It applies to a significant primary industry employing tens of thousands of Australians. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) has argued that Australia needs to do this in the interests of trade liberalisation to benefit our own farmers. However, trade liberalisation should not mean jeopardising our own standards or unnecessarily risking our own environment. Destroying the livelihoods of Australia's efficient small primary producers and those who depend on them is hardly good for our own economy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting that the debate this morning so far has been relatively focused on the chicken industry but the bill does cover a number of other industries. Obviously previous speakers have taken a keen interest in that particular issue at the moment. It is quite topical as far as the importation of chicken meat is concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: I was interested in the remarks from the member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) with regard to an attitude that prevails within this government and the previous government towards international trade arrangements under GATT. I just highlight to the member for Kalgoorlie that there are a number of us who take the attitude that we are watching and seeing how beneficial it is. Whilst I personally acknowledge the philosophy behind trade liberalisation, the process in achieving the ultimate goal is not always equitable. Certainly at the moment there is anecdotal evidence that it is not equitable either. So on that basis I would probably disagree a little bit with the member for Kalgoorlie on that point.

The other issue that has been commented on fairly generally this morning is with regard to the way we as a nation discharge our international responsibilities and how we treat the import‐export arrangements and our bilateral trade arrangements. As far as the importation of the chicken meat is concerned, I am sure that as a nation exporting commodities and a lot of primary produce we are expected to go over much higher hurdles sometimes than what we impose on imports into this country. One of the previous speakers was talking about the export of rice. If we think of the process and the lengthy negotiations that this country has had to go through to be able to export rice to Japan, the restrictions that are put on us and the requirements that we must meet compared to other nations, certainly we see that the process and the progress of the development of world trade liberalisation is not equitable. I think that we should always bear that in mind when making decisions such as this with regard to the non‐direct tariff/subsidy type arrangements with commodities.

A number of the previous speakers have focused to a large extent on the chicken industry. I want to focus a little bit on a couple of our other primary industries that have associated and not totally unrelated problems at the moment. I know this bill is about protecting what we have got in this country. I suppose that when people in Australia go to the shop, to the supermarket or to the butcher's shop to buy beef, lamb or chicken, they just take for granted that it is in pristine condition, that we do not have any exotic diseases in Australia and that there is no fear of foot‐and‐mouth disease or mad cow disease and all the sorts of things that are evident in other countries. Generally, the population takes that too much for granted.

I think that Australia's very good track record in this regard should be highlighted. Perhaps that record causes other nations to which we are trying to export to raise the bar, so to speak, and to try to slow us down. There are so many other nations around the world which do not have such a good track record on animal diseases.

We obviously support the bill before the Main Committee today. The purpose of this bill and the associated amendments to a number of primary industry levy acts is to direct funds to the Australian Animal Health Council Ltd. This will allow the beef, sheep meat, egg, chicken meat and pork industries to meet their funding obligations to the council. The Australian Animal Health Council Ltd has been established as a non‐profit company and will be jointly owned and funded by the Commonwealth government, state and territory governments and the peak national representative bodies of Australia's livestock‐based industries. Its mission will be to ensure that the Australian animal health service system is capable of maintaining acceptable national animal health standards which meet consumer needs and market requirements at home and overseas. That is described in the second reading speech, which also describes the structure of this body. Under `Remarks' in the bills digest it says:

While the provisions of this bill are of a non controversial technical nature, the use of a non statutory corporation as a disbursement vehicle for public and private funds differs from the more traditional statutory disbursement vehicle in a number of respects, including:
the AAHC is not required to prepare an annual report which must be tabled in parliament;
the AAHC is not subject to the Audit Act of 1901; and
it is unclear whether the AAHC is subject to the Senate Estimates process.

Bear in mind, that this body is being funded by governments, both Commonwealth, and state and territory, and by industry. So there is a very broad range of public funds being applied in this exercise. As a member of the Public Accounts committee—and we are just reviewing the Audit Act and looking at a new Auditor‐General's bill—I think that the parliament, generally, and the government should watch that the responsibilities of this organisation are dispersed when it is structured in such a manner. I am not saying that it is not an acceptable manner but, certainly, it is new as far as a statutory authority is concerned.

We have had instances recently where different government departments have been less than prudent in their oversight of the expenditure of public funds. For instance, the future tech project, I understand, had many millions of dollars worth of taxpayers' and levy payers' funds and, to all intents and purposes, these were lost in that failed project. We should flag that. The minister and his department should monitor the process as it takes place once this organisation comes into effect.

Obviously, the whole exercise is about guarding and protecting Australian industries. The annual report from EXANDIS—the Exotic Animal Disease Preparedness Consultative Council—says that there are 54 animal diseases currently not present, but which could enter Australia and threaten our livestock industry. We all know what difficulties our primary industries are facing as far as exports are concerned and we certainly do not want to see the incursion of any of these diseases into Australia. They may jeopardise those very important domestic and export industries.

EXANDIS goes on to say that the best known of the diseases with the most serious potential impact is foot‐and‐mouth disease. It has been prevalent in a lot of the countries overseas, some of which would like to break into some of the marketplaces that we currently occupy overseas. It is important from that perspective that we support and bolster the activities and the appropriations that are being outlined in this bill.

In its final annual report EXANDIS urged government and industry to maintain, through the AAHC Ltd, a high level of continued activity aimed at protecting Australia against exotic animal diseases and preparing for any outbreaks. EXANDIS considered that the greatest exotic animal disease threats to Australia are foot‐and‐mouth disease, newcastle disease, bluetongue and classical swine fever. As I say, we have heard a fair bit about newcastle disease here this morning.

The AAHC was born out of concerns that Australia might not be able to meet the demands of trading partners for information on animal health and welfare, unless a number of fundamental changes were made for the delivery of animal health services. The AAHC Ltd, is an unlisted public company, as I said. It was established following agreement in August 1995, by the Agriculture and Resource Management Council of Australia. It is unique in its structure, in that it is a non‐statutory corporation administering public and private funds. It differs from the more traditional industry and statutory bodies, such as AMLC and MRC—and I want to make some comments on those couple of bodies shortly.

However, the advantage of this structure is that the AAHC is still accountable to its members, is more flexible in nature and is relatively cost‐effective in its administration. As I said before, we should be monitoring its effectiveness and the way it is administered. There are a lot of public funds going to be applied to this body, and so it is important that we do that on the basis of the manner in which other statutory bodies have expended public funds and discharged their responsibilities. They are bodies that have been under the direct scrutiny of the parliament and the Auditor‐General.

With regard to an associated issue, with the current review that the minister and the department are undertaking with regard to the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation, the MRC and the MIC, there has been a lot of public comment, particularly from the relevant industries that are involved. I have attended a number of public meetings, predominantly of beef producers in my electorate who are not satisfied with the way the AMLC and its associated bodies have discharged their responsibilities. The producers are not satisfied as levy payers, and this is associated with the issue that we are debating today, because the funds are coming in part from industry as well as from government.

The producers in my area are not satisfied that the levies that they pay are being spent to the best advantage of the industry, and particularly of the producers. They are not satisfied that they have adequate representation on any of those bodies. They are in a minority, and the processing sector has the majority view from its end of the industry on all of those bodies. As I say, there has been an enormous amount of public comment as to what should be happening with the restructuring of those bodies. At this stage, I have not been convinced that we should not have two separate species bodies controlling sheep meats and beef meats and live cattle and live sheep.

I believe that there has been a conflict of interest within the AMLC, probably on a four‐way basis, between the sheep industry, the beef industry, the processors and the producers. They are all mixed into the one melting pot together, all trying to achieve a goal. There is a great question mark now over whether generic marketing is the way to go, when you consider what some of the people that we trade against in the world marketplace are doing with their commodities.

That raises the next question regarding getting some sort of agreement throughout the industry with regard to grading. It has been a bone of contention within the beef industry for a lot of years that there has never been agreement on a grading system. We are now getting to a stage as far as world competitiveness and access to markets are concerned where, unless the national industry—and it will probably take leadership from the government, the department and the minister—agrees to decide on a universally accepted grading system, we are going to be continually put at a disadvantage in the marketplace.

In speaking in support of this bill, I have a couple of points to make in closing. We must continue to support this sort of monitoring. As I say, we probably take too much for granted in this country the fact that we benefit from living in a disease‐free island nation. We do not have common borders with other countries where we can see diseases coming across those borders. We must continue to monitor, and it is very important that the government plays its role in industry as well. I highlight the fact again that, with this new structure for a limited company that is using government funds, public moneys and levies that are being applied to its exercise, we should monitor the way that it has gone. Maybe in the future there should be a report brought back with regard to how this particular structure has worked in this industry.

I take the opportunity to urge the minister to bring in the report while there is an end date to the review into the beef industry and to bring down his response to that as soon as possible. The beef industry is in crisis and the beef industry is looking for leadership. As far as I am concerned, I think there is leadership throughout the industry but at different levels. I think the beef industry is looking for some leadership and some direction from government. The time is right to restructure those processes and statutory bodies so they better reflect what the industry wishes, they better reflect the producers in the industry and they better reflect the market in which we have got to operate internationally in the 1990s. With those few comments, I will finish there in support of the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I am representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson). He is with the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) who is launching the Supermarket to Asia strategy here in Canberra at this time. It is a privilege for me to represent the minister on this very important piece of legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to thank all those who have participated in this debate. There have been some issues raised that I will comment on. I think it is important that we have had a wide‐ranging debate from both sides and I know that some of the comments made certainly have not gone unnoticed by the minister and the minister's office. To an industry as important as the beef industry and agriculture generally, not only to this nation but also to employment in regional Australia, these amendments are certainly important. They are certainly going to tidy up some of the mess that was left behind by the Labor Party in this area.

The proposed amendments to these bills remove the retrospective application of the levies. As the bill stands, the levies will come into effect from 1 July 1996 on receiving royal assent. The amendments will ensure that the levies come into effect from the first day of the month at least 30 days after the act commences. A retrospective application of the levies and charges would disadvantage producers, levy payers and intermediaries who collect the levies on the Commonwealth's behalf. A retrospective application would also impose considerable additional cost on the levies management unit, the LMU, in the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, in its attempts to recover the additional levies. The LMU is a cost recovery area, so costs incurred are passed on to industry and impact on the funding of the Australian Animal Health Council. Associated industry bodies, such as the promotional and research and development bodies, are also funded by these levies. It would have an adverse affect on those bodies.

The 30‐day period after the act commences will ensure that levy payers and intermediaries who will collect the levies receive sufficient notice before the levies come into effect. An additional amendment to the Laying Chicken Levy Amendment (AAHC) Bill 1996 will remove the unnecessary duplication of the provision which limits the levy to no more than the amount recommended to the minister. This provision is already included in the Laying Chicken Levy Amendment Act 1988.

Now the Australian Animal Health Council (Live‐stock Industries) Funding Bill 1996, the Meat Chicken Levy Amendment (AAHC) Bill 1996 and the Pig Slaughter Levy Amendment (AAHC) Bill 1996, are not being amended. These bills do not impose a rate of levy and so have no retrospective application date.

In their contributions to this debate several members raised the issue of the application for importation into Australia of cooked chicken meat from Thailand, Denmark and the United States. I should reiterate several points previously raised on the Hansard record. In May the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy made it clear that these are not new applications, rather that they date from the late 1980s. They have been the subject of extended analysis by both government and industry. Under legislation, the procedure for such applications is that they are referred for scientific analysis of disease threat.

The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service recommended in June 1994 that cooked product should be admitted provided that it met certain strict conditions, including time and temperature parameters, which would inactivate disease agents of concern. In the consultation phase that followed, the effectiveness of the proposed time and temperature parameters as a minimum treatment against disease agents was agreed by a wide range of independent scientific authorities. It was also agreed by the Australian Poultry Industry Association and the National Poultry Association.

AQIS advised the former minister, in the former administration, on 30 May 1995—and I stress that it was May of last year—that the technical assessments were complete and that access would be granted to the United States of America, Denmark and possibly Thailand. It is very important that that is on the public record and that it is reinforced: that the former minister in the previous administration agreed to those technical assessments that were complete on 30 May 1995. The previous minister noted this, without caveat, on 2 June last year. So it is hypocritical of those on the opposite side to come into this place and criticise this decision. It is a decision that was supported from the other side.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are just doing what we—
—When you get out into the electorate you talk a different language.
—It is you blokes who have been criticising it.
—Out in the electorate you talk in a different language. And we also heard the former minister for primary industries using a different language—
—What you are saying is that you now agree with it.

—A completely unexplained delay ensued. And, on attaining government this year, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has been advised that all of these procedures I have outlined have taken place. Following the incompetent approach of the former minister, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy now, Minister Anderson, has—
—You are being disingenuous.
—It is not disingenuous; it is the fact.
—You have been hoist on your own petard so high—talk about flapping in the breeze!
—Order!

—Following the incompetent approach of the previous administration, which is its legacy, Minister Anderson has engaged in extensive discussions with industry. All honourable members should acknowledge that the coalition government has established two working groups—one on the establishment of imported protocols and one on any economic and adjustment effects arising from the importation of cooked chicken meat. These groups were established with the full involvement of industry. A major industry and government meeting was convened at the minister's instruction and chaired by the minister in June this year. It must be acknowledged that the government is undertaking an exhaustive effort to address matters raised by the domestic chicken and chicken meat industries.

BREAK.PARA: I want to wind up by thanking those members who have contributed valuable comment to this debate. I also want to say that it is an extremely important change and I am sure these amendments will be welcomed by the industries concerned.
