DEBATE.TITLE: PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 27 June, on motion by Mr Miles:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe, Neil, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to make some observations about the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1996 I should say to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott) that there was a reason for my interjecting during his summing up of the previous legislation. AQIS is related to this bill for meat inspection, food quality and all those things, so we can find plenty of hangovers if he wants to. I thought he was being unkind when he said that he was coming in to clean up Labor's mess because, although he may not be aware of it, all of the items contained in that legislation are simply rolling forms of the—
—Order! The honourable member is speaking on the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), not the matter just resolved by the House.

—I am relating it, Mr Deputy Speaker, to a general observation I am making about the fact that, if you go to the second reading speech in relation to this bill, you will see that the amendments being made here relate partly to the quarantine service. I think that the quarantine service has food inspection issues related to it, so I will make some observations on it anyway.

SPEECH.PARA: All I am saying to the minister is that the rolling changes that have been made to all these pieces of agricultural legislation are simply that. They were in process. The government has simply continued what we set going, and in fact it has been supported by us for exactly the same reasons. I just made the point that I thought he was a bit unkind, that is all, for those reasons.

Everybody seems to be wandering around with some confusion over those observations I made about quarantine. My briefing notes here tell me that the purpose of this bill is to make amendments to the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals (Administration) Act, the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Code Act, the Fisheries Management Act, the Farm Household Support Act, the Imported Food Control Act and the Quarantine Act. That is what they tell me. They are the government's own notes that came to us, so I do not know why the minister is confused about it.

To move on from there, I have to say to the minister that I was enjoying his discomfort about the issue of imported chicken meat, having heard the sorts of things he wandered around Australia saying and noting that he is now simply picking up and moving on with exactly what was in process.

I will set the minister a challenge. I remember John Kerin telling me once, when we came to office in 1983, that something like 125 or 150 was the number for the minutiae of agriculture bills which had been created by the old Liberal‐National Party administration, as it tried to legislate for every specific farm activity you could possibly find. With a whole lot of effort over a number of years, we have probably managed to get it down to about 75—I do not know. There is a challenge for the minister. For as long as his party is the government he should see if he can remove some of this for us. He should see if he can get this down to maybe a handful of sensible pieces of legislation, instead of all these levies, laying acts and heaven knows what.

I note that one of the amendments being introduced in the legislation is to ensure that drought relief payments are payable to eligible farmers only within the period specified on the drought exceptional circumstances certificate. I can only assume that it has been necessary to do that because we have been having payments outside the exceptional circumstances certificate. I do not know why that would be so, but if it has to be, it has to be. If it means that we are tightening up drought relief, then I am sure that the honourable minister opposite (Mr Bruce Scott) will be able to go round and explain to his constituency why we are having to do that. If it has to be, I am glad that it is.

BREAK.PARA: You will also note in the second reading speech that one of the amendments will allow quarantine officers of the various state and territory departments to be involved in the inspection of food imported into Australia. I think that it is important to make this point because there is certainly a perception conveyed in regional Australia that Australian producers and processors face great barriers when attempting to export food products into other countries. They will constantly tell you that you can bring anything into Australia where we do not have the same situation. I am sure that the honourable minister opposite has been one of the ones wandering around Australia saying that.

The fact is that foods imported into Australia face significant testing and quality control processes and it is a nonsensical claim to say otherwise. I hope that the new government will take some steps to make it clear that not only are foods imported into Australia subject to inspection and quality assessment issues but also more resources are being made available to ensure that happens, because we hear a lot about unlevel playing fields.
If we are launching a supermarket program to Asia, such as you are doing today, we support it wholeheartedly because we thought it up—

PARA.EMPHASIS: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—
Sitting suspended from 11.38 a.m. to 12.03 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —In continuation and winding up, I was making the point to honourable members opposite that we are wildly enthusiastic about the launch of the supermarket to Asia project today, because it evolved from initiatives taken last year by the former government.
—There is a long story there.

—Yes, it is excellent. There was a meeting—I think in Bathurst—where the former Prime Minister and a range of industry leaders in food processing, the farm sector and the transport sector looked at what things were required to bring this all together and really explore the food bowls for Asia concept. The document that was released from there had an action plan with a whole lot of key points. I was reading the other day the release from the new Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) announcing all these new initiatives. Every one of those key points was there and I thought, `Ah, isn't that wonderful?' This was what led me earlier to make the observation that I thought the minister was being a bit unkind. I am perfectly happy to say that I am glad to see the new government picking up these things, maintaining the consistency and running them through. But it would not hurt the new government to acknowledge that there is a process here and, where we have a bit of bipartisanship, we ought to be promoting that in the general community.

BREAK.PARA: Having made those observations, Mr Deputy Speaker, as you are well aware, this is an omnibus bill. There is no need for me to go through the detail of it; it was outlined in the second reading speech. It has our support and I thank you for the opportunity to make a contribution.

TALK.START.PARA: —When enacted, the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1996 will be an omnibus bill. It will address areas of agriculture and provide amendments to acts from as diverse a spread as veterinary science, regulatory adjustment to fisheries, quarantine, household farm support and food control. Similarly, it will repeal 15 inoperative acts which, following a departmental review by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, are acts that were either superseded or which were intended to have effect for only a certain period of time, which has now expired.

BREAK.PARA: As the member for Paterson—an electorate of over 9,000 square kilometres possessing some of the most productive grazing land and agricultural output in Australia through its predominance in beef, dairy produce, timber, seafood, poultry, vegetable produce and, of course, not forgetting the very much adjacent world‐class wineries of the Hunter Region—I will be getting right behind and supporting any legislative change that improves the lot of the primary industry sector. With the people of Paterson very much steeped and enriched with primary sector pursuits, it is important to highlight how the wave of the legislatory wand in the House can be applied to deliver an agri‐industry that will put more and better quality food on a nation's table and, more importantly, deliver valuable export dollars that enhance the nation's accounts.

To build on one of the great religious stories, it would be fair to say that my region can and does deliver both the fishes and the loaves. The fishing industry, built around the tranquil coastal fishing villages and the majestic Port Stephens region, has the infrastructure and the environment to reap great rewards for the region and help to balance the import/export ledger.

As the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr McGauran) has just announced, the Howard government is determined to realise the multimillion dollar potential of our marine resources. By the year 2020, the nation's marine resources are expected to generate many extra hundreds of millions of dollars in annual turnover. It is a phenomenal figure. But when you break down the reality of pressing overseas demand for our clean and outstanding fish and seafood, the access to maritime resources over an area almost twice as large as our island continent itself and the real initiatives promoted by the supermarket to Asia and the world strategy of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), it is not hard to see that vision and hard work can and will reach this astronomical trading performance inside two decades.

Under this legislation, the Howard government, in implementing an amendment to the former government's Fishery Management Act 1991, is directly reacting to the requests of the fishing industry, which has called for amendments following the outcome of several court cases that have related to fisheries, and other areas of concern relating to property rights and the examination of effects of the current provisions of an act on the level of security for statutory fishing rights.

The Fisheries Management Act provides for the issue of statutory fishing rights under fishery management plans. These rights are created by statute. In other words, rights created by statute can be withdrawn by statute without necessarily requiring the payment of compensation.

The current reality provides that no compensation is payable because the fishing right is cancelled, ceases to have effect or ceases to apply to an individual fishery. The amendment seeks to clarify that, where there is an acquisition of property within the meaning of the constitution. Some recent court decisions in this very area have raised the question of circumstances where application of the provision may be contrary to paragraph 51(xxxi) of the federal constitution and therefore deemed invalid.

The point of the act is, as it presently stands—and I am sure it was intended—that it was never meant to be an unfair and unconscionable piece of legislation. Yet the legal reality is that fishing rights can be cancelled in writing without any consideration of the cost or impost to the actual licensee.

In many cases these are individual fishermen, individual small enterprises and hardworking people who do not need another slug from government. The Howard government is determined to stick to the key priorities, one of which is getting the monkey and the government off the back of business and allowing them to do what they do best; that is, being in business and getting ahead. The potential loss of profit and hard‐earned income by not passing this amendment is simply untenable. I would think it most untenable to the representatives of the local fishing and seafood industry that embraces Paterson electorate and, of course, the entire Australian seaboard.

Another key amendment in this legislation is the amendment to the Imported Food Control Act 1992. Even if you are not an avid reader of the newspaper, or aware of Australian trade policy, I am sure the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service and its role in the quarantine of imported food—in the interests of human health—would get a gentle nod from many people. AQIS has been put through the wringer in recent times. The Nairn inquiry will, in due course, address and assess its overall operation, its effectiveness and its ability to play the role of border guard, or the nation's doorman, in order to halt the introduction of exotics and noxious diseases.

The substantial amount of food which is imported into the country has a quarantine status. Inspection teams from the various state and territory departments of agriculture and the imported food inspection program of AQIS perform this role. The anomaly of the current Imported Food Control Act 1992 is that it only allows officers of AQIS to be appointed as authorised officers to inspect imported food, even though a fully equipped quarantine officer may carry out an inspection of the same food. The proposed amendment simply puts right a glaring problem in the current act. It is a critical problem and on the national scale of importance a problem that must be effectively addressed.

Governments around the world may be wanting to drag down the tariff walls, to take a sledgehammer to unnecessary and overburdensome protectionism in keynote industries, but the wall that should never be diminished—indeed only strengthened—is the wall that has been put up to protect Australia from exotic diseases and the importation of noxious plants, insects and wildlife. The former Exotic Animal Disease Preparedness Consultative Council—EXANDIS—outlined in its final report that the greatest threat to Australia is considered to be exotic and highly virulent diseases imported via the backs of migrating birds, on the plastic wrapping of imported products, and in illegally imported products.

As I said, AQIS is being given a hard time at the moment, and the inadvertent outbreak of the rabbit calicivirus, the pilchard killings off south‐east Australia and the papaya fruit fly outbreak has not enhanced its cause. However, any legislative clout that gives AQIS a more effective and efficient inspection service, that minimises unnecessary duplication of services and frees up resources to fight the fight against disease where it needs it the most has to be a step in the right direction. It should be acknowledged that this proposed amendment has been discussed with the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson), and representatives of the imported food sector and has received a thumbs up all around.

Under current arrangements, it is not always cost-effective to prosecute passengers and inbound tourists breaching quarantine regulations at Australia's international airports, particularly in cases of less serious breaches. The proposed amendment tied to this legislation in relation to the Quarantine Act 1908 is a practical means of serving penalty notices—in other words, on‐the‐spot fines—on people detected leaving an airport or port in Australia with undeclared quarantine goods in their possession. This initiative will free up forever our overstretched court system whilst not neglecting the serious breaches against quarantine that occur.

One case I caught up with in the local press some months ago was that of an individual trying to bring in a giant snail, courtesy of a South American country, as a pet. I understand that this particular breed of snail grows to an astronomical size and, if undetected and let loose on native flora, could have wreaked all sorts of damage. The government is not shirking its task in saying that the quarantine breaches are not serious. On the contrary, introducing a system of penalty notices, or opting for a court hearing for minor breaches, provides cost‐effectiveness in obtaining compliance with our strict quarantine requirements and, importantly, enhances public awareness of the requirements which escape so many people, from our man with his giant snail in his suitcase to many more.

As the chicken industry's leading parliamentary fighter against the virulent newcastle disease, I find it noteworthy that exotic disease is not limited just to living plants or to wildlife brought in through the back door. The fact that exotic diseases can be brought in via packaged and processed goods is a source of concern.

There is another pleasing feature of the legislation, and it should please the people of regional and rural Australia who have done it tough in the past decade and a little bit longer. The recent horrific drought which still, despite healthy rains, has not broken in portions of New South Wales and Queensland, and the dire necessity of drought relief payments, are always a matter of concern.

The classic bumbling by the former Labor government in which farm communities and not dissimilar drought stricken communities or regions were to receive drought relief payments was, of course, an appalling exercise in public relations and yet further evidence of a kick in the guts by Labor to our regions and the bush.

The amendments to the Farm Household Support Act 1992 will strengthen the arrangements that apply to the drought relief payment by clarifying the period of validity for drought exceptional circumstances certificates for the purpose of obtaining drought relief payments. To receive drought relief payments, a requirement to access government money comes in the form of receipt of a current drought exceptional circumstances certificate. These certificates are issued on a six‐monthly basis.

Under the current legislation, there is nothing to prevent farmers from saving the DEC certificates and then, at some time in the future, claiming and receiving those DRP retrospectively. The amendments will make this income support payment consistent with other such government outlays which do not provide for entitlements to be paid retrospectively.

Another important clarification is the consequential amendments by DEETYA to the Student Assistance (Youth Training Allowance—Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Act 1994, which erroneously omits the words `or drought relief payment'. Again, this corrects another case of a classic Labor barb against the people of regional and rural Australia.

The general outline of the legislation also amends the Farm Household Support Act 1992 by exempting income tests applicable to drought relief payments on any proceeds derived from the forced disposal of livestock. Under current arrangements by the former government, farmers receiving drought relief payments who are forced to dispose of their livestock—a tragic occurrence during times of drought—are assessed by the Department of Social Security under the DRO test. This is the test that is used as the basis for the estimation of annual income, and it is used to set the rate of the drought relief payment for the next six months.

It is just a crazy situation. You cut your stock, and the government potentially cuts your drought relief payments as well. The amendment will exempt from income tests the people of Gloucester, Dungog, Stroud, Bulahdelah—and indeed, my colleague for Lyne (Mr Vaile), the seat north of mine—who depend on livestock for their income and survival and who, in tight times, need the drought relief payments to get through. This amendment will ease it for them.

Our government, the Howard government, is absolutely committed to regional and rural Australia. We are determined to make sure that we provide fair and equitable relief to the people in the country. We have to forget all the Labor rhetoric that says that we are cutting services and cutting the guts out from under people in regional and rural Australia. How wrong they are.

With an improved economy, lower interest rates and support for small businesses—and one thing that Labor has forgotten is that farms are indeed small businesses—we are fully supportive of rural and regional Australia. We fully support, too, families in country areas and their need for increased access to things like Medicare. I point out that this is one of the reasons that the Liberal Party holds 31 seats in regional and rural Australia. Indeed, my National Party colleagues hold 18 seats, and the Labor Party, at best, could scratch up two seats. We will accept Tasmania there as a seat. I fully support the bill and I commend the bill to the people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott, Bruce, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr BRUCE SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to thank all those who have spoken in this debate and say that I am representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and Deputy National Party Leader (Mr Anderson). He has a clash in his diary today. He is launching supermarket to Asia with the Prime Minister and is in attendance there. So it is my privilege to participate in this debate on his behalf.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to thank those who have contributed to this bill. It is quite clear from the comments from the honourable member for Paterson (Mr Bob Baldwin) that he is clearly across the issues of regional and rural Australia, and not only in his own electorate. He spoke very forcefully about the fact that these changes and amendments are necessary and fair.

He also touched on the importance to this nation of a good quarantine inspection regime. I know that is an issue that goes to the heart of many Australians, because ours is an island nation and we ought to make sure that we continue to have a very strong quarantine inspection service in this country. The amendments in this bill will make sure that we have not only an effective service but also a more efficient one. The points raised by the member for Paterson clearly indicate that there are still many people who would like to bring into this nation products which would put at risk the great agricultural industries of this nation. Of course, diseases could afflict not only the agricultural industries but also the jobs that are generated as a result of the very successful agricultural industries which we have in this nation.

These amendments will certainly go a long way to addressing some of the sloppiness and lack of attention to detail shown by the former administration, and I thank those who participated in the debate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

BREAK.PARA: Message from the Governor‐General recommending appropriation for the purpose of amendments announced.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill—by leave—taken as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott, Bruce, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr BRUCE SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Schedule 5, page 11 (after line 3), before item 1, insert:
Insert:

exempt livestock proceeds means proceeds of a forced disposal of farm livestock by a person at a time when a drought exceptional circumstances certificate referred to in section 8A applied to the person, to the extent to which the proceeds are invested in:

PARA.TAB: (a) a deposit under the Loan (Income Equalization Deposits) Act 1976 ; or
(b) a deposit with a term of at least 3 months with a bank, building society, credit union or other institution that receives money on deposit.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Schedule 5, page 11 (after line 9), after item 2 insert:
Add:

PARA.TAB: (3) In calculating a rate referred to in subsection (1), exempt livestock proceeds are to be disregarded.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendment made by item 2A applies to the proceeds of disposals that occur after the commencement of this Schedule.

I would like to make a few points on the amendment of the Farm Household Support Act 1992. The amendments will correct an anomaly in the existing legislation governing the payment of drought relief payments. This was certainly adequately and very eloquently pointed out by the member for Paterson (Mr Bob Baldwin).

At present, for the purposes of drought relief payment, if a farmer is forced to dispose of livestock due to extreme drought conditions, the proceeds from the forced sale are treated as income for the year in which they are received, while in subsequent years they are treated as an asset. This means the proceeds are assessed under the income test for the drought relief payment. The effect of this treatment is that a farmer may be excluded from assistance under the drought relief payment or have his or her entitlement reduced. Following this amendment, all proceeds from the forced disposal of livestock will be excluded from the income test for the purpose of the drought relief payment. This is not only sensible but is a very necessary amendment to the drought relief payment under the Farm Household Support Act 1992.

There are many producers who, through extreme drought, have sold off their livestock and have been denied access to drought relief payments. It is important to point out to the committee that the drought relief payment is really an emergency relief payment that is to bring essential food and clothing items into families. There are those who had livestock in the past and had to sell them, through no fault of their own, through the circumstances of the drought, and were denied this. I know this is going to be welcomed by the farming community.

It is just another demonstration that this government understands the needs of those who live in rural and regional Australia. It is also another example of why we are on this side of the parliament. Those on the other side clearly did not understand the needs and the unfairness of how this was impacting under the previous drought relief arrangements.

In speaking to these amendments, I conclude by saying that I know that many members of the House will be able to advise their communities of this necessary change. It is about putting food on the table, basic clothing and support into the household, and they are very welcome amendments. I table the supplementary explanatory memoranda.
Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

DEBATE.TITLE: EDUCATION SERVICES FOR OVERSEAS STUDENTS (REGISTRATION OF PROVIDERS AND FINANCIAL REGULATION) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 1) 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 22 August.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abbott, Tony, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr ABBOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the bill be now read a second time.

The Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration of Providers and Financial Regulation) Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996 is a very simple bill. It proposes just one amendment to the principal act. That amendment is to section 20 and it ensures that the act continues to apply for a further two years until 1 January 1999.

Section 20 of the principal act, the Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration of Providers and Financial Regulation) Act 1991, is a sunset clause. It currently provides that the act ceases to have effect on 1 January 1997. This bill proposes changing that date to 1 January 1999. Extensive national industry consultations have indicated widespread support for this two‐year extension of the act.

The principal act provides assurances of education quality and financial protection to international students studying in Australia. It does so by registering providers of international education and training, based on state or territory approval and accreditation, and by imposing financial conditions on private education providers.

The principal act was introduced in 1991 to meet three main objectives, namely: to ensure that international students in Australia are treated with equity and fairness; to provide a positive basis for promoting Australia's international reputation as a provider of reliable high quality education and training; and to ensure that taxpayers' funds are not required to recompense international students who may have been let down by individual education and training providers.

These objectives remain relevant. This is not just the government's view, but the universal view of industry representatives expressed in recent national consultations by an independent consultant. This is an industry which currently earns Australia $1.9 billion in export revenue annually. It warrants proper protection and this bill allows that protection to continue.

BREAK.PARA: The act has included a sunset clause since its making in 1991. The original provision was for a three‐year sunset period. This was to allow development of complementary state and territory regulation and to ensure that the regulation of many small and medium sized businesses did not continue without review.

Unfortunately, states and territories have still not implemented legislation which would allow withdrawal of this act. Following review and extensive debate, the act was strengthened in 1993 and the sunset date was extended by another three years to the current 1 January 1997. Part of this extensive debate was consideration by the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, which has now contributed to consideration of this act on several occasions.

Consistent with the government's push to limit unnecessary business regulation, it is appropriate to retain a sunset clause in this act. The bill before the Main Committee seeks to extend the sunset date by only two years because this is considered sufficient time to allow further industry consultations and to develop simpler but still effective regulation in this industry. In particular, when the government has had the opportunity to fully consider the report of the current review, it expects to be able to bring forward further amendments to streamline this legislation.

The industry is an important and valuable one for Australia. It is a major part of our growth in the export of services, bringing many intangible benefits, including the development of contacts for future trade and diplomatic links, in addition to the $1.9 billion in export revenue annually. This industry deserves continuing protection. This bill is an important part of such protection. I commend the bill to the Main Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition supports the Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration of Providers and Financial Regulation) Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996. It extends the existing legislation for a further two years to ensure that there is a degree of financial and quality assurance in the provision of education services to overseas students.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation was introduced in response to a situation that developed at the beginning of this decade with regard to the credibility of much that was on offer from the non‐formal parts of Australia's education and training system; that is, not including the universities, the schools and the TAFE colleges, but the other providers. Some major questions emerged as to the financial viability and the quality of the courses offered by many of those institutions. I think it was universally accepted that a proper regulatory framework had to be put in place and that led to the introduction of this ESOS Act. As has been indicated by Mr Abbott, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, it has been looked at a number of times since and the original sunset clause has been extended.

Clearly, it is vitally important that we do this to protect what is now a very substantial export industry. There is no doubt that the success of that industry is very sensitive to the credibility and the reputation for quality of what is provided by Australian providers of education and training services, and that has to be protected.

The precise nature of the regulatory framework is a matter that one can debate. The previous government initiated a review, carried out by Ernst and Young, of the operation of the legislation. That review involved very extensive consultations with all the stakeholders, including the industry and the various tiers of government. I do not think there is any great dissent from the broad thrust of what emerged from that review.

The review canvassed a number of possible regulatory models, including the Commonwealth having the predominant role, or giving it to the states and territories, or having some sort of self‐regulatory arrangement with the industry. There was something approaching unanimity, I gather, that the right approach would be a cooperative regulatory scheme involving the Commonwealth and state and territory governments together with the industry. There was no great dissent from that.

The review also recommended the extension of the sunset clause for the existing legislation for a further two years. That is what the legislation we are dealing with today does, the idea being to provide a further period to enable the development of a more streamlined and simplified scheme of regulation. The opposition has no problem with that whatsoever, so that is all I will say.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Worth, Trish, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Following the collapse in the late 1980s of several private education providers who had offered services to overseas students—particularly from the Republic of China—and who had accepted a deposit payment of full fees, the Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration of Providers and Financial Regulation) Act was passed in 1991. Specifically, the government was forced to refund the fees of more than 12,000 international students in 1989 who were affected by the closure of private educational services.

SPEECH.PARA: Obviously this was embarrassing for everyone concerned and the principal bill was an attempt to ensure that this situation was not repeated. The principal act has since successfully given greater protection for overseas students, principally through the provision that education providers be registered, and fees paid by overseas students be placed into trust funds that may only be accessed in accordance with the regulations.

Section 20 of the act provides a sunset clause up to the beginning of January 1997. The purpose of this bill is to extend this sunset clause to 1 January 1999. The government has stated that, in this time, it is hoped that the industry will, in consultation with the government, be able to develop simpler and more effective self‐regulation. These are necessary and somewhat inevitable developments within an industry still in the maturing process. Australia's history in the overseas higher education sector began in the 1950s with Australia becoming an active participant in the Colombo Plan. This country initially provided 150 scholarships to students mainly from Commonwealth countries, Thailand, Malaysia and Indonesia.

Beginning with the University of Melbourne, Monash University and the University of New South Wales, strategies were developed in the 1960s for universities to become more accessible to overseas students. In 1969, these initiatives culminated in the Australian vice‐chancellors forming the Australian‐Asian universities cooperation scheme to strengthen research and teaching exchanges with foreign higher education facilities. After a further series of debates about the future of higher education provision during the 1970s and early 1980s, the Jackson report in 1984 concluded that the internationalisation of Australia's higher education should be encouraged.

This groundbreaking report stated that the higher education sector in this country needed to be more accessible for overseas students because `discouraging the entry of foreign students harms Australia's foreign relations, deprives the community of cultural contacts, and neglects a potential source of export earnings'. By 1988, every Australian education sector was aggressively competing for overseas students and, after some initial hiccups, consumer protection was extended to the growing number of overseas students in the form of the principal act.

I take this opportunity to inform the committee of the many benefits, apart from the immediate moneys received from fees, that overseas students bring to Australia, benefits which will only be enhanced as this industry develops, grows and matures. As I have already said, following the recommendations of the 1984 Jackson report, education facilities in Australia opened their doors to overseas fee paying students. Since 1986, the number of fee paying students in Australia has increased from 2,000 to around 81,000 in 1995. By far the greatest increase has come from the Asian region. Of the 70,000 students in 1994, 55,000 came from Asia. In 1994, 16.5 per cent of overseas students came from the People's Republic of China; 11.9 per cent, from Malaysia; 10.7 per cent, from Indonesia; and a further 9.5 per cent, from Hong Kong.

From a negligible amount of revenue received from fees from overseas students, the figure has grown and now stands at between $300 million and $400 million per year. Estimates for total net expenditure of overseas students in 1991‐92 in Australia ranged from $800 million to $1.2 billion per year. The total spending in 1994 of overseas students on course fees and stationery items alone amounted to well over $700 million.

Overseas students also, according to the Bureau of Immigration, Multicultural and Population Research, increase the aggregate demand for labour here in Australia by between 0.4 and 0.7 per cent. This so‐called `quasi export income' results from the expenditure of overseas students on locally produced goods and services. I might add at this stage that overseas students do not displace Australian students, nor are they subsidised. Unlike in the mid‐1980s, the overseas student industry has become trade rather than aid.

In the 1992 survey of international students, it was estimated that the average overseas student spends about $422 per week whilst in Australia. This can only be good for small business everywhere. The average student from Japan spends 48 weeks of the year in Australia studying, spending an annual total of $26,683. Apart from the education expenditure that overseas students outlay on other goods and services whilst here in Australia, they pay taxes and contribute to research and teaching and the internationalisation of business and training; they encourage future trade opportunities; they add to the cultural, social and political tapestry; they benefit post‐study immigration; and, importantly, they promote tourism by their friends and families, not only for the time that they are here but for many years after.

Overseas students do not harm local employment. Even if working rights are granted to overseas students, there remains a substantial net gain to local employment. The effect on employment levels within the higher education sector has naturally been the most dramatic, both in regards to academics and their support staff. There has been a fivefold increase over the period 1989 to 1995 of staff employed as a direct result of the presence of overseas students.

The presence of foreign students in our educational facilities also enables the higher education sector in Australia to be more effective in an increasingly international environment. Whilst rapid increases in technology, such as the Internet, have ensured a vigorous exchange of ideas and dialogue between students in different countries, nothing will ever compare with the physical exchange of students and the enriching experience they gain from spending study and recreational time in other countries.

BREAK.PARA: In a world where most industries are evolving a more international focus, the interaction of Australian and international students can only be seen as a good thing. In the fields of medicine, engineering, economics and development, to name just a few, the personal relationships begun here in Australia often lead to healthy and beneficial relationships of a business and humanitarian nature in the future. This promotes understanding, tolerance and mutual respect. Many of those studying here will become the leaders of tomorrow, especially in the Asian region. It benefits our objectives and national interests to understand and be better understood.

But we cannot underestimate just how competitive this industry is. America leads the way with 400,000 overseas students, followed by France with 125,000. Germany and Australia are roughly on equal terms with about 80,000 students. In recent years both Germany and France have attempted to restrict the future of growth in overseas student numbers, thereby presenting to Australia an opportunity to increase its share in this expanding market. Japan, however, has recently indicated its commitment to internationalising education and has plans for 100,000 students by the turn of the century. Australia therefore has to remain committed to providing quality education that guarantees that overseas students get what they paid for. This bill will go a long way in ensuring that this happens.

In detail, the principal bill requires accreditation for both the courses and institutions, which must remain proper in their recruitment of overseas students and must maintain notified trust accounts to be audited by DEETYA. The education providers must deposit all prepaid course money, refund fees if the institution closes and provide alternative arrangements in such a case.
As the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs has recently commented:
The partnership between education providers and the government ensures high quality student services through the combination of effective industry self‐regulation and a legislative safety net.

The government‐industry partnership in international education is now pursued directly through the Australian International Education Foundation, which provides support and continuous improvement. The Minister for Education has stated:

The Australian government is looking to a genuine and equal partnership with the education industry and to a commitment to continuous improvement of Australia's performance to ensure consistent achievement of international commercial best practice.

This act goes a long way in consolidating this relationship and coordinating private and public sector ambitions in the area of higher education provision to overseas students in the immediate future.

In conclusion, the ongoing protection for overseas students is a vital component to Australia remaining a popular choice for students, especially in the South‐East Asia region. The international competition between Australia and North America will only increase in the future and it is important that these safeguards remain until the industry is mature enough for self‐regulation and stability. The extension of the act's sunset clause is a judicious decision until this time. I commend the bill to the Main Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grace, Elizabeth, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration of Providers and Financial Regulation) Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996, the main intent of which is to postpone the sunset clause in the principal act from having effect until 1 January 1999. The principal legislation was enacted following disturbing events involving overseas students who had paid up‐front fees for training courses and were left in the lurch when private providers failed to honour their obligations.

SPEECH.PARA: The Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration of Providers and Financial Regulation) Act 1991 sought to achieve three main objectives: to ensure international students in Australia were fairly treated; to ensure Australia maintained its international reputation as a reliable provider of high quality education and training; and to ensure that Australian taxpayers were not again required to compensate for broken commitments of service providers. In short, the act provided an essential framework of protection for overseas students studying in Australia.

It is unfortunate that, since the passage of the Commonwealth act several years ago, complementary legislation has not been enacted in the states and territories. Consequently, the federal government has found it necessary to extend the sunset clause provision. In Queensland's case, it is a glaring indictment of the former Goss Labor government that it procrastinated and neglected this relatively simple task for years. I am glad to see that the current Queensland Minister for Education, Mr Bob Quinn, is taking the appropriate steps to alleviate this problem.

The extension of the sunset clause provision will enable governments, in consultation with industry, to devise a coherent regulatory scheme that will provide effective protection to overseas students. The legislation will also be in keeping with the federal government's initiatives against unnecessary red tape that needlessly hampers this industry.

The importance of this task should not be underestimated. The provision of education and training services to fee‐paying overseas students has been one of the quiet success stories of recent times, the magnitude of which still goes largely unrecognised. Australia's reputation in these overseas countries has been a pivotal element in Australia's past success, and is essential to the future expansion of the industry. In many ways it is astonishing to realise that, from its beginnings as a foreign aid scheme under the Colombo Plan, the provision of educational services to overseas students by Australian institutions and other providers has transformed into an industry which now earns Australia $1.9 billion annually.

The magnitude of this industry—for that is what it is—cannot be underestimated when institutions such as the University of Queensland can claim to be amongst Australia's top 500 exporters. The University of Queensland aims to have international students constituting five per cent of all enrolments, and when one looks at the facts it is not hard to see why this is a desirable outcome.

It has to be remembered that overseas students are enrolled over and above the course quotas for Australian students. They do not deny any Australian student a place at university. In purely economic terms, overseas students contribute enormously both to the economy and to the particular institutions they attend. The course fees paid contribute direct income to universities which decreases their reliance on government funding and helps the universities to stand on their own feet in this tight fiscal climate.

In 1994 fee‐paying undergraduate students from overseas comprised 2.3 per cent of the total undergraduate enrolments at the University of Queensland, but they contributed $6.6 million in income. Fee‐paying postgraduate students comprised 10.6 per cent of total postgraduate enrolments and contributed $8.1 million. Universities are not, however, the sole providers of educational services in this country.

BREAK.PARA: A prime example of a training provider set to earn export income for Australia is the Queensland Racing Industry Training Centre. The centre will be based in my electorate of Lilley and, as the federal member, I have a keen interest in its success. Lilley has the benefit of being the undisputed racing capital of Queensland. Within Lilley's boundaries fall most of south‐east Queensland's major race tracks, including Eagle Farm, Doomben, Albion Park and the Deagon training track.

Almost 1,000 thoroughbred horses are trained in the electorate, and the suburbs of Hendra, Hamilton and Ascot provide the traditional base for the stabling of horses in south‐east Queensland. The Queensland Turf Club at Eagle Farm and the Brisbane Turf Club at Doomben have a total membership of about 4,000 people. Consequently, it is fair to say that the success of the Queensland Racing Industry Training Centre is of vital importance to the economic wellbeing of Lilley.

The Queensland Racing Industry Training Centre's one‐year course is specifically designed for international students who want a career in the Australian racing and breeding industry. Students will study in Brisbane and at the University of Queensland's Gatton campus. While the course is nationally accredited, it is only available in Queensland. Features of the course include a specially designed English language program. Opportunities to specialise in specific areas of the racing industry, such as track riding, race riding and stud management, are also available. Students will exit the course with a vocational certificate at ASF level II.

The importance of the Education Services for Overseas Students Amendment Bill cannot be underestimated in the case of the Queensland Racing Industry Training Centre. The first intake of 56 Japanese students in January this year has been very successful. These students have already contributed almost $2 million to our economy, by way of fees and accommodation, and they help reduce the cost of the training to our own students.

This bill should assist the Queensland Racing Industry Training Centre to market its courses in Asia and future students will be excellent advocates for promoting our racing industry. It is estimated that within the next five to 10 years at least 10 new racetracks will be open in China alone. This will require the purchase of more than 10,000 horses and expanded infrastructure in a country with no racing expertise. We therefore have the opportunity to educate people who will eventually become influential in the South‐East Asian, Chinese and Japanese racing industries. This strong network can only benefit the Australian industry in terms of racing, breeding and tourism. Already, 50 per cent of the students are indicating they would like to study advanced courses in Australia.

Finally, the development of our integrated racing training complex in south‐east Queensland, with the support of the Queensland Racing Industry Training Centre, would be an excellent platform for the Australian racing industry to seek further markets in South‐East Asia. I have no hesitation in supporting the bill, as the importance of our engagement with overseas students should be fostered and, above all, their interests protected. Through this interaction, the educational lives of both Australians and overseas students may be enriched and Australia may earn significant export dollars in return.
Debate (on motion by Mr Slipper) adjourned.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Smith, Warwick, MP

TALK.START.PARA: — The Minister for the Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: I can only answer these questions insofar as they seek information about the Environment, Sport and Territories Portfolio. Table 1
(a) The Waterwatch Australia Program

This program aims to provide a national community based water quality and aquatic biodiversity monitoring program. It aims to catalyse the establishment of community driven monitoring programs in all parts of Australia, and especially in areas of high nature conservation value.
The Feral Pests Program

This program was established in 1992/93 with the objective being to reduce the impact of feral animal pests on native species and the natural environment, particularly in areas important for the recovery of endangered species through the development and implementation of projects in cooper ation with other Commonwealth authorities and State and Territory agencies.
River Murray Corridor of Green Program

This program seeks to restore the River Murray to ecological sustainability by protecting, extending and linking remnant native vegetation on public and private land to enhance productivity and biodiversity.

The Program concluded in 1995-96, but the work of the River Murray Corridor of Green will continue to be funded, possibly at a reduced level, via the National Corridors of Green Program. Greening Australia Ltd implements the Program, under contract to the Australian Nature Conservation Agency.

The Program assists local people to extend existing vegetation corridors along riversides, rail-lines, roadsides and ridgelines, and to link them together into a network of vegetation to help combat land degradation and loss of biological diversity. Successful consortia of local government, landholders, landcare and other community groups received up to $75,000 over two years under community incentive contracts.
Drought Landcare Program

The objective of this program is to stimulate on-ground landcare activities to protect land, water and vegetation resources from the effects of drought; to assist in preparation for post-drought recovery; and to mobilise the long term unemployed in these activities and to address the employment needs of farmers, their families and farm workers.

Uluru-Kata Tjuta Tourism Management was established under the December 1992 Statement on the Environment. The extra funds, used to protect the Park from such pressures, will achieve the dual objectives of supporting a valuable tourism industry while sustaining the ecological and cultural values of the area. The Australian Nature Conservation Agency will use the funds to carry out erosion control, stabilisation of viewing area and other works.
Ozone Protection Program

The objective of this program is to meet Australia's obligations to protect the ozone layer by working with relevant industry sectors, government and the community, and contribute to international efforts in ozone protection to ensure that Australia's achievements are not eroded by a lack of adequate or timely action in the rest of the world.
The National Pollutant Inventory

This Inventory will provide information on emissions to the environment, for use by industry, governments and the community. It will provide part of the information base for good policy making, for planning, cleaner production and waste minimisation.
The goals of the Inventory are to:

PARA.TAB: provide information to enhance and facilitate policy formulation and decision making for environmental planning and management;
satisfy community needs by providing publicly accessible and available information, on a geographic basis about being released to the environment, especially those of hazardous nature;
promote and facilitate waste minimisation cleaner production programs for industry and government; and
assist Australia in meeting international obligations.

ANSWER.PARA: National Reserve System Cooperative Program
The objectives of the Program are to:

PARA.TAB: expand existing government programs for developing and implementing a bioregional approach to identifying protected areas;
provide incentives to the States and Territories to cooperate in progressively developing the national system by the year 2000, including providing funds for land acquisition;
develop and apply national management principles for protected areas, in association with the States and Territories, which are in line with international standards.

ANSWER.PARA: World Heritage Management

The program aims to develop consistent management arrangements and structures, including Ministerial Councils for each State, community consultation and scientific advisory bodies tailored to the needs of individual properties. The program aims to develop and implement management plans for all World Heritage properties.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Rocher, Allan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 18 June 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to his statement in answer to my question without notice concerning contingent debt (Hansard , 28 May 1996, page 1505) that the Government will make policy decisions on taxation matters, has his attention been drawn to taxation ruling SST6.

(2) Is it a fact that from 1 October 1996 major changes to the interpretation of tax laws will come into effect and that (a) goods producers, including manufacturers, goods processors and fabricators, (b) importers, (c) wholesalers, (d) retailers, (e) indirect marketers, including direct sellers, (f) end users, (g) taxpayers who sell to related entities and (h) duty free operators will be affected; if so, was the decision to make the changes taken by the current Government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: — The Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, I have received a copy of SST6 from the Australian Taxation Office (ATO). This public ruling is not a change of Government policy. The ATO in conjunction with professional bodies and taxpayer representatives has developed a comprehensive ruling to assist taxpayers to determine the taxable value of the goods they sell. The ruling deals with and provides solutions for issues affecting the calculation of taxable value of goods which is a major building block in the sales tax law. The ruling seeks to assist taxpayers by explaining the practical application of Government policy.

Next to the difficulties experienced in correctly classifying goods for sales tax purposes, determining the taxable value of goods is the most common and time consuming problem faced by both the ATO and taxpayers. For this reason publishing a public taxation ruling on taxable value was considered to be of some priority by the ATO, sales tax practitioners and large corporate taxpayers.

(2) This ruling is the result of intensive negotiations over the last 2 years with sales tax professional bodies, industry bodies and the ATO. It provides certainty and consistency through the use of Safe Harbours that can be adopted by taxpayers. These are practical guidelines to help make taxable value calculations easier and will provide clarity for taxpayers to self assess their sales tax dealings. While safe harbours are not mandatory, if taxpayers apply them and pay sales tax at the correct rate they will have met their sales tax liability for that transaction.
The ruling provides simplified methods of calculating taxable value and may reduce the cost of compliance for taxpayers who choose that option.

In conjunction with the professional bodies and the Corporate Taxpayers Association, the ATO has included processes in the ruling to manage the impact of the withdrawal of previous rulings and to give taxpayers time to consider their position. If a previous ruling conflicts with the principles in the new public ruling, it will be altered from 1 October 1996 giving taxpayers time to consider their position and to approach the ATO if their circumstances are not adequately dealt with in the ruling. If there is no conflict of principles, all private rulings issued after 30 June 1992 will cease to be effective 5 years from their date of issue.
To date the ruling has been very well received by both the practitioners and taxpayers and there have been a number of positive reports in the media.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Thomson, Kelvin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 19 June 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: Has he endorsed the Industry Commission's recommendations against compulsory third party property insurance; if so, what steps will he take to encourage the Insurance Council of Australia to repeat its advertising campaign in South Australia which resulted in a 7 per cent increase in cover over a two month period.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The government's response to the Industry Commission's report was announced in my Press Release of 3 May 1996. In that response, I noted that the Commonwealth would raise in the Council of Australian Governments' Committee on Regulatory Reform those recommendations of the Commission that fall within the jurisdiction of the States and Territories. The question of compulsory third party property damage is one such issue.

The Commonwealth Government generally supports the Industry Commission recommendation that State and Territory Governments should not introduce a compulsory third party property damage insurance scheme in any form that limits insurers' underwriting flexibility.

Any government imposed limitation on the underwriting discretion of insurers (for example, to mandate coverage and/or premium rates) could have an adverse impact on insurers' solvency and their capacity to pay claims. This may discourage insurers from participating in the vehicle insurance market and reduce the level of competition which acts to keep premiums to a minimum. Alternatively, insurers might seek government guarantees against adverse outcomes flowing from any limitations imposed on their underwriting discretion.

I am informed that the Insurance Council of Australia's campaign in South Australia was not a direct response to the Industry Commission's report, but to local circumstances and that it was wholly funded by the insurance industry. The Government is of the view that advertising campaigns of that nature are solely for the commercial discretion of the industry.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Lee Michael

TALK.START.PARA: Answer to question by the Honourable Michael Lee to the Prime Minister asked in question time on 10 September 1996, which was taken on notice by the Prime Minister.

ANSWER.PARA: `My office and I communicate on a regular basis with the Minister for Health and Family Services and his office about a wide range of issues pertaining to health policy matters, including private health insurance. To the best of my knowledge and the knowledge of my office, at no time prior to 28 August 1996 did the Minister for Health and Family Services or his office advise me or my office that the Minister had been aware at the time of the Budget of any funds having been granted increases in their rates.

On 28 August 1996, after the Herald‐Sun published an article, my office contacted the office of the Minister for Health and Family Services which informed my office that there had been a number of increases in private health insurance premiums since the Government assumed office and provided my office with the details of a number of these increases.

On 29 August 1996, the office of the Minister for Health and Family Services provided my office with a letter from National Mutual Health Insurance dated 25 July 1996 addressed to the Minister for Health and Family Services advising him of an adjustment in rates. This letter was brought to my attention on 29 August 1996. On 29 August 1996, my office was informed by the Minister's office that none of the increases which had taken place since the Government assumed office had been brought to the attention of the Minister for Health and Family Services by his department.

On 29 August 1996 and 30 August 1996, my office and I had a number of conversations with the Minister for Health and Family Services and his office about private health insurance premium increases. In the course of those conversations, my office and I were informed that the Minister had personally been aware of at least one of these increases before the Budget.

There is absolutely no disagreement between the Minister and me on any issues of substance relating to this matter. The last part of the Honourable Member's question must be considered in its correct context, whereby earlier in Question Time today the Minister was responding to interjections from the Opposition as to whether he had a responsibility to inform me of an advertisement in a newspaper.'
